   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Slovenia
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div class="noprint" id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>
    <div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
     Jump to:
     <a href="#mw-head">
      navigation
     </a>
     ,
     <a href="#p-search">
      search
     </a>
    </div>
    <div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       This article is about the country bordering the Adriatic Sea. For the landlocked country to its northeast, see
       <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">
        Slovakia
       </a>
       . For the historic region of Croatia to its east, see
       <a href="/wiki/Slavonia" title="Slavonia">
        Slavonia
       </a>
       . For other uses, see
       <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Slovene_(disambiguation)" title="Slovene (disambiguation)">
        Slovene (disambiguation)
       </a>
       .
      </div>
      <p>
       <span style="font-size: small;">
        <span id="coordinates">
         <a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">
          Coordinates
         </a>
         :
         <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion">
          <a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Slovenia&amp;params=46_07_N_14_49_E_">
           <span class="geo-default">
            <span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
             <span class="latitude">
              46°07′N
             </span>
             <span class="longitude">
              14°49′E
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
           <span class="geo-multi-punct">
            ﻿ / ﻿
           </span>
           <span class="geo-nondefault">
            <span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
             46.117°N 14.817°E
            </span>
            <span style="display:none">
             ﻿ /
             <span class="geo">
              46.117; 14.817
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </a>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </p>

      <p>
       <b>
        Slovenia
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="'s' in 'sigh'">
            s
           </span>
           <span title="'l' in 'lie'">
            l
           </span>
           <span title="/oʊ/: 'o' in 'code'">
            oʊ
           </span>
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="'v' in 'vie'">
            v
           </span>
           <span title="/iː/: 'ee' in 'fleece'">
            iː
           </span>
           <span title="'n' in 'nigh'">
            n
           </span>
           <span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">
            i
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
          </span>
          ,
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="'s' in 'sigh'">
            s
           </span>
           <span title="'l' in 'lie'">
            l
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
          </span>
          -/
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Slovenia.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8b/En-us-Slovenia.ogg" title="En-us-Slovenia.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
        <a href="#cite_note-18">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key">
        <i title="English pronunciation respelling">
         sloh-
         <span style="font-size:90%">
          VEE
         </span>
         -nee-ə
        </i>
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">
        Slovene
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="sl">
         Slovenija
        </span>
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Slovene" title="Help:IPA/Slovene">
         [slɔˈʋèːnija]
        </a>
       </span>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       officially the
       <b>
        Republic of Slovenia
       </b>
       (Slovene:
       <span class="unicode haudio">
        <span class="fn">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sl-Republika_Slovenija.oga" title="About this sound">
           <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4d/Sl-Republika_Slovenija.oga" title="Sl-Republika Slovenija.oga">
          <i>
           Republika Slovenija
          </i>
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">
         (
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           help
          </span>
         </a>
         ·
         <a href="/wiki/File:Sl-Republika_Slovenija.oga" title="File:Sl-Republika Slovenija.oga">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           info
          </span>
         </a>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Abbreviation" title="Abbreviation">
        abbr.
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        RS
       </i>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ), is a
       <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">
        nation state
       </a>
       located in southern
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
        Central Europe
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Armstrong2007_23-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Armstrong2007-23">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [Note 2]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country is located at the crossroads of main European cultural and trade routes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
        <a href="#cite_note-29">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
        <a href="#cite_note-30">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is bordered by Italy to the west, Austria to the north, Hungary to the northeast, Croatia to the south and southeast, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">
        Adriatic Sea
       </a>
       to the southwest.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
        <a href="#cite_note-31">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It covers 20,273 square kilometers (7,827 sq mi) and has a population of 2.06 million.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
        <a href="#cite_note-32">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is a
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">
        parliamentary republic
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
        <a href="#cite_note-33">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The capital and largest city is
       <a href="/wiki/Ljubljana" title="Ljubljana">
        Ljubljana
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
        <a href="#cite_note-35">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The territory is mostly mountainous
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-perko2008_36-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-perko2008-36">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with a mainly
       <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">
        continental climate
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fallon2007_37-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Fallon2007-37">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with the exception of the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
        Slovene Littoral
       </a>
       , which has a sub-
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">
        Mediterranean climate
       </a>
       , and the northwest, which has an
       <a href="/wiki/Alpine_climate" title="Alpine climate">
        Alpine climate
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Additionally, the
       <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Alps" title="Dinaric Alps">
        Dinaric Alps
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pannonian_Plain" title="Pannonian Plain">
        Pannonian Plain
       </a>
       meet on the territory of Slovenia. The country, marked by a significant biological diversity,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
        <a href="#cite_note-40">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is one of the most water-rich in Europe,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
        <a href="#cite_note-41">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with a dense river network, a rich
       <a href="/wiki/Aquifer" title="Aquifer">
        aquifer
       </a>
       system, and significant
       <a href="/wiki/Karst" title="Karst">
        karst
       </a>
       underground watercourses.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Over half of the territory is covered by forest.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
        <a href="#cite_note-43">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The human settlement of Slovenia is dispersed and uneven.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
        <a href="#cite_note-44">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Slovenia has historically been the crossroads of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Slavic" title="West Slavic">
        West Slavic
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/South_Slavic_languages" title="South Slavic languages">
        South Slavic
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">
        Germanic
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">
        Romance
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       languages and culture.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
        <a href="#cite_note-45">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
        <a href="#cite_note-46">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
        <a href="#cite_note-47">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Although the population is not homogeneous, the majority is
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenes" title="Slovenes">
        Slovene
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The South Slavic language
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">
        Slovene
       </a>
       is the official language throughout the country. Slovenia is a largely
       <a href="/wiki/Secularization" title="Secularization">
        secularized
       </a>
       country,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but its culture and identity have been significantly influenced by
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">
        Catholicism
       </a>
       as well as
       <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">
        Lutheranism
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Strubelj_50-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Strubelj-50">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Slovenia" title="Economy of Slovenia">
        economy of Slovenia
       </a>
       is small, open, and
       <a href="/wiki/Export-oriented_industrialization" title="Export-oriented industrialization">
        export-oriented
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and has been strongly influenced by international conditions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It has been severely hurt by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurozone_crisis" title="Eurozone crisis">
        Eurozone crisis
       </a>
       , started in the late 2000s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VE2012-03-15_53-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-VE2012-03-15-53">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The main economic field is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Service_sector" title="Service sector">
        services
       </a>
       , followed by industry and construction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UMAR2011-09_54-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UMAR2011-09-54">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Historically, the current territory of Slovenia was part of many different state formations, including the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Roman Empire
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">
        Holy Roman Empire
       </a>
       , followed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Monarchy" title="Habsburg Monarchy">
        Habsburg Monarchy
       </a>
       . In October 1918, the Slovenes exercised self-determination for the first time by co-founding the
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Slovenes,_Croats_and_Serbs" title="State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs">
        State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs
       </a>
       . In December 1918, they merged with the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">
        Kingdom of Serbia
       </a>
       into the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbs,_Croats_and_Slovenes" title="Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes">
        Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes
       </a>
       (renamed
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Kingdom of Yugoslavia">
        Kingdom of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       in 1929). During
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       , Slovenia was occupied and annexed by
       <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">
        Germany
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary_(1920%E2%80%9346)" title="Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)">
        Hungary
       </a>
       , with a tiny area transferred to the
       <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">
        Independent State of Croatia
       </a>
       , a Nazi puppet state.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sečen2005_55-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-sečen2005-55">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Afterward, it was a founding member of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_People%27s_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia">
        Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       , later renamed the
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">
        Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       , a communist state which was the only country in the Eastern Bloc which was never part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">
        Warsaw Pact
       </a>
       . In June 1991, after the introduction of
       <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">
        multi-party
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">
        representative democracy
       </a>
       , Slovenia split from Yugoslavia and became an independent country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Škrk1999_9-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Škrk1999-9">
         [6]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2004, it entered NATO and the European Union; in 2007 became the first
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Postcommunism" title="Postcommunism">
        formerly communist
       </a>
       country to join the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
        Eurozone
       </a>
       ;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
        <a href="#cite_note-56">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and in 2010 joined the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        OECD
       </a>
       , a global association of high-income developed countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>
      <div class="toc" id="toc">
       <div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en">

        </li>

          </span>

        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-35">

          </span>

         <ul>

           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-41">
         <a href="#Education">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           7
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Education
          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-42">
         <a href="#Culture">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           8
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Culture
          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-43">
           <a href="#Heritage">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.1
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Heritage
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-44">
           <a href="#Comedy">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.2
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Comedy
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-45">
           <a href="#Cuisine">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.3
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Cuisine
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-46">
           <a href="#Dance">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.4
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Dance
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-47">
           <a href="#Festivals,_book_fairs,_and_other_events">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.5
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Festivals, book fairs, and other events
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-48">
           <a href="#Film">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.6
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Film
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-49">
           <a href="#Literature">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.7
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Literature
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-50">
           <a href="#Music">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.8
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Music
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-51">
           <a href="#Theatre">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.9
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Theatre
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-52">
           <a href="#Visual_arts,_architecture_and_design">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.10
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Visual arts, architecture and design
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-53">

          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-54">
         <a href="#See_also">

          </span>

        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-55">

         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-56">

        </li>

          </span>

        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-58">

          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Slovenia" title="History of Slovenia">
        History of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_to_Slavic_settlement">
        Prehistory to Slavic settlement
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Prehistory to Slavic settlement">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">
        Prehistory
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Prehistory">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:112px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fl%C3%BBte_pal%C3%A9olithique_(mus%C3%A9e_national_de_Slov%C3%A9nie,_Ljubljana)_(9420310527).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Fl%C3%BBte_pal%C3%A9olithique_%28mus%C3%A9e_national_de_Slov%C3%A9nie%2C_Ljubljana%29_%289420310527%29.jpg/110px-Fl%C3%BBte_pal%C3%A9olithique_%28mus%C3%A9e_national_de_Slov%C3%A9nie%2C_Ljubljana%29_%289420310527%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Fl%C3%BBte_pal%C3%A9olithique_%28mus%C3%A9e_national_de_Slov%C3%A9nie%2C_Ljubljana%29_%289420310527%29.jpg/165px-Fl%C3%BBte_pal%C3%A9olithique_%28mus%C3%A9e_national_de_Slov%C3%A9nie%2C_Ljubljana%29_%289420310527%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Fl%C3%BBte_pal%C3%A9olithique_%28mus%C3%A9e_national_de_Slov%C3%A9nie%2C_Ljubljana%29_%289420310527%29.jpg/220px-Fl%C3%BBte_pal%C3%A9olithique_%28mus%C3%A9e_national_de_Slov%C3%A9nie%2C_Ljubljana%29_%289420310527%29.jpg 2x" width="110"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fl%C3%BBte_pal%C3%A9olithique_(mus%C3%A9e_national_de_Slov%C3%A9nie,_Ljubljana)_(9420310527).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Divje_Babe_flute" title="Divje Babe flute">
          pierced cave bear bone
         </a>
         , possibly a
         <a href="/wiki/Flute" title="Flute">
          flute
         </a>
         , from
         <a href="/wiki/Divje_Babe" title="Divje Babe">
          Divje Babe
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Present-day Slovenia has been inhabited since
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prehistoric" title="Prehistoric">
        prehistoric
       </a>
       times, and there is evidence of
       <a href="/wiki/Human_settlement" title="Human settlement">
        human habitation
       </a>
       from around 250,000 years ago.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
        <a href="#cite_note-58">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Divje_Babe_flute" title="Divje Babe flute">
        pierced cave bear bone
       </a>
       , dating from 43100 ± 700
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Before_present" title="Before present">
        BP
       </a>
       , found in 1995 in Divje Babe cave near
       <a href="/wiki/Cerkno" title="Cerkno">
        Cerkno
       </a>
       , is possibly the oldest musical instrument discovered in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the 1920s and 1930s, artifacts belonging to the
       <a href="/wiki/Cro-Magnon" title="Cro-Magnon">
        Cro-Magnon
       </a>
       such as pierced bones, bone points, and needle were found by archaeologist
       <a href="/wiki/Sre%C4%8Dko_Brodar" title="Srečko Brodar">
        Srečko Brodar
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Potok_Cave" title="Potok Cave">
        Potok Cave
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_61-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-61">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2002,
       <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_pile_dwellings_around_the_Alps" title="Prehistoric pile dwellings around the Alps">
        remains of pile dwellings
       </a>
       over 4,500 years old were discovered in the
       <a href="/wiki/Ljubljana_Marshes" title="Ljubljana Marshes">
        Ljubljana Marshes
       </a>
       , now protected as a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">
        UNESCO World Heritage Site
       </a>
       , along with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ljubljana_Marshes_Wooden_Wheel" title="Ljubljana Marshes Wooden Wheel">
        Ljubljana Marshes Wooden Wheel
       </a>
       , the oldest wooden
       <a href="/wiki/Wheel" title="Wheel">
        wheel
       </a>
       in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Oldest_Wooden_Wheel_in_the_World_62-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_Oldest_Wooden_Wheel_in_the_World-62">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It shows that wooden wheels appeared almost simultaneously in Mesopotamia and Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slovenia_63-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Slovenia-63">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the transition period between the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bronze_age" title="Bronze age">
        Bronze age
       </a>
       to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iron_age" title="Iron age">
        Iron age
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urnfield" title="Urnfield">
        Urnfield
       </a>
       culture flourished. Archaeological remains dating from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hallstatt_period" title="Hallstatt period">
        Hallstatt period
       </a>
       have been found, particularly in southeastern Slovenia, among them a number of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Situla_(vessel)" title="Situla (vessel)">
        situlas
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Novo_Mesto" title="Novo Mesto">
        Novo Mesto
       </a>
       , the "Town of Situlas".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google2008_64-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-google2008-64">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">
        Iron Age
       </a>
       , present-day Slovenia was inhabited by
       <a href="/wiki/Illyrians" title="Illyrians">
        Illyrian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">
        Celtic
       </a>
       tribes until the 1st century BC.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Roman_era">
        Roman era
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Roman era">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Emona_v_Ljubljani_(6).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="698" data-file-width="1024" height="102" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Emona_v_Ljubljani_%286%29.jpg/150px-Emona_v_Ljubljani_%286%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Emona_v_Ljubljani_%286%29.jpg/225px-Emona_v_Ljubljani_%286%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Emona_v_Ljubljani_%286%29.jpg/300px-Emona_v_Ljubljani_%286%29.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Emona_v_Ljubljani_(6).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Roman
         <a href="/wiki/Emona" title="Emona">
          Emona
         </a>
         's south wall (reconstruction) in present-day Ljubljana
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The area that is present-day Slovenia was in Roman times shared between
       <i>
        Venetia et Histria
       </i>
       (region X of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italia_(Roman_Empire)" title="Italia (Roman Empire)">
        Roman Italia
       </a>
       in the classification of
       <a href="/wiki/Augustus" title="Augustus">
        Augustus
       </a>
       ) and the provinces
       <a href="/wiki/Pannonia" title="Pannonia">
        Pannonia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Noricum" title="Noricum">
        Noricum
       </a>
       . The Romans established posts at
       <a href="/wiki/Emona" title="Emona">
        Emona
       </a>
       (Ljubljana),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poetovio" title="Poetovio">
        Poetovio
       </a>
       (Ptuj), and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Celeia" title="Celeia">
        Celeia
       </a>
       (Celje); and constructed trade and military roads that ran across Slovene territory from Italy to Pannonia. In the 5th and 6th centuries, the area was subject to invasions by the
       <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">
        Huns
       </a>
       and Germanic tribes during their incursions into
       <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       . A part of the inner state was protected with a defensive line of towers and walls called
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Claustra_Alpium_Iuliarum" title="Claustra Alpium Iuliarum">
         Claustra Alpium Iuliarum
        </a>
       </i>
       . A
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Frigidus" title="Battle of the Frigidus">
        crucial battle
       </a>
       between
       <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">
        Theodosius I
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Eugenius" title="Eugenius">
        Eugenius
       </a>
       took place in the
       <a href="/wiki/Vipava_Valley" title="Vipava Valley">
        Vipava Valley
       </a>
       in 394.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Slavic_settlement">
        Slavic settlement
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Slavic settlement">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slavic_peoples" title="Slavic peoples">
        Slavic
       </a>
       tribes migrated to the Alpine area after the westward departure of the
       <a href="/wiki/Lombards" title="Lombards">
        Lombards
       </a>
       (the last Germanic tribe) in 568, and under pressure from
       <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Avars" title="Pannonian Avars">
        Avars
       </a>
       established a
       <a href="/wiki/Slavic_settlement_of_the_Eastern_Alps" title="Slavic settlement of the Eastern Alps">
        Slavic settlement in the Eastern Alps
       </a>
       . From 623 to 624 or possibly 626 onwards,
       <a href="/wiki/Samo" title="Samo">
        King Samo
       </a>
       united the Alpine and Western Slavs against the Avars and Germanic peoples and established what is referred to as Samo's Kingdom. After its disintegration following Samo's death in 658 or 659, the ancestors of the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenes" title="Slovenes">
        Slovenes
       </a>
       located in present-day
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carinthia_(state)" title="Carinthia (state)">
        Carinthia
       </a>
       formed the independent
       <a href="/wiki/Carantania" title="Carantania">
        duchy of Carantania
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Carniola" title="Carniola">
        Carniola
       </a>
       , later duchy Carniola. Other parts of present-day Slovenia were again ruled by Avars before
       <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">
        Charlemagne
       </a>
       's victory over them in 803.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Landhaus_Wappensaal_Fuerstenstein_01.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Landhaus_Wappensaal_Fuerstenstein_01.jpg/150px-Landhaus_Wappensaal_Fuerstenstein_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Landhaus_Wappensaal_Fuerstenstein_01.jpg/225px-Landhaus_Wappensaal_Fuerstenstein_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Landhaus_Wappensaal_Fuerstenstein_01.jpg/300px-Landhaus_Wappensaal_Fuerstenstein_01.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Landhaus_Wappensaal_Fuerstenstein_01.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Prince%27s_Stone" title="Prince's Stone">
          Prince's Stone
         </a>
         , symbol of
         <a href="/wiki/Carantania" title="Carantania">
          duchy of Carantania
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Middle Ages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Carantanians" title="Carantanians">
        Carantanians
       </a>
       , one of the ancestral groups of the modern Slovenes, particularly the
       <a href="/wiki/Carinthian_Slovenes" title="Carinthian Slovenes">
        Carinthian Slovenes
       </a>
       , were the first Slavic people to
       <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_the_Slavs" title="Christianization of the Slavs">
        accept Christianity
       </a>
       . They were mostly Christianized by
       <a href="/wiki/Irish_people" title="Irish people">
        Irish
       </a>
       missionaries, among them
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modestus" title="Modestus">
        Modestus
       </a>
       , known as the "Apostle of Carantanians". This process, together with the Christianization of the
       <a href="/wiki/Bavarians" title="Bavarians">
        Bavarians
       </a>
       , was later described in the memorandum known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Conversio_Bagoariorum_et_Carantanorum" title="Conversio Bagoariorum et Carantanorum">
        Conversio Bagoariorum et Carantanorum
       </a>
       , which is thought to have overemphasized the role of the Church of Salzburg in the Christianization process over similar efforts of the Patriarchate of
       <a href="/wiki/Aquileia" title="Aquileia">
        Aquileia
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kaernten_herzogeinsetzung.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="740" data-file-width="1000" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Kaernten_herzogeinsetzung.jpg/180px-Kaernten_herzogeinsetzung.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Kaernten_herzogeinsetzung.jpg/270px-Kaernten_herzogeinsetzung.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Kaernten_herzogeinsetzung.jpg/360px-Kaernten_herzogeinsetzung.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kaernten_herzogeinsetzung.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A depiction of an ancient democratic ritual of Slovene-speaking tribes, which took place on the
         <a href="/wiki/Prince%27s_Stone" title="Prince's Stone">
          Prince's Stone
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">
          Slovene language
         </a>
         until 1414.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In the mid-8th century, Carantania became a vassal duchy under the rule of the
       <a href="/wiki/Bavaria" title="Bavaria">
        Bavarians
       </a>
       , who began
       <a href="/wiki/Christianization" title="Christianization">
        spreading Christianity
       </a>
       . Three decades later, the
       <a href="/wiki/Carantanians" title="Carantanians">
        Carantanians
       </a>
       were incorporated, together with the Bavarians, into the
       <a href="/wiki/Carolingian_Empire" title="Carolingian Empire">
        Carolingian Empire
       </a>
       . During the same period
       <a href="/wiki/Carniola" title="Carniola">
        Carniola
       </a>
       , too, came under the Franks, and was Christianised from
       <a href="/wiki/Aquileia" title="Aquileia">
        Aquileia
       </a>
       . Following the anti-Frankish rebellion of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liudewit" title="Liudewit">
        Liudewit
       </a>
       at the beginning of the 9th century, the
       <a href="/wiki/Franks" title="Franks">
        Franks
       </a>
       removed the Carantanian princes, replacing them with their own border dukes. Consequently, the Frankish
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feudal_system" title="Feudal system">
        feudal system
       </a>
       reached the Slovene territory.
      </p>
      <p>
       After the victory of Emperor
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Otto_I" title="Otto I">
        Otto I
       </a>
       over the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magyars" title="Magyars">
        Magyars
       </a>
       in 955, Slovene territory was divided into a number of border regions of the
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">
        Holy Roman Empire
       </a>
       . Carantania, being the most important, was elevated into the
       <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Carinthia" title="Duchy of Carinthia">
        Duchy of Carinthia
       </a>
       in 976.
      </p>
      <p>
       By the 11th century, the Germanization of what is now
       <a href="/wiki/Lower_Austria" title="Lower Austria">
        Lower Austria
       </a>
       , effectively isolated the Slovene-inhabited territory from the other
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Slavs" title="Western Slavs">
        western Slavs
       </a>
       , speeding up the development of the
       <a href="/wiki/Carantanians" title="Carantanians">
        Slavs of Carantania
       </a>
       and of
       <a href="/wiki/Carniola" title="Carniola">
        Carniola
       </a>
       into an independent Carantanian/Carniolans/Slovene ethnic group. By the late Middle Ages, the historic provinces of Carniola,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Styria_(duchy)" title="Styria (duchy)">
        Styria
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carinthia_(duchy)" title="Carinthia (duchy)">
        Carinthia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/County_of_Gorizia" title="County of Gorizia">
        Gorizia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">
        Trieste
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Istria" title="Istria">
        Istria
       </a>
       developed from the border regions and were incorporated into the medieval German state. The consolidation and formation of these historical lands took place in a long period between the 11th and 14th centuries, and were led by a number of important feudal families, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Bernhard_von_Spanheim" title="Bernhard von Spanheim">
        Dukes of Spannheim
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Meinhardiner" title="Meinhardiner">
        Counts of Gorizia
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Counts_of_Celje" title="Counts of Celje">
        Counts of Celje
       </a>
       , and, finally, the
       <a href="/wiki/House_of_Habsburg" title="House of Habsburg">
        House of Habsburg
       </a>
       . In a parallel process, an intensive German colonization significantly diminished the extent of Slovene-speaking areas. By the 15th century, the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Lands" title="Slovene Lands">
        Slovene ethnic territory
       </a>
       was reduced to its present size.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture.si_66-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-culture.si-66">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 14th century, most of the territory of present-day Slovenia was taken over by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habsburgs" title="Habsburgs">
        Habsburgs
       </a>
       , the Hungarian clan
       <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%A1h_(gens)" title="Záh (gens)">
        Záh
       </a>
       administering the territories connecting Slovenia with
       <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">
        Slovakia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Moravia" title="Moravia">
        Moravia
       </a>
       was exterminated in 1330 and the Slovenes permanently lost the connection with their
       <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">
        Slovak
       </a>
       kinsmen. The
       <a href="/wiki/Counts_of_Celje" title="Counts of Celje">
        counts of Celje
       </a>
       , a feudal family from this area who in 1436 acquired the title of state princes, were
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habsburgs" title="Habsburgs">
        Habsburgs
       </a>
       ' powerful competitors for some time. This large dynasty, important at a European political level, had its seat in Slovene territory but died out in 1456. Its numerous large estates subsequently became the property of the Habsburgs, who retained control of the area right up until the beginning of the 20th century.
       <a href="/wiki/Patria_del_Friuli" title="Patria del Friuli">
        Patria del Friuli
       </a>
       ruled present western Slovenia until
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">
        Venetian
       </a>
       takeover in 1420.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Boj_s_Turki-Valvasor.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="974" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Boj_s_Turki-Valvasor.jpg/220px-Boj_s_Turki-Valvasor.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Boj_s_Turki-Valvasor.jpg/330px-Boj_s_Turki-Valvasor.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Boj_s_Turki-Valvasor.jpg/440px-Boj_s_Turki-Valvasor.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Boj_s_Turki-Valvasor.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Ottoman army battling the
         <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Habsburg_wars" title="Ottoman–Habsburg wars">
          Habsburgs
         </a>
         in present-day Slovenia during the
         <a href="/wiki/Great_Turkish_War" title="Great Turkish War">
          Great Turkish War
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       At the end of the Middle Ages, the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Lands" title="Slovene Lands">
        Slovene Lands
       </a>
       suffered a serious economic and demographic setback because of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Habsburg_wars" title="Ottoman–Habsburg wars">
        Turkish raids
       </a>
       . In 1515, a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenian_peasant_revolt_of_1515" title="Slovenian peasant revolt of 1515">
        peasant revolt
       </a>
       spread across nearly the whole Slovene territory. In 1572 and 1573 the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatian-Slovenian_peasant_revolt" title="Croatian-Slovenian peasant revolt">
        Croatian-Slovenian peasant revolt
       </a>
       wrought havoc throughout the wider region. Such uprisings, which often met with bloody defeats, continued throughout the 17th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture.si_66-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-culture.si-66">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_modern_period">
        Early modern period
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Early modern period">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The Republic of Venice was dissolved by France and Venetian Slovenia was passed to the Austrian Empire in 1797. The
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Lands" title="Slovene Lands">
        Slovene Lands
       </a>
       were part of the French-administered
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illyrian_provinces" title="Illyrian provinces">
        Illyrian provinces
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Empire" title="Austrian Empire">
        Austrian Empire
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
        Austria-Hungary
       </a>
       . Slovenes inhabited most of
       <a href="/wiki/Carniola" title="Carniola">
        Carniola
       </a>
       , the southern part of the duchies of
       <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Carinthia" title="Duchy of Carinthia">
        Carinthia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Styria" title="Duchy of Styria">
        Styria
       </a>
       , the northern and eastern areas of the
       <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Littoral" title="Austrian Littoral">
        Austrian Littoral
       </a>
       , as well as
       <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
        Prekmurje
       </a>
       in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary_(Austria-Hungary)" title="Kingdom of Hungary (Austria-Hungary)">
        Kingdom of Hungary
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Industrialization was accompanied by construction of railroads to link cities and markets, but the urbanization was limited.
      </p>
      <p>
       Due to limited opportunities, between 1880 and 1910 there was extensive emigration, and around 300,000 Slovenes (i.e. 1 in 6) emigrated to other countries,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Benderly9_68-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Benderly9-68">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       mostly to the US, but also to
       <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">
        South America
       </a>
       (the main part to Argentina), Germany,
       <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">
        Egypt
       </a>
       , and to larger cities in Austria-Hungary, especially
       <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">
        Vienna
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Graz" title="Graz">
        Graz
       </a>
       . The area of the United States with the highest concentration of Slovenian immigrants is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cleveland,_Ohio" title="Cleveland, Ohio">
        Cleveland, Ohio
       </a>
       . The other locations in the United States where many Slovenians settled were areas with substantial industrial and mining activities: Pittsburgh, Chicago, Pueblo, Butte, and the Salt Lake Valley. The men were important as workers in the mining industry, because of some of the skills they brought from Slovenia. Despite this, the Slovene population increased significantly.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Benderly9_68-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Benderly9-68">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Literacy was exceptionally high, at 80–90%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Benderly9_68-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Benderly9-68">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The 19th century also saw a revival of culture in the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">
        Slovene language
       </a>
       , accompanied by a
       <a href="/wiki/Romantic_nationalism" title="Romantic nationalism">
        Romantic nationalist
       </a>
       quest for cultural and political autonomy. The idea of a
       <a href="/wiki/United_Slovenia" title="United Slovenia">
        United Slovenia
       </a>
       , first advanced during the
       <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1848" title="Revolutions of 1848">
        revolutions of 1848
       </a>
       , became the common platform of most Slovenian parties and political movements in Austria-Hungary. During the same period,
       <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavism" title="Yugoslavism">
        Yugoslavism
       </a>
       , an ideology stressing the unity of all
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Slavic_peoples" title="South Slavic peoples">
        South Slavic peoples
       </a>
       , spread as a reaction to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pan-German_nationalism" title="Pan-German nationalism">
        Pan-German nationalism
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_irredentism" title="Italian irredentism">
        Italian irredentism
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_I">
        World War I
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: World War I">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_Campaign_(World_War_I)" title="Italian Campaign (World War I)">
        Italian Campaign (World War I)
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_the_Isonzo" title="Battles of the Isonzo">
        Battles of the Isonzo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1915)" title="Treaty of London (1915)">
        Treaty of London (1915)
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Corfu_Declaration" title="Corfu Declaration">
        Corfu Declaration
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eingebaute_Mannschaftsunterst%C3%A4nde_am_Monte_Sabotino.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1198" data-file-width="1680" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Eingebaute_Mannschaftsunterst%C3%A4nde_am_Monte_Sabotino.jpg/200px-Eingebaute_Mannschaftsunterst%C3%A4nde_am_Monte_Sabotino.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Eingebaute_Mannschaftsunterst%C3%A4nde_am_Monte_Sabotino.jpg/300px-Eingebaute_Mannschaftsunterst%C3%A4nde_am_Monte_Sabotino.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Eingebaute_Mannschaftsunterst%C3%A4nde_am_Monte_Sabotino.jpg/400px-Eingebaute_Mannschaftsunterst%C3%A4nde_am_Monte_Sabotino.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eingebaute_Mannschaftsunterst%C3%A4nde_am_Monte_Sabotino.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_the_Isonzo" title="Battles of the Isonzo">
          Battles of the Isonzo
         </a>
         took place mostly in rugged mountainous areas above the Soča River.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        World War I
       </a>
       brought heavy casualties to Slovenes, particularly the twelve
       <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_the_Isonzo" title="Battles of the Isonzo">
        Battles of the Isonzo
       </a>
       , which took place in present-day Slovenia's western border area. Hundreds of thousands of Slovene conscripts were drafted into the
       <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Army" title="Austro-Hungarian Army">
        Austro-Hungarian Army
       </a>
       , and over 30,000 of them died. Hundreds of thousands of Slovenes from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gorizia_and_Gradisca" title="Gorizia and Gradisca">
        Gorizia and Gradisca
       </a>
       were resettled in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Refugee_camps" title="Refugee camps">
        refugee camps
       </a>
       in Italy and Austria. While the refugees in Austria received decent treatment, the Slovene refugees in Italian camps were treated as state enemies, and several thousand died of malnutrition and diseases between 1915 and 1918.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Entire areas of the Slovene Littoral were destroyed.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rapallo,_1920" title="Treaty of Rapallo, 1920">
        Treaty of Rapallo
       </a>
       of 1920 left approximately 327,000 out of the total population of 1.3 million Slovenes in Italy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SacroEgoismo2012_70-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SacroEgoismo2012-70">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cresciani_ClashOfCivilisations_71-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Cresciani_ClashOfCivilisations-71">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After the
       <a href="/wiki/March_on_Rome" title="March on Rome">
        fascists took power
       </a>
       in Italy, they were subjected to a policy of violent
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fascist_Italianization" title="Fascist Italianization">
        Fascist Italianization
       </a>
       . This caused the mass emigration of Slovenes, especially the middle class, from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenian_Littoral" title="Slovenian Littoral">
        Slovenian Littoral
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">
        Trieste
       </a>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia" title="Yugoslavia">
        Yugoslavia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">
        South America
       </a>
       . Those who remained organized several connected networks of both passive and armed resistance. The best known was the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Militant_anti-fascist" title="Militant anti-fascist">
        militant anti-fascist
       </a>
       organization
       <a href="/wiki/TIGR" title="TIGR">
        TIGR
       </a>
       , formed in 1927 in order to fight Fascist oppression of the Slovene and Croat populations in the
       <a href="/wiki/Julian_March" title="Julian March">
        Julian March
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mira_Cencič_1997_72-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Mira_Cencič_1997-72">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tatjana_Rejec_1995_73-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tatjana_Rejec_1995-73">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Kingdom_of_Serbs.2C_Croats.2C_and_Slovenes_.28later_the_Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Kingdom_of_Serbs,_Croats,_and_Slovenes_(later_the_Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia)">
        Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes (later the Kingdom of Yugoslavia)
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes (later the Kingdom of Yugoslavia)">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Creation_of_Yugoslavia" title="Creation of Yugoslavia">
        Creation of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carinthian_Plebiscite" title="Carinthian Plebiscite">
        Carinthian Plebiscite
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Rudolf_Maister" title="Rudolf Maister">
        Rudolf Maister
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KongressfallofAH.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2067" data-file-width="3140" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/KongressfallofAH.jpg/220px-KongressfallofAH.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/KongressfallofAH.jpg/330px-KongressfallofAH.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/KongressfallofAH.jpg/440px-KongressfallofAH.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KongressfallofAH.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The proclamation of the State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs at
         <a href="/wiki/Congress_Square" title="Congress Square">
          Congress Square
         </a>
         in Ljubljana on 20 October 1918
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_People%27s_Party_(historical)" title="Slovene People's Party (historical)">
        Slovene People's Party
       </a>
       launched a movement for self-determination, demanding the creation of a semi-independent
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Slavic_peoples" title="South Slavic peoples">
        South Slavic
       </a>
       state under
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habsburg_dynasty" title="Habsburg dynasty">
        Habsburg
       </a>
       rule. The proposal was picked up by most Slovene parties, and a mass mobilization of Slovene civil society, known as the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=May_Declaration_(1917)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="May Declaration (1917) (page does not exist)">
        Declaration Movement
       </a>
       , followed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This demand was rejected by the Austrian political elites; but following the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire in the aftermath of the
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        First World War
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Council_of_Slovenes,_Croats_and_Serbs" title="National Council of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs">
        National Council of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs
       </a>
       took power in
       <a href="/wiki/Zagreb" title="Zagreb">
        Zagreb
       </a>
       on 6 October 1918. On 29 October, independence was declared by a national gathering in Ljubljana, and by the Croatian parliament, declaring the establishment of the new
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_of_Slovenes,_Croats,_and_Serbs" title="State of Slovenes, Croats, and Serbs">
        State of Slovenes, Croats, and Serbs
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Rapallo.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="964" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Treaty_of_Rapallo.png/220px-Treaty_of_Rapallo.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Treaty_of_Rapallo.png/330px-Treaty_of_Rapallo.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Treaty_of_Rapallo.png/440px-Treaty_of_Rapallo.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Rapallo.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The map showing the present territory of Slovenia, with traditional regional boundaries; the Slovene-speaking areas annexed by Italy after WWI are shown in stripes
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       On 1 December 1918 the State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs merged with
       <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">
        Serbia
       </a>
       , becoming part of the new
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbs,_Croats,_and_Slovenes" title="Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes">
        Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes
       </a>
       ; in 1929 it was renamed the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Kingdom of Yugoslavia">
        Kingdom of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       . The main territory of Slovenia, being the most industrialized and westernized compared to other less developed parts of Yugoslavia, became the main center of industrial production: Compared to Serbia, for example, Slovenian industrial production was four times greater; and it was 22 times greater than in
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Macedonia" title="Republic of Macedonia">
        Macedonia
       </a>
       . The interwar period brought further industrialization in Slovenia, with rapid economic growth in the 1920s, followed by a relatively successful economic adjustment to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1929_economic_crisis" title="1929 economic crisis">
        1929 economic crisis
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">
        Great Depression
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Following a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carinthian_Plebiscite" title="Carinthian Plebiscite">
        plebiscite
       </a>
       in October 1920, the Slovene-speaking southern
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carinthia_(state)" title="Carinthia (state)">
        Carinthia
       </a>
       was ceded to
       <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">
        Austria
       </a>
       . With the
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Trianon" title="Treaty of Trianon">
        Treaty of Trianon
       </a>
       , on the other hand, the Kingdom of Yugoslavia was awarded the Slovene-inhabited
       <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
        Prekmurje
       </a>
       region, formerly part of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austro-Hungary" title="Austro-Hungary">
        Austro-Hungary
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Slovenes living in territories that fell under the rule of the neighboring states—Italy, Austria, and Hungary—were subjected to
       <a href="/wiki/Cultural_assimilation" title="Cultural assimilation">
        assimilation
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">
        World War II
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: World War II">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_War_II_in_the_Slovene_Lands" title="World War II in the Slovene Lands">
        World War II in the Slovene Lands
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenia was the only present-day European nation that was trisected and completely annexed into both
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nazi" title="Nazi">
        Nazi
       </a>
       Germany and Fascist
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       during World War II.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GJK_2013_75-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GJK_2013-75">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition, the
       <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
        Prekmurje
       </a>
       region in the east was annexed to Hungary, and some villages in the
       <a href="/wiki/Lower_Sava_Valley" title="Lower Sava Valley">
        Lower Sava Valley
       </a>
       were incorporated in the newly created Nazi puppet
       <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">
        Independent State of Croatia
       </a>
       (NDH).
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_121-0721,_Marburg-Drau,_Adolf_Hitler.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="544" data-file-width="800" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Bundesarchiv_Bild_121-0721%2C_Marburg-Drau%2C_Adolf_Hitler.jpg/220px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_121-0721%2C_Marburg-Drau%2C_Adolf_Hitler.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Bundesarchiv_Bild_121-0721%2C_Marburg-Drau%2C_Adolf_Hitler.jpg/330px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_121-0721%2C_Marburg-Drau%2C_Adolf_Hitler.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Bundesarchiv_Bild_121-0721%2C_Marburg-Drau%2C_Adolf_Hitler.jpg/440px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_121-0721%2C_Marburg-Drau%2C_Adolf_Hitler.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_121-0721,_Marburg-Drau,_Adolf_Hitler.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">
          Adolf Hitler
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Martin_Bormann" title="Martin Bormann">
          Martin Bormann
         </a>
         visiting
         <a href="/wiki/Maribor" title="Maribor">
          Maribor
         </a>
         in April 1941.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Axis forces
       <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Yugoslavia" title="Invasion of Yugoslavia">
        invaded Yugoslavia
       </a>
       in April 1941 and defeated the country in a few weeks. The southern part, including Ljubljana, was annexed to Italy, while the Nazis took over the northern and eastern parts of the country. The Nazis had a plan of
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">
        ethnic cleansing
       </a>
       of these areas,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HF2006_BerghahnBooks_76-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HF2006_BerghahnBooks-76">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and they resettled or expelled the local Slovene civilian population to the puppet states of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nedi%C4%87%27s_Serbia" title="Nedić's Serbia">
        Nedić's Serbia
       </a>
       (7,500) and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NDH" title="NDH">
        NDH
       </a>
       (10,000). In addition, some 46,000 Slovenes were expelled to Germany, including children who were separated from their parents and allocated to German families.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LM2009_UNC_77-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LM2009_UNC-77">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At the same time, the ethnic Germans in the
       <a href="/wiki/Gottschee" title="Gottschee">
        Gottschee
       </a>
       enclave in the Italian annexation zone were resettled to the Nazi-controlled areas cleansed of their Slovene population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-L1993_UNC_79-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-L1993_UNC-79">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Around 30,000 to 40,000 Slovene men were drafted to the
       <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">
        German Army
       </a>
       and sent to the Eastern front. The Slovene language was banned from education, and its use in the public life was limited to the absolute minimum.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GJK_2013_75-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-GJK_2013-75">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In south-central Slovenia, annexed by Fascist Italy and renamed to
       <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Ljubljana" title="Province of Ljubljana">
        Province of Ljubljana
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Liberation_Front_of_the_Slovene_Nation" title="Liberation Front of the Slovene Nation">
        Slovenian National Liberation Front
       </a>
       was organized in April 1941. Led by the Communist Party, it formed the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Partisans" title="Slovene Partisans">
        Slovene Partisan
       </a>
       units as part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisans" title="Yugoslav Partisans">
        Yugoslav Partisans
       </a>
       led by the Communist leader
       <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">
        Josip Broz Tito
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JJR2013_OxfordPress_80-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-JJR2013_OxfordPress-80">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AS_2005_81-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AS_2005-81">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Boji_za_Trst_in_Slovensko_primorje.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1404" data-file-width="1971" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Boji_za_Trst_in_Slovensko_primorje.jpg/220px-Boji_za_Trst_in_Slovensko_primorje.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Boji_za_Trst_in_Slovensko_primorje.jpg/330px-Boji_za_Trst_in_Slovensko_primorje.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Boji_za_Trst_in_Slovensko_primorje.jpg/440px-Boji_za_Trst_in_Slovensko_primorje.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Boji_za_Trst_in_Slovensko_primorje.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Partisans fighting for Trieste and Primorje region, 1945
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After the resistance started in summer 1941, Italian violence against the Slovene civilian population escalated, as well. The Italian authorities deported some 25,000 people to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_concentration_camps" title="Italian concentration camps">
        concentration camps
       </a>
       , which equaled 7.5% of the population of their occupation zone. The most infamous ones were
       <a href="/wiki/Rab_concentration_camp" title="Rab concentration camp">
        Rab
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Gonars_concentration_camp" title="Gonars concentration camp">
        Gonars
       </a>
       . To counter the Communist-led insurgence, the Italians sponsored local anti-guerrilla units, formed mostly by the local conservative Catholic Slovene population that resented the revolutionary violence of the partisans. After the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_armistice" title="Italian armistice">
        Italian armistice
       </a>
       of September 1943, the Germans took over both the Province of Ljubljana and the Slovenian Littoral, incorporating them into what was known as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Operation_Zone_of_Adriatic_Coastal_Region" title="Operation Zone of Adriatic Coastal Region">
        Operation Zone of Adriatic Coastal Region
       </a>
       . They united the Slovene anti-Communist counter-insurgence into the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Home_Guard" title="Slovene Home Guard">
        Slovene Home Guard
       </a>
       and appointed a puppet regime in the Province of Ljubljana. The anti-Nazi resistance however expanded, creating its own administrative structures as the basis for Slovene statehood within a new, federal and socialist Yugoslavia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tomasevich_2001_82-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tomasevich_2001-82">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dennison_I._Rusinow_1978,_p._2_83-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Dennison_I._Rusinow_1978,_p._2-83">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1945, Yugoslavia was liberated by the partisan resistance and soon became a socialist federation known as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="People's Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">
        People's Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       . Slovenia joined the federation as a constituent republic, led by its own pro-Communist leadership.
      </p>
      <p>
       Approximately 8% of the entire Slovene population died during World War II. The small Jewish community, mostly settled in the
       <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
        Prekmurje
       </a>
