       region, perished in 1944 in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust_in_Hungary" title="Holocaust in Hungary">
        holocaust of Hungarian Jews
       </a>
       . The German speaking minority, amounting to 2.5% of the Slovenian population prior to WWII, was either expelled or killed in the aftermath of the war. Hundreds of
       <a href="/wiki/Istrian_Italians" title="Istrian Italians">
        Istrian Italians
       </a>
       and Slovenes that opposed communism were killed in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foibe_killings" title="Foibe killings">
        foibe massacres
       </a>
       , and more than 25,000 fled or were expelled from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenian_Istria" title="Slovenian Istria">
        Slovenian Istria
       </a>
       in the aftermath of the war.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Socialist_Period">
        Socialist Period
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Socialist Period">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Locator_map_Slovenia_in_Yugoslavia.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1057" data-file-width="1220" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Locator_map_Slovenia_in_Yugoslavia.svg/200px-Locator_map_Slovenia_in_Yugoslavia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Locator_map_Slovenia_in_Yugoslavia.svg/300px-Locator_map_Slovenia_in_Yugoslavia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Locator_map_Slovenia_in_Yugoslavia.svg/400px-Locator_map_Slovenia_in_Yugoslavia.svg.png 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Locator_map_Slovenia_in_Yugoslavia.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Location of Slovenia within Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Following the re-establishment of Yugoslavia during World War II, Slovenia became part of
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">
        Federal Yugoslavia
       </a>
       . A
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">
        socialist state
       </a>
       was established, but because of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tito%E2%80%93Stalin_split" title="Tito–Stalin split">
        Tito–Stalin split
       </a>
       in 1948, economic and personal freedoms were broader than in the rest of the
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">
        Eastern Bloc
       </a>
       . In 1947, the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
        Slovene Littoral
       </a>
       and the western half of
       <a href="/wiki/Inner_Carniola" title="Inner Carniola">
        Inner Carniola
       </a>
       , which had been annexed by
       <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       after World War One, were annexed to Slovenia.
      </p>
      <p>
       After the failure of
       <a href="/wiki/Collective_farming" title="Collective farming">
        forced collectivisation
       </a>
       that was attempted from 1949–53, a policy of gradual economic liberalisation, known as
       <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_self-management" title="Workers' self-management">
        workers self-management
       </a>
       , was introduced under the advice and supervision of the Slovene Marxist theoretician and Communist leader
       <a href="/wiki/Edvard_Kardelj" title="Edvard Kardelj">
        Edvard Kardelj
       </a>
       , the main ideologue of the
       <a href="/wiki/Titoism" title="Titoism">
        Titoist
       </a>
       path to socialism. Suspected opponents of this policy both from within and outside the Communist party were persecuted and thousands were sent to the
       <a href="/wiki/Goli_otok" title="Goli otok">
        Goli otok
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nixontito19712.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1981" data-file-width="2934" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Nixontito19712.jpg/220px-Nixontito19712.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Nixontito19712.jpg/330px-Nixontito19712.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Nixontito19712.jpg/440px-Nixontito19712.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nixontito19712.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">
          Josip Broz Tito
         </a>
         led
         <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">
          SFR Yugoslavia
         </a>
         from 1944 to 1980; Pictured: Tito with the US president
         <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">
          Richard Nixon
         </a>
         in the
         <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">
          White House
         </a>
         , 1971
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The late 1950s saw a policy of liberalisation in the cultural sphere, as well, and limited border crossing into neighboring Italy and Austria was allowed again. Until the 1980s,
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Slovenia" title="Socialist Republic of Slovenia">
        Slovenia
       </a>
       enjoyed relatively broad autonomy within the federation. In 1956,
       <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">
        Josip Broz Tito
       </a>
       , together with other leaders, founded the
       <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">
        Non-Aligned Movement
       </a>
       . Particularly in the 1950s, Slovenia's economy developed rapidly and was strongly industrialised. With further economic decentralisation of Yugoslavia in 1965–66, Slovenia's domestic product was 2.5 times the average of Yugoslav republics.
      </p>
      <p>
       Opposition to the regime was mostly limited to intellectual and literary circles, and became especially vocal after Tito's death in 1980, when the economic and political situation in Yugoslavia became very strained.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture.si_66-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-culture.si-66">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Political disputes around economic measures were echoed in the public sentiment, as many Slovenians felt they were being economically exploited, having to sustain an expensive and inefficient federal administration.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Slovenian_Spring.2C_democracy_and_independence">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Slovenian_Spring,_democracy_and_independence">
        Slovenian Spring, democracy and independence
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Slovenian Spring, democracy and independence">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       In 1987 a group of intellectuals demanded Slovene independence in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Contributions_for_the_Slovenian_National_Program" title="Contributions for the Slovenian National Program">
        57th edition
       </a>
       of the magazine
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Nova_revija_(magazine)" title="Nova revija (magazine)">
         Nova revija
        </a>
       </i>
       . Demands for democratisation and more Slovenian independence were sparked off. A mass democratic movement, coordinated by the
       <a href="/wiki/Committee_for_the_Defence_of_Human_Rights" title="Committee for the Defence of Human Rights">
        Committee for the Defence of Human Rights
       </a>
       , pushed the Communists in the direction of democratic reforms.
      </p>
      <p>
       In September 1989, numerous
       <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_amendment" title="Constitutional amendment">
        constitutional amendments
       </a>
       were passed to introduce
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" title="Parliamentary democracy">
        parliamentary democracy
       </a>
       to Slovenia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The same year
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rally_of_Truth" title="Rally of Truth">
        Action North
       </a>
       united both the opposition and democratized communist establishment in Slovenia as the first defense action against attacks by
       <a href="/wiki/Slobodan_Milo%C5%A1evi%C4%87" title="Slobodan Milošević">
        Slobodan Milošević
       </a>
       's supporters, leading to Slovenian independence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
        <a href="#cite_note-87">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
        <a href="#cite_note-88">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">
          <span title="Quotation needed from source to verify. (July 2012)">
           need quotation to verify
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       On 7 March 1990, the Slovenian Assembly changed the official name of the state to the "Republic of Slovenia".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-twenty.si_89-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-twenty.si-89">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In April 1990, the first democratic election in Slovenia took place, and the united opposition movement
       <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Opposition_of_Slovenia" title="Democratic Opposition of Slovenia">
        DEMOS
       </a>
       led by
       <a href="/wiki/Jo%C5%BEe_Pu%C4%8Dnik" title="Jože Pučnik">
        Jože Pučnik
       </a>
       emerged victorious.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Teritorialci_so_z_armbrustom_zadeli_tank_v_kri%C5%BEi%C5%A1%C4%8Du_pred_MMP_Ro%C5%BEna_Dolina..jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="636" data-file-width="1158" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Teritorialci_so_z_armbrustom_zadeli_tank_v_kri%C5%BEi%C5%A1%C4%8Du_pred_MMP_Ro%C5%BEna_Dolina..jpg/220px-Teritorialci_so_z_armbrustom_zadeli_tank_v_kri%C5%BEi%C5%A1%C4%8Du_pred_MMP_Ro%C5%BEna_Dolina..jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Teritorialci_so_z_armbrustom_zadeli_tank_v_kri%C5%BEi%C5%A1%C4%8Du_pred_MMP_Ro%C5%BEna_Dolina..jpg/330px-Teritorialci_so_z_armbrustom_zadeli_tank_v_kri%C5%BEi%C5%A1%C4%8Du_pred_MMP_Ro%C5%BEna_Dolina..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Teritorialci_so_z_armbrustom_zadeli_tank_v_kri%C5%BEi%C5%A1%C4%8Du_pred_MMP_Ro%C5%BEna_Dolina..jpg/440px-Teritorialci_so_z_armbrustom_zadeli_tank_v_kri%C5%BEi%C5%A1%C4%8Du_pred_MMP_Ro%C5%BEna_Dolina..jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Teritorialci_so_z_armbrustom_zadeli_tank_v_kri%C5%BEi%C5%A1%C4%8Du_pred_MMP_Ro%C5%BEna_Dolina..jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Slovenian forces attacking a Yugoslav army tank during the
         <a href="/wiki/Ten-Day_War" title="Ten-Day War">
          Ten-Day War
         </a>
         , 1991
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The initial revolutionary events in Slovenia pre-dated the
       <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">
        Revolutions of 1989
       </a>
       in Eastern Europe by almost a year, but went largely unnoticed by international observers. On 23 December 1990, more than 88% of the electorate voted for a sovereign and independent Slovenia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Felicijan_91-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Felicijan-91">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-STAT11_92-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-STAT11-92">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 25 June 1991, Slovenia became independent
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Škrk1999_9-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Škrk1999-9">
         [6]
        </a>
       </sup>
       through the passage of appropriate legal documents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jonsson_93-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Jonsson-93">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 27 June in the early morning, the
       <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_People%27s_Army" title="Yugoslav People's Army">
        Yugoslav People's Army
       </a>
       dispatched its forces to prevent further measures for the establishment of a new country, which led to the
       <a href="/wiki/Ten-Day_War" title="Ten-Day War">
        Ten-Day War
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Race_94-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Race-94">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SAF_History_95-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SAF_History-95">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 7 July, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brijuni_Agreement" title="Brijuni Agreement">
        Brijuni Agreement
       </a>
       was signed, implementing a truce and a three-month halt of the enforcement of Slovenia's independence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
        <a href="#cite_note-96">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the end of the month, the last soldiers of the Yugoslav Army left Slovenia.
      </p>
      <p>
       In December 1991, a new
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Slovenia" title="Constitution of Slovenia">
        constitution
       </a>
       was adopted,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jonsson_93-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Jonsson-93">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       followed in 1992 by the laws on
       <a href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">
        denationalisation and privatization
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Klemenčič2004_97-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Klemenčič2004-97">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The members of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       recognised Slovenia as an independent state on 15 January 1992, and the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       accepted it as a member on 22 May 1992.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Borak2004_98-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Borak2004-98">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Slovenia joined the European Union on 1 May 2004. Slovenia has one Commissioner in the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">
        European Commission
       </a>
       , and seven Slovene parliamentarians were elected to the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">
        European Parliament
       </a>
       at elections on 13 June 2004. In 2004 Slovenia also joined
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       . Slovenia subsequently succeeded in meeting the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maastricht_criteria" title="Maastricht criteria">
        Maastricht criteria
       </a>
       and joined the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
        Eurozone
       </a>
       (the first transition country to do so) on 1 January 2007. It was the first post-Communist country to hold the
       <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_the_Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Presidency of the Council of the European Union">
        Presidency of the Council of the European Union
       </a>
       , for the first six months of 2008. On 21 July 2010, it became a member of the OECD.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The disillusionment with domestic socio-economic elites at municipal and national levels was expressed at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%932013_Slovenian_protests" title="2012–2013 Slovenian protests">
        2012–2013 Slovenian protests
       </a>
       on a wider scale than in the smaller
       <a href="/wiki/15_October_2011_global_protests#Slovenia" title="15 October 2011 global protests">
        15 October 2011 protests
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In relation to the leading politicians' response to allegations made by the official
       <a href="/wiki/Commission_for_the_Prevention_of_Corruption_of_the_Republic_of_Slovenia" title="Commission for the Prevention of Corruption of the Republic of Slovenia">
        Commission for the Prevention of Corruption of the Republic of Slovenia
       </a>
       , legal experts expressed the need for changes in the system that would limit political
       <a href="/wiki/Arbitrariness" title="Arbitrariness">
        arbitrariness
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style">
          <span title="You can help -- (January 2017)">
           context needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
        Geography
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Geography">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Slovenia" title="Geography of Slovenia">
        Geography of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Slovenia" title="Protected areas of Slovenia">
        Protected areas of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:General_map_of_slovenia.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1372" data-file-width="1952" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/General_map_of_slovenia.svg/250px-General_map_of_slovenia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/General_map_of_slovenia.svg/375px-General_map_of_slovenia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/General_map_of_slovenia.svg/500px-General_map_of_slovenia.svg.png 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:General_map_of_slovenia.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A topographic map of Slovenia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Triglav.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Triglav.jpg/200px-Triglav.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Triglav.jpg/300px-Triglav.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Triglav.jpg/400px-Triglav.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Triglav.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Mount
         <a href="/wiki/Triglav" title="Triglav">
          Triglav
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenia is situated in Central and Southeastern Europe touching the Alps and bordering the Mediterranean. It lies between latitudes
       <a href="/wiki/45th_parallel_north" title="45th parallel north">
        45°
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/47th_parallel_north" title="47th parallel north">
        47° N
       </a>
       , and longitudes
       <a href="/wiki/13th_meridian_east" title="13th meridian east">
        13°
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/17th_meridian_east" title="17th meridian east">
        17° E
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/15th_meridian_east" title="15th meridian east">
        15th meridian east
       </a>
       almost corresponds to the middle line of the country in the direction west-east.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
        <a href="#cite_note-102">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geometric_Centre_of_the_Republic_of_Slovenia" title="Geometric Centre of the Republic of Slovenia">
        Geometrical Center of the Republic of Slovenia
       </a>
       is located at
       <a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">
        coordinates
       </a>
       46°07'11.8" N and 14°48'55.2" E.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It lies in
       <a href="/wiki/Slivna" title="Slivna">
        Slivna
       </a>
       in the Municipality of
       <a href="/wiki/Litija" title="Litija">
        Litija
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Slovenia's highest peak is
       <a href="/wiki/Triglav" title="Triglav">
        Triglav
       </a>
       (2,864 m or 9,396 ft); the country's average height
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" title="Above mean sea level">
        above sea level
       </a>
       is 557 m (1,827 ft).
      </p>
      <p>
       Four major European geographic regions meet in Slovenia: the
       <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">
        Alps
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Alps" title="Dinaric Alps">
        Dinarides
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pannonian_Plain" title="Pannonian Plain">
        Pannonian Plain
       </a>
       , and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean" title="Mediterranean">
        Mediterranean
       </a>
       . Although on the shore of the
       <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">
        Adriatic Sea
       </a>
       near the
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
        Mediterranean Sea
       </a>
       , most of Slovenia is in the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
        Black Sea
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">
        drainage basin
       </a>
       . The Alps—including the Julian Alps, the Kamnik-Savinja Alps and the Karavanke chain, as well as the Pohorje massif—dominate Northern Slovenia along its long border with Austria. Slovenia's Adriatic coastline stretches approximately 47 kilometres (29 mi)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
        <a href="#cite_note-105">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       from Italy to Croatia.
      </p>
      <p>
       The term "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karst_topography" title="Karst topography">
        Karst topography
       </a>
       " refers to that of southwestern Slovenia's
       <a href="/wiki/Karst_Plateau" title="Karst Plateau">
        Karst Plateau
       </a>
       , a limestone region of underground rivers, gorges, and caves, between Ljubljana and the Mediterranean. On the Pannonian plain to the East and Northeast, toward the Croatian and Hungarian borders, the landscape is essentially flat. However, the majority of Slovenian terrain is hilly or mountainous, with around 90% of the surface 200 m (656 ft) or more
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" title="Above mean sea level">
        above sea level
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Over half of the country (11,823 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       or 4,565 sq mi) is covered by forests.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This makes Slovenia the third most forested country in Europe, after
       <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">
        Finland
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Sweden
       </a>
       . The areas are covered mostly by
       <a href="/wiki/Beech" title="Beech">
        beech
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fir" title="Fir">
        fir
       </a>
       -beech and beech-
       <a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak">
        oak
       </a>
       forests and have a relatively high production capacity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
        <a href="#cite_note-107">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Remnants of primeval forests are still to be found, the largest in the
       <a href="/wiki/Ko%C4%8Devje" title="Kočevje">
        Kočevje
       </a>
       area. Grassland covers 5,593 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (2,159 sq mi) and fields and gardens (954 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       or 368 sq mi). There are 363 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (140 sq mi) of orchards and 216 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (83 sq mi) of vineyards.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geology">
        Geology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Geology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C5%BDlebi%C4%8Di.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/%C5%BDlebi%C4%8Di.jpg/220px-%C5%BDlebi%C4%8Di.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/%C5%BDlebi%C4%8Di.jpg/330px-%C5%BDlebi%C4%8Di.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/%C5%BDlebi%C4%8Di.jpg/440px-%C5%BDlebi%C4%8Di.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C5%BDlebi%C4%8Di.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Solution runnels (also known as rillenkarren) are a
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karst_topography" title="Karst topography">
          karst
         </a>
         feature on the Karst Plateau, as in many other karst areas of the world.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenia is in a rather active seismic zone because of its position on the small
       <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Plate" title="Adriatic Plate">
        Adriatic Plate
       </a>
       , which is squeezed between the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Plate" title="Eurasian Plate">
        Eurasian Plate
       </a>
       to the north and the
       <a href="/wiki/African_Plate" title="African Plate">
        African Plate
       </a>
       to the south and rotates counter-clockwise.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seisme_108-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Seisme-108">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Thus the country is at the junction of three important geotectonic units: the Alps to the north, the Dinaric Alps to the south and the Pannonian Basin to the east.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seisme_108-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Seisme-108">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Scientists have been able to identify 60 destructive earthquakes in the past. Additionally, a network of seismic stations is active throughout the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seisme_108-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Seisme-108">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many parts of Slovenia have a carbonate ground, and an extensive subterranean system has developed.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Natural_regions">
        Natural regions
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Natural regions">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The first regionalisations of Slovenia were made by geographers
       <a href="/wiki/Anton_Melik" title="Anton Melik">
        Anton Melik
       </a>
       (1935–1936) and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Svetozar_Ile%C5%A1i%C4%8D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Svetozar Ilešič (page does not exist)">
        Svetozar Ilešič
       </a>
       (1968). The newer regionalisation by
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ivan_Gams&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Ivan Gams (page does not exist)">
        Ivan Gams
       </a>
       divided Slovenia in the following macroregions:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        the
        <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">
         Alps
        </a>
        (
        <i>
         Alpe
        </i>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        the
        <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Prealps" title="Slovene Prealps">
         subalpine landscapes
        </a>
        (
        <i>
         predalpski svet
        </i>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        the
        <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
         Slovene Littoral
        </a>
        or
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Submediterranean" title="Submediterranean">
         Submediterranean
        </a>
        Slovenia (
        <i>
         Primorje
        </i>
        or
        <i>
         submediteranska Slovenija
        </i>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        the
        <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Alps" title="Dinaric Alps">
         Dinaric
        </a>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plateaus" title="Plateaus">
         plateaus
        </a>
        of the continental Slovenia (
        <i>
         dinarske planote celinske Slovenije
        </i>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pannonian_Plain" title="Pannonian Plain">
         Subpannonian Slovenia
        </a>
        (
        <i>
         subpanonska Slovenija
        </i>
        )
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       According to a newer natural geographic regionalisation, the country consists of four
       <a href="/wiki/Macroregion" title="Macroregion">
        macroregions
       </a>
       . These are the Alpine, the Mediterranean, the Dinaric, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Pannonia" title="Pannonia">
        Pannonian
       </a>
       landscapes. Macroregions are defined according to major relief units (the Alps, the Pannonian plain, the Dinaric mountains) and climate types (submediterranean, temperate continental, mountain climate).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
        <a href="#cite_note-110">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These are often quite interwoven.
      </p>
      <p>
       Protected areas of Slovenia include national parks, regional parks, and nature parks, the largest of which is
       <a href="/wiki/Triglav_National_Park" title="Triglav National Park">
        Triglav National Park
       </a>
       . There are 286
       <a href="/wiki/Natura_2000" title="Natura 2000">
        Natura 2000
       </a>
       designated protected areas, which comprise 36% of the country's land area, the largest percentage among European Union states.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Additionally, according to
       <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">
        Yale University
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index" title="Environmental Performance Index">
        Environmental Performance Index
       </a>
       , Slovenia is considered a "strong performer" in environmental protection efforts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
        <a href="#cite_note-112">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 183.33333333333px">
        <div style="width: 183.33333333333px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 181.33333333333px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Strunjan_bay_(24209577441).jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4928" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Strunjan_bay_%2824209577441%29.jpg/272px-Strunjan_bay_%2824209577441%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Strunjan_bay_%2824209577441%29.jpg/408px-Strunjan_bay_%2824209577441%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Strunjan_bay_%2824209577441%29.jpg/544px-Strunjan_bay_%2824209577441%29.jpg 2x" width="182"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>

           <a href="/wiki/Cliff" title="Cliff">

           </a>
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">

            Gorizia Hills
           </a>
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 234.66666666667px">

           </a>
          </div>
         </div>

           </a>

            Lake Cerknica
           </a>
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>

           </a>
          </div>
         </div>

          </p>

       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182.66666666667px">

           </a>
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>

       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">

           </a>
          </div>

           Pannonian Slovenia: the town of
           <a href="/wiki/Lendava" title="Lendava">
            Lendava
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
            Prekmurje
           </a>
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
        Climate
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Climate">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:View_from_Mangart_MC.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2109" data-file-width="6042" height="105" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/View_from_Mangart_MC.jpg/300px-View_from_Mangart_MC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/View_from_Mangart_MC.jpg/450px-View_from_Mangart_MC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/View_from_Mangart_MC.jpg/600px-View_from_Mangart_MC.jpg 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:View_from_Mangart_MC.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Different types of clouds in the
         <a href="/wiki/Julian_Alps" title="Julian Alps">
          Julian Alps
         </a>
         (northwestern Slovenia), as seen from the top of
         <a href="/wiki/Mangart" title="Mangart">
          Mangart
         </a>
         in September 2007.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Climate_types_Slovenia_1970-2000.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1125" data-file-width="765" height="324" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Climate_types_Slovenia_1970-2000.JPG/220px-Climate_types_Slovenia_1970-2000.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Climate_types_Slovenia_1970-2000.JPG/330px-Climate_types_Slovenia_1970-2000.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Climate_types_Slovenia_1970-2000.JPG/440px-Climate_types_Slovenia_1970-2000.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Climate_types_Slovenia_1970-2000.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Climate types Slovenia 1970–2000 and climograms for selected settlements.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenia is located in temperate latitudes. The climate is also influenced by the variety of relief, and the influence of the
       <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">
        Alps
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">
        Adriatic Sea
       </a>
       . In the northeast, the
       <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">
        continental climate
       </a>
       type with greatest difference between winter and summer temperatures prevails. In the coastal region, there is sub-
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">
        Mediterranean climate
       </a>
       . The effect of the sea on the temperature rates is visible also up the
       <a href="/wiki/So%C4%8Da" title="Soča">
        Soča
       </a>
       valley, while a severe
       <a href="/wiki/Alpine_climate" title="Alpine climate">
        Alpine climate
       </a>
       is present in the high mountain regions. There is a strong interaction between these three climatic systems across most of the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arso.gov.si_113-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-arso.gov.si-113">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arso.gov.si_Meteo_Archive_114-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-arso.gov.si_Meteo_Archive-114">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">
        Precipitation
       </a>
       , often coming from
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Bay_of_Genoa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bay of Genoa (page does not exist)">
        Bay of Genoa
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       varies across the country as well, with over 3,500 mm (138 in) in some western regions and dropping down to 800 mm (31 in) in
       <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
        Prekmurje
       </a>
       . Snow is quite frequent in winter and the record snow cover in Ljubljana was recorded in 1952 at 146 cm (57 in).
      </p>
      <p>
       Compared to Western Europe, Slovenia is not very windy, because it lies in the slipstream of the Alps. The average wind speeds are lower than in the plains of the nearby countries. Due to the rugged terrain, local vertical winds with daily periods are present. Besides these, there are three winds of particular regional importance: the
       <a href="/wiki/Bora_(wind)" title="Bora (wind)">
        bora
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Sirocco" title="Sirocco">
        jugo
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Foehn_wind" title="Foehn wind">
        foehn
       </a>
       . The jugo and the bora are characteristic of the Littoral. Whereas the jugo is humid and warm, the bora is usually cold and gusty. The foehn is typical of the Alpine regions in the north of Slovenia. Generally present in Slovenia are the northeast wind, the southeast wind and the
       <a href="/wiki/North_wind" title="North wind">
        north wind
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Waters">
        Waters
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Waters">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Triglav_National_Park_(7892861178).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="2736" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Triglav_National_Park_%287892861178%29.jpg/180px-Triglav_National_Park_%287892861178%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Triglav_National_Park_%287892861178%29.jpg/270px-Triglav_National_Park_%287892861178%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Triglav_National_Park_%287892861178%29.jpg/360px-Triglav_National_Park_%287892861178%29.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Triglav_National_Park_(7892861178).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/So%C4%8Da" title="Soča">
          Soča
         </a>
         River flows through Triglav National Park
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lake_Bohinj_(9452094709).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="483" data-file-width="1024" height="104" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Lake_Bohinj_%289452094709%29.jpg/220px-Lake_Bohinj_%289452094709%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Lake_Bohinj_%289452094709%29.jpg/330px-Lake_Bohinj_%289452094709%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Lake_Bohinj_%289452094709%29.jpg/440px-Lake_Bohinj_%289452094709%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lake_Bohinj_(9452094709).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Lake_Bohinj" title="Lake Bohinj">
          Lake Bohinj
         </a>
         , largest Slovenian lake, one of the two springs of the
         <a href="/wiki/Sava" title="Sava">
          Sava
         </a>
         River
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The territory of Slovenia mainly (16,423 square kilometers or 6,341 square miles, i.e. 81%) belongs to the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
        Black Sea
       </a>
       basin, and a smaller part (3,850 square kilometers or 1,490 square miles, i.e. 19%) belongs to the
       <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">
        Adriatic Sea
       </a>
       basin. These two parts are divided into smaller units in regard to their central rivers, the
       <a href="/wiki/Mur_(river)" title="Mur (river)">
        Mura
       </a>
       River basin, the
       <a href="/wiki/Drava" title="Drava">
        Drava
       </a>
       River basin, the
       <a href="/wiki/Sava" title="Sava">
        Sava
       </a>
       River basin with
       <a href="/wiki/Kupa" title="Kupa">
        Kolpa
       </a>
       River basin, and the basin of the Adriatic rivers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In comparison with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developed_countries" title="Developed countries">
        developed countries
       </a>
       , water quality in Slovenia is considered to be among the highest in Europe. One of the reasons is undoubtedly that most of the rivers rise on the mountainous territory of Slovenia. But this does not mean that Slovenia has no problems with surface water and groundwater quality, especially in areas with
       <a href="/wiki/Intensive_farming" title="Intensive farming">
        intensive farming
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">
        Biodiversity
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Biodiversity">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P_anguinus2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="207" data-file-width="300" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/P_anguinus2.jpg/220px-P_anguinus2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f1/P_anguinus2.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:P_anguinus2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Olm" title="Olm">
          Olm
         </a>
         can be found in
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Postojna_cave" title="Postojna cave">
          Postojna cave
         </a>
         and other caves in the country.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenia signed the Rio
       <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">
        Convention on Biological Diversity
       </a>
       on 13 June 1992 and became a party to the convention on 9 July 1996.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It subsequently produced a
       <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_action_plan" title="Biodiversity action plan">
        National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan
       </a>
       , which was received by the convention on 30 May 2002.
      </p>
      <p>
       Slovenia is distinguished by an exceptionally wide variety of habitats,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       due to the contact of geological units and biogeographical regions, and due to human influences. Around 12.5% of the territory is protected with 35.5% in the
       <a href="/wiki/Natura_2000" title="Natura 2000">
        Natura 2000
       </a>
       ecological network.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Despite this, because of pollution and environmental degradation, diversity has been in decline.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Animals
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">
        biological diversity
       </a>
       of the country is high, with 1% of the world's organisms on 0.004% of the Earth's surface area.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are 75 mammal species, among them
       <a href="/wiki/Marmot" title="Marmot">
        marmots
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Alpine_ibex" title="Alpine ibex">
        Alpine ibex
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Chamois" title="Chamois">
        chamois
       </a>
       . There are numerous
       <a href="/wiki/Deer" title="Deer">
        deer
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Roe_deer" title="Roe deer">
        roe deer
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boar" title="Boar">
        boar
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Hare" title="Hare">
        hares
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NFPRes_123-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NFPRes-123">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Edible_dormouse" title="Edible dormouse">
        edible dormouse
       </a>
       is often found in the Slovenian beech forests. Trapping these animals is a long tradition and is a part of the Slovenian national identity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C4%8Cebela_na_cvetu_marelice.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1469" data-file-width="1600" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/%C4%8Cebela_na_cvetu_marelice.jpg/220px-%C4%8Cebela_na_cvetu_marelice.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/%C4%8Cebela_na_cvetu_marelice.jpg/330px-%C4%8Cebela_na_cvetu_marelice.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/%C4%8Cebela_na_cvetu_marelice.jpg/440px-%C4%8Cebela_na_cvetu_marelice.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C4%8Cebela_na_cvetu_marelice.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Carniolan_honey_bee" title="Carniolan honey bee">
          Carniolan honey bee
         </a>
         is native to Slovenia and is a subspecies of the western honey bee.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Some important carnivores include the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_lynx" title="Eurasian lynx">
        Eurasian lynx
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       European
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wild_cat" title="Wild cat">
        wild cats
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fox" title="Fox">
        foxes
       </a>
       (especially the
       <a href="/wiki/Red_fox" title="Red fox">
        red fox
       </a>
       ), and
       <a href="/wiki/European_jackal" title="European jackal">
        European jackal
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
        <a href="#cite_note-127">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are
       <a href="/wiki/Hedgehog" title="Hedgehog">
        hedgehogs
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Marten" title="Marten">
        martens
       </a>
       , and snakes such as
       <a href="/wiki/Viperinae" title="Viperinae">
        vipers
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Grass_snake" title="Grass snake">
        grass snakes
       </a>
       . According to recent estimates, Slovenia has c. 40–60
       <a href="/wiki/Gray_wolf" title="Gray wolf">
        wolves
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
        <a href="#cite_note-128">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and about 450
       <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">
        brown bears
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
        <a href="#cite_note-129">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
        <a href="#cite_note-130">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Slovenia is home to an exceptionally diverse number of cave species, with a few tens of
       <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">
        endemic species
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Among the cave vertebrates, the only known one is the
       <a href="/wiki/Olm" title="Olm">
        olm
       </a>
       , living in Karst, Lower Carniola, and White Carniola.
      </p>
      <p>
       The only regular species of
       <a href="/wiki/Cetacea" title="Cetacea">
        cetaceans
       </a>
       found in the northern Adriatic sea is the
       <a href="/wiki/Bottlenose_dolphin" title="Bottlenose dolphin">
        bottlenose dolphin
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Tursiops truncatus
       </i>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are a wide variety of birds, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Tawny_owl" title="Tawny owl">
        tawny owl
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Long-eared_owl" title="Long-eared owl">
        long-eared owl
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eagle_owl" title="Eagle owl">
        eagle owl
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hawk" title="Hawk">
        hawks
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Short-toed_eagle" title="Short-toed eagle">
        short-toed eagles
       </a>
       . Other birds of prey have been recorded, as well as a growing number of
       <a href="/wiki/Raven" title="Raven">
        ravens
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Crow" title="Crow">
        crows
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Magpie" title="Magpie">
        magpies
       </a>
       migrating into Ljubljana and Maribor where they thrive.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
        <a href="#cite_note-133">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other birds include
       <a href="/wiki/Black_woodpecker" title="Black woodpecker">
        black
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/European_green_woodpecker" title="European green woodpecker">
        green
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Woodpecker" title="Woodpecker">
        woodpeckers
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/White_stork" title="White stork">
        white stork
       </a>
       , which nests mainly in
       <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
        Prekmurje
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lipica_horses_(7198987762).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="787" data-file-width="1600" height="108" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Lipica_horses_%287198987762%29.jpg/220px-Lipica_horses_%287198987762%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Lipica_horses_%287198987762%29.jpg/330px-Lipica_horses_%287198987762%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Lipica_horses_%287198987762%29.jpg/440px-Lipica_horses_%287198987762%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lipica_horses_(7198987762).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Modern
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lipizzaner" title="Lipizzaner">
          Lipizzaner
         </a>
         grazing
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       There are 13 domestic animals native to Slovenia,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
        <a href="#cite_note-134">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       of eight species (hen, pig, dog, horse, sheep, goat, honey bee, and cattle).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meglič2003_135-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Meglič2003-135">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Among these are the
       <a href="/wiki/Karst_Shepherd" title="Karst Shepherd">
        Karst Shepherd
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FCI2009doc_136-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FCI2009doc-136">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carniolan_honeybee" title="Carniolan honeybee">
        Carniolan honeybee
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Lipizzan" title="Lipizzan">
        Lipizzan
       </a>
       horse.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meglič2003_135-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Meglič2003-135">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       They have been preserved
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ex_situ" title="Ex situ">
        ex situ
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/In_situ" title="In situ">
        in situ
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marble_trout" title="Marble trout">
        marble trout
       </a>
       or marmorata (
       <i>
        Salmo marmoratus
       </i>
       ) is an indigenous Slovenian fish.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Balkan_Trout_Restoration_Group_138-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Balkan_Trout_Restoration_Group-138">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Extensive breeding programmes have been introduced to repopulate the marble trout into lakes and streams invaded by non-indigenous species of
       <a href="/wiki/Trout" title="Trout">
        trout
       </a>
       . Slovenia is also home to the
       <a href="/wiki/Wels_catfish" title="Wels catfish">
        wels catfish
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Fungi
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       More than 2,400 fungal species have been recorded from Slovenia
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
        <a href="#cite_note-139">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and, since that figure does not include lichen-forming fungi, the total number of Slovenian fungi already known is undoubtedly much higher. Many more remain to be discovered.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Plants
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Slovenia is the third most-forested country in Europe,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
        <a href="#cite_note-140">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with 58.3% of the territory covered by forests.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
        <a href="#cite_note-141">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The forests are an important natural resource, and logging is kept to a minimum — Slovenians value their forests for the preservation of natural diversity, for enriching the soil and cleansing the water and air, for the social and economic benefits of recreation and tourism, and for the natural beauty they give the landscape.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       In the interior of the country are typical
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
        Central European
       </a>
       forests, predominantly
       <a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak">
        oak
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Beech" title="Beech">
        beech
       </a>
       . In the mountains,
       <a href="/wiki/Spruce" title="Spruce">
        spruce
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fir" title="Fir">
        fir
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine">
        pine
       </a>
       are more common. Pine trees grow on the
       <a href="/wiki/Karst_Plateau" title="Karst Plateau">
        Karst Plateau
       </a>
       , although only one-third of the region is covered by pine forest. The
       <a href="/wiki/Tilia" title="Tilia">
        lime/linden
       </a>
       tree, common in Slovenian forests, is a national symbol. The
       <a href="/wiki/Tree_line" title="Tree line">
        tree line
       </a>
       is at 1,700 to 1,800 metres (5,600 to 5,900 feet).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
        <a href="#cite_note-142">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the Alps, flowers such as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Daphne_blagayana" title="Daphne blagayana">
         Daphne blagayana
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gentian" title="Gentian">
        gentians
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Gentiana_clusii" title="Gentiana clusii">
         Gentiana clusii
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gentiana_froelichi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gentiana froelichi (page does not exist)">
         Gentiana froelichi
        </a>
       </i>
       ),
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Primula_auricula" title="Primula auricula">
         Primula auricula
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leontopodium_alpinum" title="Leontopodium alpinum">
        edelweiss
       </a>
       (the symbol of Slovene mountaineering),
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Cypripedium_calceolus" title="Cypripedium calceolus">
         Cypripedium calceolus
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Fritillaria_meleagris" title="Fritillaria meleagris">
         Fritillaria meleagris
        </a>
       </i>
       (snake's head fritillary), and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Pulsatilla_grandis" title="Pulsatilla grandis">
         Pulsatilla grandis
        </a>
       </i>
       are found.
      </p>
      <p>
       Slovenia harbors many plants of
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnobotany" title="Ethnobotany">
        ethnobotanically
       </a>
       useful groups. Of 59 known species of ethnobotanical importance, some species such as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Aconitum_napellus" title="Aconitum napellus">
         Aconitum napellus
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Cannabis_sativa" title="Cannabis sativa">
         Cannabis sativa
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Taxus_baccata" title="Taxus baccata">
         Taxus baccata
        </a>
       </i>
       are restricted for use as per the Official Gazette of the Republic of Slovenia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
        <a href="#cite_note-143">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">
        Politics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Politics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Slovenia" title="Politics of Slovenia">
        Politics of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Slovenia" title="Foreign relations of Slovenia">
        Foreign relations of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Presidential_Palace._Ljubljana.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="531" data-file-width="900" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Presidential_Palace._Ljubljana.jpg/220px-Presidential_Palace._Ljubljana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Presidential_Palace._Ljubljana.jpg/330px-Presidential_Palace._Ljubljana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Presidential_Palace._Ljubljana.jpg/440px-Presidential_Palace._Ljubljana.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Presidential_Palace._Ljubljana.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Government_Building_and_President%27s_Office" title="Government Building and President's Office">
          Government Building and President's Office
         </a>
         in Ljubljana
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:269px;max-width:269px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:131px;max-width:131px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Borut_Pahor_2010.jpg">
           <img alt="Borut Pahor" data-file-height="2156" data-file-width="1621" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Borut_Pahor_2010.jpg/129px-Borut_Pahor_2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Borut_Pahor_2010.jpg/194px-Borut_Pahor_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Borut_Pahor_2010.jpg/258px-Borut_Pahor_2010.jpg 2x" width="129"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          President
          <a href="/wiki/Borut_Pahor" title="Borut Pahor">
           Borut Pahor
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:134px;max-width:134px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Miro_Cerar_2014-07-13.jpg">
           <img alt="Miro Cerar" data-file-height="1050" data-file-width="810" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Miro_Cerar_2014-07-13.jpg/132px-Miro_Cerar_2014-07-13.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Miro_Cerar_2014-07-13.jpg/198px-Miro_Cerar_2014-07-13.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Miro_Cerar_2014-07-13.jpg/264px-Miro_Cerar_2014-07-13.jpg 2x" width="132"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Prime Minister
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miroslav_Cerar_Jr." title="Miroslav Cerar Jr.">
           Miro Cerar
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenia is a
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">
        parliamentary democracy
       </a>
       republic with a
       <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">
        multi-party system
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
        head of state
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Slovenia" title="President of Slovenia">
        president
       </a>
       , who is elected by popular vote and has an important integrative role.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Furtlehner_144-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Furtlehner-144">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He is elected for five years and at maximum for two consecutive terms. He has mainly a representative role and is the commander-in-chief of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Slovenia" title="Military of Slovenia">
        Slovenian military forces
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
        <a href="#cite_note-145">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">
        executive
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Administration_(business)" title="Administration (business)">
        administrative
       </a>
       authority in Slovenia is held by the
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Slovenia" title="Government of Slovenia">
        Government of Slovenia
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        <span lang="sl" title="Slovene language text">
         Vlada Republike Slovenije
        </span>
       </i>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Borak2004_98-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Borak2004-98">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       headed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Slovenia" title="Prime Minister of Slovenia">
        Prime Minister
       </a>
       and the council of
       <a href="/wiki/Minister_(government)" title="Minister (government)">
        ministers
       </a>
       or cabinet, who are elected by the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Slovenia)" title="National Assembly (Slovenia)">
        National Assembly
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        <span lang="sl" title="Slovene language text">
         Državni zbor Republike Slovenije
        </span>
       </i>
       ). The legislative authority is held by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bicameral" title="Bicameral">
        bicameral
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Slovenia" title="Parliament of Slovenia">
        Parliament of Slovenia
       </a>
       , characterised by an asymmetric duality.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
          <span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (April 2014)">
           clarification needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prunk2007_146-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Prunk2007-146">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The bulk of power is concentrated in the National Assembly, which consists of ninety members. Of those, 88 are elected by all the citizens in a system of
       <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">
        proportional representation
       </a>
       , whereas two are elected by the registered members of the
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenism" title="Indigenism">
        autochthonous
       </a>
       Hungarian and Italian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_Minorities" title="Ethnic Minorities">
        minorities
       </a>
       . Election takes place every four years. The
       <a href="/wiki/National_Council_(Slovenia)" title="National Council (Slovenia)">
        National Council
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        <span lang="sl" title="Slovene language text">
         Državni svet Republike Slovenije
        </span>
       </i>
       ), consisting of forty members, appointed to represent social, economic, professional and local interest groups, has a limited advisory and control power.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prunk2007_146-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Prunk2007-146">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The 1992–2004 period was marked by the rule of the
       <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Democracy_of_Slovenia" title="Liberal Democracy of Slovenia">
        Liberal Democracy of Slovenia
       </a>
       , which was responsible for gradual transition from the
       <a href="/wiki/Titoism" title="Titoism">
        Titoistic
       </a>
       economy to the capitalist market economy. It later attracted much criticism by neo-liberal economists, who demanded a less gradual approach. The party's president
       <a href="/wiki/Janez_Drnov%C5%A1ek" title="Janez Drnovšek">
        Janez Drnovšek
       </a>
       , who served as prime minister between 1992 and 2002, was one of the most influential Slovenian politicians of the 1990s,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
        <a href="#cite_note-147">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       alongside President
       <a href="/wiki/Milan_Ku%C4%8Dan" title="Milan Kučan">
        Milan Kučan
       </a>
       (who served between 1990 and 2002).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
        <a href="#cite_note-148">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The 2005–2008 period was characterized by over-enthusiasm after joining the EU. During the first term of
       <a href="/wiki/Janez_Jan%C5%A1a" title="Janez Janša">
        Janez Janša
       </a>
       's government, for the first time after independence, the Slovenian banks saw their
       <a href="/wiki/Loan-deposit_ratio" title="Loan-deposit ratio">
        loan-deposit ratios
       </a>
       veering out of control. There was over-borrowing from foreign banks and then over-crediting of customers, including local tycoons.
      </p>
      <p>
       After the onset of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932010" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2010">
        financial crisis of 2007–2010
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_sovereign-debt_crisis" title="European sovereign-debt crisis">
        European sovereign-debt crisis
       </a>
       , the left-wing coalition that replaced Janša's government in the 2008 elections, had to face the consequences of the 2005–2008 over-borrowing. Attempts to implement reforms that would help economic recovery were met by student protesters, led by a student who later became a member of
       <a href="/wiki/Janez_Jan%C5%A1a" title="Janez Janša">
        Janez Janša
       </a>
       's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenska_demokratska_stranka" title="Slovenska demokratska stranka">
        SDS
       </a>
       , and by the trade unions. The proposed reforms were postponed in a referendum. The left-wing government was ousted with a vote of no confidence. Janez Janša attributed the boom of spending and overborrowing to the period of left-wing government; he proposed harsh austerity reforms which he had previously helped postpone. Generally, some economists estimate that left and right parties attributed to over-loaning and managers' takeovers; reason behind was that each block tried to establish economic elite which will support political forces.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Judiciary">
        Judiciary
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Judiciary">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Slovenia" title="Judiciary of Slovenia">
        Judiciary of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Judicial powers in Slovenia are executed by
       <a href="/wiki/Judge" title="Judge">
        judges
       </a>
       , who are elected by the National Assembly. Judicial power in Slovenia is implemented by courts with general responsibilities and specialised courts that deal with matters relating to specific legal areas. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State%27s_Attorney" title="State's Attorney">
        State Prosecutor
       </a>
       is an independent state authority responsible for prosecuting cases brought against those suspected of committing criminal offences. The
       <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Slovenia" title="Constitutional Court of Slovenia">
        Constitutional Court
       </a>
