       , composed of nine judges elected for nine-year terms, decides on the conformity of laws with the Constitution; all laws and regulations must also conform with the general principles of international law and with ratified international agreements.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture.si_66-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-culture.si-66">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
        Military
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Military">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Slovenia" title="Military of Slovenia">
        Military of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AS_AL_532_SLO.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/AS_AL_532_SLO.jpg/220px-AS_AL_532_SLO.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/AS_AL_532_SLO.jpg/330px-AS_AL_532_SLO.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/AS_AL_532_SLO.jpg/440px-AS_AL_532_SLO.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AS_AL_532_SLO.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurocopter_Cougar" title="Eurocopter Cougar">
          Eurocopter Cougar
         </a>
         of the Slovenian Army
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ASIV_Slovenia_19_(23929783333).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2698" data-file-width="4054" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/ASIV_Slovenia_19_%2823929783333%29.jpg/220px-ASIV_Slovenia_19_%2823929783333%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/ASIV_Slovenia_19_%2823929783333%29.jpg/330px-ASIV_Slovenia_19_%2823929783333%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/ASIV_Slovenia_19_%2823929783333%29.jpg/440px-ASIV_Slovenia_19_%2823929783333%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ASIV_Slovenia_19_(23929783333).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Slovenian soldiers of 3rd Company of 10th Regiment at a military exercise
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenian_Armed_Forces" title="Slovenian Armed Forces">
        Slovenian Armed Forces
       </a>
       provide military defence independently or within an alliance, in accordance with international agreements. Since conscription was abolished in 2003, it is organized as a fully professional
       <a href="/wiki/Standing_army" title="Standing army">
        standing army
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
        <a href="#cite_note-151">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commander-in-Chief" title="Commander-in-Chief">
        Commander-in-Chief
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Slovenia" title="President of Slovenia">
        President of the Republic of Slovenia
       </a>
       , while operational command is in the domain of the
       <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_the_General_Staff_(Slovenia)" title="Chief of the General Staff (Slovenia)">
        Chief of the General Staff
       </a>
       of the Slovenian Armed Forces. In 2016, military spending was an estimated 0.91% of the country's GDP. Since joining
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       , the Slovenian Armed Forces have taken a more active part in supporting international peace. They have participated in peace support operations and humanitarian activities. Among others, Slovenian soldiers are a part of international forces serving in
       <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">
        Bosnia and Herzegovina
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">
        Kosovo
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">
        Afghanistan
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
        <a href="#cite_note-152">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Government">
        Government
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Government">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions_and_traditional_regions">
        Administrative divisions and traditional regions
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Administrative divisions and traditional regions">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Statistical_regions_of_Slovenia" title="Statistical regions of Slovenia">
        Statistical regions of Slovenia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Slovenia" title="Municipalities of Slovenia">
        Municipalities of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <table class="infobox bordered" style="width: auto;">
       <caption>
        Traditional regions of Slovenia
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <div class="center">
          <div class="floatnone">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Borders_of_the_Historical_Habsburgian_Lands_in_the_Republic_of_Slovenia.png">
            <img alt="Borders of the Historical Habsburgian Lands in the Republic of Slovenia.png" data-file-height="637" data-file-width="919" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Borders_of_the_Historical_Habsburgian_Lands_in_the_Republic_of_Slovenia.png/250px-Borders_of_the_Historical_Habsburgian_Lands_in_the_Republic_of_Slovenia.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Borders_of_the_Historical_Habsburgian_Lands_in_the_Republic_of_Slovenia.png/375px-Borders_of_the_Historical_Habsburgian_Lands_in_the_Republic_of_Slovenia.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Borders_of_the_Historical_Habsburgian_Lands_in_the_Republic_of_Slovenia.png/500px-Borders_of_the_Historical_Habsburgian_Lands_in_the_Republic_of_Slovenia.png 2x" width="250"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <center>
          <span style="color:#3f3f3f">
           <b>
            1
           </b>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
           Slovene Littoral
          </a>
          ;
          <span style="color:#3f3f3f">
           <b>
            Carniola:
           </b>
           <b>
            2a
           </b>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Upper_Carniola" title="Upper Carniola">
           Upper
          </a>
          <br/>
          <span style="color:#3f3f3f">
           <b>
            2b
           </b>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Inner_Carniola" title="Inner Carniola">
           Inner
          </a>
          ,
          <span style="color:#3f3f3f">
           <b>
            2c
           </b>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Lower_Carniola" title="Lower Carniola">
           Lower
          </a>
          <br/>
          <span style="color:#3f3f3f">
           <b>
            3
           </b>
          </span>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovene_Carinthia" title="Slovene Carinthia">
           Carinthia
          </a>
          ;
          <span style="color:#3f3f3f">
           <b>
            4
           </b>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Styria_(Slovenia)" title="Styria (Slovenia)">
           Styria
          </a>
          ;
          <span style="color:#3f3f3f">
           <b>
            5
           </b>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
           Prekmurje
          </a>
         </center>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Municipalities">
        Municipalities
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Municipalities">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Officially, Slovenia is subdivided into 211
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Municipalities" title="Municipalities">
        municipalities
       </a>
       (eleven of which have the status of urban municipalities). The municipalities are the only bodies of local autonomy in Slovenia. Each municipality is headed by a mayor (
       <i>
        župan
       </i>
       ), elected every four years by popular vote, and a municipal council (
       <i>
        občinski svet
       </i>
       ). In the majority of municipalities, the municipal council is elected through the system of
       <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">
        proportional representation
       </a>
       ; only a few smaller municipalities use the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" title="Plurality voting system">
        plurality voting system
       </a>
       . In the urban municipalities, the municipal councils are called town (or city) councils.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-www2.gov.si_153-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-www2.gov.si-153">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Every municipality also has a Head of the Municipal Administration (
       <i>
        načelnik občinske uprave
       </i>
       ), appointed by the mayor, who is responsible for the functioning of the local administration.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-www2.gov.si_153-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-www2.gov.si-153">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_districts">
        Administrative districts
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Administrative districts">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       There is no official intermediate unit between the municipalities and the Republic of Slovenia. The 62 administrative districts, officially called "Administrative Units" (
       <i>
        upravne enote
       </i>
       ), are only subdivisions of the national government administration and are named after their respective bases of government offices. They are headed by a Manager of the Unit (
       <i>
        načelnik upravne enote
       </i>
       ), appointed by the Minister of Public Administration.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Traditional_regions_and_identities">
        Traditional regions and identities
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Traditional regions and identities">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Traditional regions were based on the former
       <a href="/wiki/House_of_Habsburg" title="House of Habsburg">
        Habsburg
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Crown_land" title="Crown land">
        crown lands
       </a>
       that included
       <a href="/wiki/Carniola" title="Carniola">
        Carniola
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Carinthia" title="Duchy of Carinthia">
        Carinthia
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Styria_(duchy)" title="Styria (duchy)">
        Styria
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
        Littoral
       </a>
       . Stronger than with either the Carniola as a whole, or with Slovenia as the state, Slovenes historically tend to identify themselves with the traditional regions of
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
        Slovene Littoral
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
        Prekmurje
       </a>
       , and even traditional (sub)regions, such as Upper, Lower and, to a lesser extent, Inner Carniola.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Repe_deželani_ali_državljani_154-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Repe_deželani_ali_državljani-154">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Slovenia,_administrative_divisions_-_Nmbrs_(statistical_regions)_-_colored.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="859" data-file-width="1160" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Slovenia%2C_administrative_divisions_-_Nmbrs_%28statistical_regions%29_-_colored.svg/250px-Slovenia%2C_administrative_divisions_-_Nmbrs_%28statistical_regions%29_-_colored.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Slovenia%2C_administrative_divisions_-_Nmbrs_%28statistical_regions%29_-_colored.svg/375px-Slovenia%2C_administrative_divisions_-_Nmbrs_%28statistical_regions%29_-_colored.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Slovenia%2C_administrative_divisions_-_Nmbrs_%28statistical_regions%29_-_colored.svg/500px-Slovenia%2C_administrative_divisions_-_Nmbrs_%28statistical_regions%29_-_colored.svg.png 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Slovenia,_administrative_divisions_-_Nmbrs_(statistical_regions)_-_colored.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Statistical regions: 1. Gorizia, 2. Upper Carniola, 3. Carinthia, 4. Drava, 5. Mura, 6. Central Slovenia, 7. Central Sava, 8. Savinja, 9. Coastal–Karst, 10. Inner Carniola–Karst, 11. Southeast Slovenia, 12. Lower Sava
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The capital city Ljubljana was historically the administrative center of Carniola and belonged to
       <a href="/wiki/Lower_Carniola" title="Lower Carniola">
        Lower Carniola
       </a>
       , except for the Šentvid district, which was in
       <a href="/wiki/Upper_Carniola" title="Upper Carniola">
        Upper Carniola
       </a>
       where the border between the German occupation zone and
       <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Ljubljana" title="Province of Ljubljana">
        Province of Ljubljana
       </a>
       also was during WWII.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kje_so_naše_meje_155-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Kje_so_naše_meje-155">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Statistical_regions">
        Statistical regions
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Statistical regions">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The 12
       <i>
        statistical regions
       </i>
       have no administrative function and are subdivided into two macroregions for the purpose of the
       <a href="/wiki/Regional_policy_of_the_European_Union" title="Regional policy of the European Union">
        Regional policy of the European Union
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
        <a href="#cite_note-156">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These two macroregions are:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_Slovenia" title="East Slovenia">
         East Slovenia
        </a>
        (
        <i>
         Vzhodna Slovenija
        </i>
        – SI01), which groups the Mura, Drava, Carinthia, Savinja, Central Sava, Lower Sava, Southeast Slovenia, and Inner Carniola–Karst statistical regions.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Slovenia" title="West Slovenia">
         West Slovenia
        </a>
        (
        <i>
         Zahodna Slovenija
        </i>
        – SI02), which groups the Central Slovenia, Upper Carniola, Gorizia, and Coastal–Karst statistical regions.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Economy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Slovenia" title="Economy of Slovenia">
        Economy of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eurozone.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="456" data-file-width="450" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/220px-Eurozone.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/330px-Eurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/440px-Eurozone.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eurozone.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Since 2007 Slovenia has been part of the
         <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
          Eurozone
         </a>
         (dark blue).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenia has a
       <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">
        developed economy
       </a>
       and is
       <a href="/wiki/Per_capita_income" title="Per capita income">
        per capita
       </a>
       the richest of the Slavic countries by nominal GDP,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rich2_157-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-rich2-157">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the second richest by GDP (PPP) behind the
       <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">
        Czech Republic
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rich_158-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-rich-158">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Slovenia was in the beginning of 2007 the first new member to introduce the
       <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">
        euro
       </a>
       as its currency, replacing the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenian_tolar" title="Slovenian tolar">
        tolar
       </a>
       . Since 2010, it has been member of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VE2012-03-15_53-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-VE2012-03-15-53">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There is a big difference in prosperity between the various regions. The economically most prosperous regions are the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Slovenia_statistical_region" title="Central Slovenia statistical region">
        Central Slovenia
       </a>
       region which includes the capital
       <a href="/wiki/Ljubljana" title="Ljubljana">
        Ljubljana
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
        western Slovenian regions
       </a>
       , as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gori%C5%A1ka_Statistical_Region" title="Goriška Statistical Region">
        Goriška
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Coastal%E2%80%93Karst_Statistical_Region" title="Coastal–Karst Statistical Region">
        Coastal–Karst
       </a>
       . The poorest regions are the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mura_statistical_region" title="Mura statistical region">
        Mura
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Sava_statistical_region" title="Central Sava statistical region">
        Central Sava
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Littoral%E2%80%93Inner_Carniola_Statistical_Region" title="Littoral–Inner Carniola Statistical Region">
        Littoral–Inner Carniola
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bslo_160-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bslo-160">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_growth">
        Economic growth
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Economic growth">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Loan_to_deposit_ratio_in_Slovenia_-_including_the_Boom_Period..png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="260" data-file-width="564" height="92" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Loan_to_deposit_ratio_in_Slovenia_-_including_the_Boom_Period..png/200px-Loan_to_deposit_ratio_in_Slovenia_-_including_the_Boom_Period..png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Loan_to_deposit_ratio_in_Slovenia_-_including_the_Boom_Period..png/300px-Loan_to_deposit_ratio_in_Slovenia_-_including_the_Boom_Period..png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Loan_to_deposit_ratio_in_Slovenia_-_including_the_Boom_Period..png/400px-Loan_to_deposit_ratio_in_Slovenia_-_including_the_Boom_Period..png 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Loan_to_deposit_ratio_in_Slovenia_-_including_the_Boom_Period..png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Loan-deposit_ratio" title="Loan-deposit ratio">
          Loan-deposit ratio
         </a>
         in Slovenia by years – including the 2005–2008 Boom Period.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
          <a href="#cite_note-161">
           [155]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2004–2006, the economy grew on average by nearly 5% a year in Slovenia; in 2007, it expanded by almost 7%. The growth surge was fuelled by debt, particularly among firms, and especially in construction. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932010" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2010">
        financial crisis of 2007–2010
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_sovereign-debt_crisis" title="European sovereign-debt crisis">
        European sovereign-debt crisis
       </a>
       had a significant impact on the domestic economy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slovenia's_Economy:_Next_in_Line_162-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Slovenia's_Economy:_Next_in_Line-162">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The construction industry was severely hit in 2010 and 2011.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ST2012-03-13_163-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ST2012-03-13-163">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2009, Slovenian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP_per_capita" title="GDP per capita">
        GDP per capita
       </a>
       shrank by 8%, the biggest decline in the European Union after the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_countries" title="Baltic countries">
        Baltic countries
       </a>
       and Finland. An increasing burden for the Slovenian economy has been its rapidly ageing population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNBC2012-01-23_164-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CNBC2012-01-23-164">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In August 2012, the year-on-year contraction was 0.8%, however, 0.2% growth was recorded in the first quarter (in relation to the quarter before, after data was adjusted according to season and working days).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
        <a href="#cite_note-165">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Year-on-year contraction has been attributed to the fall in domestic consumption, and the slowdown in export growth. The decrease in domestic consumption has been attributed to the fiscal
       <a href="/wiki/Austerity" title="Austerity">
        austerity
       </a>
       , to the freeze on budget expenditure in the final months of 2011,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloomberg_166-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Bloomberg-166">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       to the failure of the efforts to implement
       <a href="/wiki/Microeconomic_reform" title="Microeconomic reform">
        economic reforms
       </a>
       , to inappropriate financing, and to the decrease in exports.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RTV2012-02-29_167-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-RTV2012-02-29-167">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Due to the effects of the crisis it was expected that several banks had to be bailed out by EU funds in 2013, however needed capital was able to be covered by the country's own funds. Fiscal actions and legislations aiming on the reduction of spendings as well as several privatisations supported an economic recovery as from 2014.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The real economic growth rate was at 2.5% in 2016 and is expected to reach 3.5% in 2017.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_169-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-auto-169">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The construction sector has seen a recent increase,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_169-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-auto-169">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the tourism industry is expected to have continuous rising numbers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
        <a href="#cite_note-170">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="National_debt">
        National debt
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: National debt">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Slovenia's total
       <a href="/wiki/Government_debt" title="Government debt">
        national debt
       </a>
       at the end of September 2011 amounted to 15,884 million euros, 44.4% of GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In August 2012, the three main
       <a href="/wiki/Credit_rating_agency" title="Credit rating agency">
        ratings agencies
       </a>
       downgraded Slovenian sovereign debt. A 2013 story about Slovenia allegedly being in need of a bailout was attributed by Finland's Europe Minister
       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Stubb" title="Alexander Stubb">
        Alexander Stubb
       </a>
       to "financial sharks" who wanted to capitalize on the story by creating
       <a href="/wiki/Self-fulfilling_prophecy" title="Self-fulfilling prophecy">
        self-fulfilling prophecies
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At the time,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Die_Welt" title="Die Welt">
         Die Welt
        </a>
       </i>
       ranked Slovenia among the three least financially vulnerable European countries, topped only by Germany and Estonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
        <a href="#cite_note-174">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Services_and_industry">
        Services and industry
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Services and industry">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Slovenia_treemap.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="861" data-file-width="1103" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Slovenia_treemap.png/250px-Slovenia_treemap.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Slovenia_treemap.png/375px-Slovenia_treemap.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Slovenia_treemap.png/500px-Slovenia_treemap.png 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Slovenia_treemap.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A graphical depiction of Slovenia's product exports in 28 color-coded categories.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Almost two-thirds of people are employed in services, and over one-third in industry and construction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_175-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-175">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Slovenia benefits from a well-educated workforce, well-developed infrastructure, and its location at the crossroads of major trade routes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VE2012-03-15_53-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-VE2012-03-15-53">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The level of
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">
        foreign direct investment
       </a>
       (FDI) per capita in Slovenia is one of the lowest in the EU,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VE2012-03-15_53-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-VE2012-03-15-53">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the labor productivity and the competitiveness of the Slovenian economy is still significantly below the EU average.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
        <a href="#cite_note-176">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Taxes are relatively high, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labor_market" title="Labor market">
        labor market
       </a>
       is seen by business interests as being inflexible, and industries are losing sales to China, India, and elsewhere.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       High level of openness makes Slovenia extremely sensitive to economic conditions in its main trading partners and changes in its international price competitiveness.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
        <a href="#cite_note-179">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The main industries are motor vehicles, electric and electronic equipment, machinery,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical" title="Pharmaceutical">
        pharmaceuticals
       </a>
       , and fuels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VE2012-03-15_53-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-VE2012-03-15-53">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Examples of major Slovenian companies operating in Slovenia include the home appliance manufacturer
       <a href="/wiki/Gorenje" title="Gorenje">
        Gorenje
       </a>
       , the pharmaceutical company
       <a href="/wiki/Krka_(company)" title="Krka (company)">
        Krka
       </a>
       , the oil distributing company
       <a href="/wiki/Petrol_Group" title="Petrol Group">
        Petrol Group
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Revoz" title="Revoz">
        Revoz
       </a>
       a manufacturing subsidiary of
       <a href="/wiki/Renault" title="Renault">
        Renault
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">
        Energy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Energy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Slovenia" title="Energy in Slovenia">
        Energy in Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2011 electricity production was 14,144 GWh and consumption was 12,602 GWh. Hydroelectric plants produced 3,361 GWh, thermal plants produced 4,883 GWh, and
       <a href="/wiki/Kr%C5%A1ko_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Krško Nuclear Power Plant">
        nuclear
       </a>
       plants produced 5,899 GWh.
      </p>
      <p>
       A new 600 MW block of Šoštanj thermal power plant is in construction and will be finished by 2014. The new 39.5 MW HE Krško hydro power plant was finished in 2013. By 2018, the 41.5 MW HE Brežice and 30.5 MW HE Mokrice hydro power plants will be built on the Sava River. Construction of ten hydropower plants on the
       <a href="/wiki/Sava" title="Sava">
        Sava River
       </a>
       with a cumulative capacity of 338 MW is planned to be finished by 2030. A large
       <a href="/wiki/Pumped-storage_hydroelectricity" title="Pumped-storage hydroelectricity">
        pumped-storage hydro power plant
       </a>
       Kozjak on the
       <a href="/wiki/Drava" title="Drava">
        Drava River
       </a>
       is in the planning stage.
      </p>
      <p>
       At the end of 2011 at least 87 MWp of photovoltaic modules and 22 MW of
       <a href="/wiki/Biogas" title="Biogas">
        biogas
       </a>
       powerplants were installed.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       There is a plan and obligation that at least 500 MW of wind power will be installed by 2020.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       Solar hot water heating is gaining popularity in Slovenia.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">
        Tourism
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Tourism">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Slovenia" title="Tourism in Slovenia">
        Tourism in Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bled_Overview.JPG">
           <img alt="Lake Bled" data-file-height="2056" data-file-width="3088" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Bled_Overview.JPG/200px-Bled_Overview.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Bled_Overview.JPG/300px-Bled_Overview.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Bled_Overview.JPG/400px-Bled_Overview.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Lake_Bled" title="Lake Bled">
           Lake Bled
          </a>
          with its island
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Panoramics_of_Piran_2015.jpg">
           <img alt="Piran" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="5376" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Panoramics_of_Piran_2015.jpg/200px-Panoramics_of_Piran_2015.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Panoramics_of_Piran_2015.jpg/300px-Panoramics_of_Piran_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Panoramics_of_Piran_2015.jpg/400px-Panoramics_of_Piran_2015.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Old town of
          <a href="/wiki/Piran" title="Piran">
           Piran
          </a>
          on Slovenian coast
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Postojna_(22206343750).jpg">
           <img alt="Postojna Cave" data-file-height="2117" data-file-width="3763" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Postojna_%2822206343750%29.jpg/200px-Postojna_%2822206343750%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Postojna_%2822206343750%29.jpg/300px-Postojna_%2822206343750%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Postojna_%2822206343750%29.jpg/400px-Postojna_%2822206343750%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Postojna_Cave" title="Postojna Cave">
           Postojna Cave
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenia offers tourists a wide variety of natural and cultural amenities. Different forms of tourism have developed. The tourist gravitational area is considerably large, however the tourist market is small. There has been no large-scale tourism and no acute environmental pressures.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
        <a href="#cite_note-182">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The nation's capital, Ljubljana, has many important
       <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">
        Baroque
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Vienna_Secession" title="Vienna Secession">
        Vienna Secession
       </a>
       buildings, with several important works of the native born architect
       <a href="/wiki/Jo%C5%BEe_Ple%C4%8Dnik" title="Jože Plečnik">
        Jože Plečnik
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
        <a href="#cite_note-183">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and also his pupil, architect Edo Ravnikar.
      </p>
      <p>
       At the northwestern corner of the country lie the
       <a href="/wiki/Julian_Alps" title="Julian Alps">
        Julian Alps
       </a>
       with the picturesque
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Bled" title="Lake Bled">
        Lake Bled
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/So%C4%8Da" title="Soča">
        Soča
       </a>
       Valley, as well as the nation's highest peak,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mount_Triglav" title="Mount Triglav">
        Mount Triglav
       </a>
       in the middle of
       <a href="/wiki/Triglav_National_Park" title="Triglav National Park">
        Triglav National Park
       </a>
       . Other mountain ranges include
       <a href="/wiki/Kamnik%E2%80%93Savinja_Alps" title="Kamnik–Savinja Alps">
        Kamnik–Savinja Alps
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karavanke" title="Karavanke">
        Karavanke
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Pohorje" title="Pohorje">
        Pohorje
       </a>
       , popular with skiers and hikers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
        <a href="#cite_note-184">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Karst_Plateau" title="Karst Plateau">
        Karst Plateau
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
        Slovene Littoral
       </a>
       gave its name to
       <a href="/wiki/Karst" title="Karst">
        karst
       </a>
       , a landscape shaped by water dissolving the carbonate bedrock, forming caves. The best-known caves are
       <a href="/wiki/Postojna_Cave" title="Postojna Cave">
        Postojna Cave
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">
        UNESCO
       </a>
       -listed
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0kocjan_Caves" title="Škocjan Caves">
        Škocjan Caves
       </a>
       . The region of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenian_Istria" title="Slovenian Istria">
        Slovenian Istria
       </a>
       meets the
       <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">
        Adriatic Sea
       </a>
       , where the most important historical monument is the
       <a href="/wiki/Venetian_Gothic_architecture" title="Venetian Gothic architecture">
        Venetian Gothic
       </a>
       Mediterranean town of
       <a href="/wiki/Piran" title="Piran">
        Piran
       </a>
       while the settlement of
       <a href="/wiki/Portoro%C5%BE" title="Portorož">
        Portorož
       </a>
       attracts crowds in summer.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
        <a href="#cite_note-185">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The hills around Slovenia's second-largest town,
       <a href="/wiki/Maribor" title="Maribor">
        Maribor
       </a>
       , are renowned for their wine-making. The northeastern part of the country is rich with spas,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
        <a href="#cite_note-186">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/Roga%C5%A1ka_Slatina" title="Rogaška Slatina">
        Rogaška Slatina
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Radenci" title="Radenci">
        Radenci
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%8Cate%C5%BE_ob_Savi" title="Čatež ob Savi">
        Čatež ob Savi
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dobrna" title="Dobrna">
        Dobrna
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Moravske_Toplice" title="Moravske Toplice">
        Moravske Toplice
       </a>
       growing in importance in the last two decades.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
        <a href="#cite_note-187">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Other popular tourist destinations include the historic cities of
       <a href="/wiki/Ptuj" title="Ptuj">
        Ptuj
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0kofja_Loka" title="Škofja Loka">
        Škofja Loka
       </a>
       , and several castles, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Predjama_Castle" title="Predjama Castle">
        Predjama Castle
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
        <a href="#cite_note-188">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
        <a href="#cite_note-189">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Important parts of tourism in Slovenia include congress and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gambling_tourism" title="Gambling tourism">
        gambling tourism
       </a>
       . Slovenia is the country with the highest percentage of
       <a href="/wiki/Casino" title="Casino">
        casinos
       </a>
       per 1,000 inhabitants in the European Union.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
        <a href="#cite_note-190">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Perla_hotel_and_casino&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Perla hotel and casino (page does not exist)">
        Perla
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Nova_Gorica" title="Nova Gorica">
        Nova Gorica
       </a>
       is the largest casino in the region.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Most of foreign tourists to Slovenia come from the key European markets:
       <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">
        Austria
       </a>
       , Germany,
       <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">
        Croatia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Benelux" title="Benelux">
        Benelux
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">
        Serbia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
        Russia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">
        Ukraine
       </a>
       , followed by UK and
       <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">
        Ireland
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
        <a href="#cite_note-192">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
       European tourists create more than 90% of Slovenia's tourist income. In 2016, Slovenia was declared the world's first green country by the Netherlands-based organization
       <a class="external text" href="http://greendestinations.info/" rel="nofollow">
        Green Destinations
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
        <a href="#cite_note-193">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On being declared the most sustainable country in 2016, Slovenia had a big part to play at the
       <a href="/wiki/ITB_Berlin" title="ITB Berlin">
        ITB Berlin
       </a>
       to promote sustainable tourism.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">
        Transport
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Transport">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Slovenia" title="Transport in Slovenia">
        Transport in Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pendolino_ETR_310.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2067" data-file-width="2901" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Pendolino_ETR_310.jpg/220px-Pendolino_ETR_310.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Pendolino_ETR_310.jpg/330px-Pendolino_ETR_310.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Pendolino_ETR_310.jpg/440px-Pendolino_ETR_310.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pendolino_ETR_310.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Pendolino" title="Pendolino">
          Pendolino
         </a>
         tilting train
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The location at the junction of major geographic units and the area being traversed by major rivers have been the reasons for the intersection of the main transport routes in Slovenia. Their course was established already in the Antiquity. A particular geographic advantage in recent times has been the location of the intersection of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pan-European_transport_corridor" title="Pan-European transport corridor">
        Pan-European transport corridors
       </a>
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Pan-European_transport_corridor_V&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pan-European transport corridor V (page does not exist)">
        V
       </a>
       (the fastest link between the North Adriatic, and Central and Eastern Europe) and
       <a href="/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_X" title="Pan-European Corridor X">
        X
       </a>
       (linking Central Europe with the Balkans) in the country. This gives it a special position in the European social, economic and cultural integration and restructuring.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UKOM2000-11_194-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UKOM2000-11-194">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Motorways-SLO-map.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1840" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Motorways-SLO-map.svg/220px-Motorways-SLO-map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Motorways-SLO-map.svg/330px-Motorways-SLO-map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Motorways-SLO-map.svg/440px-Motorways-SLO-map.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Motorways-SLO-map.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Motorways in Slovenia in 2011; capital Ljubljana lies in the intersection of north-south and west-east main directions
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The road freight and passenger transport constitutes the largest part of transport in Slovenia at 80%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MW2009SORS_195-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MW2009SORS-195">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Personal cars are much more popular than public road passenger transport, which has significantly declined.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MW2009SORS_195-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-MW2009SORS-195">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Slovenia has a very high
       <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Slovenia" title="Highways in Slovenia">
        highway and motorway density
       </a>
       compared to the European Union average.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ECORYS2011_197-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ECORYS2011-197">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The highway system, the construction of which was speeded up after 1994,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oplotnik2004_198-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Oplotnik2004-198">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       has slowly but steadily transformed Slovenia into a large
       <a href="/wiki/Conurbation" title="Conurbation">
        conurbation
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
        <a href="#cite_note-199">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other state roads have been rapidly deteriorating because of neglect and the overall increase in traffic.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ECORYS2011_197-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ECORYS2011-197">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The existing Slovenian railways are out-of-date and can't compete with the motorway network.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARSO420_200-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ARSO420-200">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       With a lack of financial assets, maintenance and modernisation of the Slovenian railway network have been neglected.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNIMB2011-04_201-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNIMB2011-04-201">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Due to the out-of-date infrastructure, the share of the railway freight transport has been in decline in Slovenia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARS416_202-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ARS416-202">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The railway passenger transport has been recovering after a large drop in the 1990s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARS416_202-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ARS416-202">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Pan-European railway corridors V and X, and several other major European rail lines intersect in Slovenia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNIMB2011-04_201-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNIMB2011-04-201">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       All international transit trains in Slovenia drive through the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Railway_Hub&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Ljubljana Railway Hub (page does not exist)">
        Ljubljana Railway Hub
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oDPN2010-03_203-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-oDPN2010-03-203">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ljubljana_airport_2017.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3190" data-file-width="5192" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ljubljana_airport_2017.jpg/220px-Ljubljana_airport_2017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ljubljana_airport_2017.jpg/330px-Ljubljana_airport_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ljubljana_airport_2017.jpg/440px-Ljubljana_airport_2017.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ljubljana_airport_2017.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Ljubljana_Jo%C5%BEe_Pu%C4%8Dnik_Airport" title="Ljubljana Jože Pučnik Airport">
          Ljubljana Jože Pučnik Airport
         </a>
         is the biggest international airport in the country
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The major Slovenian port is the
       <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Koper" title="Port of Koper">
        Port of Koper
       </a>
       . It is the largest Northern Adriatic port in terms of container transport,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with almost 590,000
       <a href="/wiki/Twenty-foot_equivalent_unit" title="Twenty-foot equivalent unit">
        TEUs
       </a>
       annually
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and lines to all major world ports.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ECONSHIP2011_206-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ECONSHIP2011-206">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AH2008-16-3GA_207-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AH2008-16-3GA-207">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is much closer to destinations east of the
       <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">
        Suez
       </a>
       than the ports of Northern Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ECONSHIP2011_206-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ECONSHIP2011-206">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition, the maritime passenger traffic mostly takes place in Koper.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RR21_208-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-RR21-208">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Two smaller ports used for the international passenger transport as well as cargo transport are located in
       <a href="/wiki/Izola" title="Izola">
        Izola
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Piran" title="Piran">
        Piran
       </a>
       . Passenger transport mainly takes place with Italy and Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReNPRP_209-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReNPRP-209">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Splo%C5%A1na_plovba&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Splošna plovba (page does not exist)">
        Splošna plovba
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the only Slovenian shipping company, transports freight and is active only in foreign ports.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RR21_208-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-RR21-208">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Air transport in Slovenia is quite low,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARS416_202-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-ARS416-202">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but has significantly grown since 1991.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RR26_211-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-RR26-211">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Of the three international airports in Slovenia,
       <a href="/wiki/Ljubljana_Jo%C5%BEe_Pu%C4%8Dnik_Airport" title="Ljubljana Jože Pučnik Airport">
        Ljubljana Jože Pučnik Airport
       </a>
       in central Slovenia is the busiest,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RR26_211-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-RR26-211">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with connections to many major European destinations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Maribor_Edvard_Rusjan_Airport" title="Maribor Edvard Rusjan Airport">
        Maribor Edvard Rusjan Airport
       </a>
       is located in the eastern part of the country and the
       <a href="/wiki/Portoro%C5%BE_Airport" title="Portorož Airport">
        Portorož Airport
       </a>
       in the western part.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RR26_211-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-RR26-211">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The state-owned
       <a href="/wiki/Adria_Airways" title="Adria Airways">
        Adria Airways
       </a>
       is the largest Slovenian airline.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RR26_211-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-RR26-211">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since 2003, several new carriers have entered the market, mainly low-cost airlines.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ECORYS2011_197-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-ECORYS2011-197">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The only Slovenian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_airbase" title="Military airbase">
        military airport
       </a>
       is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cerklje_ob_Krki_Air_Base" title="Cerklje ob Krki Air Base">
        Cerklje ob Krki Air Base
       </a>
       in the southwestern part of the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are also 12
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_airport" title="Public airport">
        public airports
       </a>
       in Slovenia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RR26_211-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-RR26-211">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Demographics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Slovenia" title="Demographics of Slovenia">
        Demographics of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dancing_in_the_Square_-_Ljubljana_(15617215922).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="567" data-file-width="851" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Dancing_in_the_Square_-_Ljubljana_%2815617215922%29.jpg/220px-Dancing_in_the_Square_-_Ljubljana_%2815617215922%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Dancing_in_the_Square_-_Ljubljana_%2815617215922%29.jpg/330px-Dancing_in_the_Square_-_Ljubljana_%2815617215922%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Dancing_in_the_Square_-_Ljubljana_%2815617215922%29.jpg/440px-Dancing_in_the_Square_-_Ljubljana_%2815617215922%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dancing_in_the_Square_-_Ljubljana_(15617215922).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Children dancing in a square in
         <a href="/wiki/Ljubljana" title="Ljubljana">
          Ljubljana
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 0.5em;">
       <tr>
        <th class="navbox-title" colspan="3" style="padding:0.25em;font-size:110%">
         Historical population
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr style="font-size:95%">
        <th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;width:3em">
         Year
        </th>
        <th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px 2px;text-align:right">
         <abbr title="Population">
          Pop.
         </abbr>
        </th>
        <th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;text-align:right">
         <abbr title="Percent change">
          ±%
         </abbr>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1921
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         1,054,919
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         —
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1931
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         1,144,298
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +8.5%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1948
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         1,391,873
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +21.6%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1953
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         1,466,425
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +5.4%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         1961
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         1,591,523
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         +8.5%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1971
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         1,727,137
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +8.5%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1981
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         1,891,864
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +9.5%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1991
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         1,913,355
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +1.1%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         2002
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         1,964,036
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +2.6%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         2011
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         2,050,189
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         +4.4%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         2017
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         2,065,895
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +0.8%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left">
         As of 1 January
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       With 101 inhabitants per square kilometer (262/sq mi), Slovenia ranks low among the European countries in population density (compared to 402/km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (1042/sq mi) for the
       <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">
        Netherlands
       </a>
       or 195/km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (505/sq mi) for
       <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       ). The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inner_Carniola%E2%80%93Karst_Statistical_Region" title="Inner Carniola–Karst Statistical Region">
        Inner Carniola–Karst Statistical Region
       </a>
       has the lowest population density while the
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Slovenia_Statistical_Region" title="Central Slovenia Statistical Region">
        Central Slovenia Statistical Region
       </a>
       has the highest.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Slovenia is among the European countries with the most pronounced ageing of its population, ascribable to a low birth rate and increasing life expectancy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Almost all Slovenian inhabitants older than 64 are retired, with no significant difference between the genders.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoff2011_216-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Hoff2011-216">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The working-age group is diminishing in spite of immigration.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
        <a href="#cite_note-217">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The proposal to raise the retirement age from the current 57 for women and 58 for men was rejected in a
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenian_referendum,_June_2011" title="Slovenian referendum, June 2011">
        referendum in 2011
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNBC2012-01-23_164-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-CNBC2012-01-23-164">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition, the difference among the genders regarding life expectancy is still significant.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoff2011_216-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Hoff2011-216">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">
        total fertility rate
       </a>
       (TFR) in 2014 was estimated at 1.33 children born/woman, which is lower than the replacement rate of 2.1.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The majority of children are born to unmarried women (in 2016, 58.6% of all births were outside of marriage).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
        <a href="#cite_note-219">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2016, life expectancy was 78.2 years (74.6 years male, and 82 years female).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
        <a href="#cite_note-220">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2009, the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_suicide_rate" title="List of countries by suicide rate">
        suicide rate
       </a>
       in Slovenia was 22 per 100,000 persons per year, which places Slovenia among the highest ranked European countries in this regard.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat2009suicide_221-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-stat2009suicide-221">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nonetheless, from 2000 until 2010, the rate has decreased by about 30%. The differences between regions and the genders are pronounced.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
        <a href="#cite_note-222">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">
        Urbanisation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Urbanisation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Slovenia" title="List of cities and towns in Slovenia">
        List of cities and towns in Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Depending on definition, between 65% and 79% of people live in wider urban areas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
        <a href="#cite_note-223">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
        OECD
       </a>
       definition of rural areas none of the
       <a href="/wiki/Statistical_regions_of_Slovenia" title="Statistical regions of Slovenia">
        Slovene statistical regions
       </a>
       is mostly urbanised, meaning that 15% or less of the population lives in rural communities. According to this definition statistical regions are classified:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        mostly rural regions:
        <a href="/wiki/Mura_Statistical_Region" title="Mura Statistical Region">
         Mura
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Drava_Statistical_Region" title="Drava Statistical Region">
         Drava
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Carinthia_Statistical_Region" title="Carinthia Statistical Region">
         Carinthia
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Savinja_Statistical_Region" title="Savinja Statistical Region">
         Savinja
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Lower_Sava_Statistical_Region" title="Lower Sava Statistical Region">
         Lower Sava
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Littoral%E2%80%93Inner_Carniola_Statistical_Region" title="Littoral–Inner Carniola Statistical Region">
         Littoral–Inner Carniola
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Gorizia_Statistical_Region" title="Gorizia Statistical Region">
         Gorizia
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Slovenia_Statistical_Region" title="Southeast Slovenia Statistical Region">
         Southeast Slovenia
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        moderately rural regions:
        <a href="/wiki/Central_Sava_Statistical_Region" title="Central Sava Statistical Region">
         Central Sava
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Upper_Carniola_Statistical_Region" title="Upper Carniola Statistical Region">
         Upper Carniola
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Coastal%E2%80%93Karst_Statistical_Region" title="Coastal–Karst Statistical Region">
         Coastal–Karst
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Central_Slovenia_Statistical_Region" title="Central Slovenia Statistical Region">
         Central Slovenia
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
         <a href="#cite_note-224">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       The only large town is the capital, Ljubljana. Other (medium-sized) towns include Maribor, Celje, and Kranj.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GV52-2_225-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GV52-2-225">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
        <a href="#cite_note-226">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Overall, there are eleven urban municipalities in Slovenia.
      </p>
      <table class="navbox" style="width: 97%">
       <tr>
        <th colspan="10" style="padding:0.3em 0; line-height:1.4em;">

      </table>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
        Languages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Languages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Slovenia" title="Languages of Slovenia">
        Languages of Slovenia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">
        Slovene language
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The official language in Slovenia is
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">
        Slovene
       </a>
       , which is a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/South_Slavic_languages" title="South Slavic languages">
        South Slavic language group
       </a>
       . In 2002, Slovene was the native language of around 88% of Slovenia's population according to the census, with more than 92% of the Slovenian population speaking it in their home environment.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-siol.net_227-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-siol.net-227">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat.si_228-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-stat.si-228">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
