       This statistic ranks Slovenia among the most homogeneous countries in the EU in terms of the share of speakers of the predominant mother tongue.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dular_229-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Dular-229">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Slovene is a highly diverse Slavic language in terms of
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_dialects" title="Slovene dialects">
        dialects
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MLD_2009_230-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MLD_2009-230">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with different degrees of mutual intelligibility. Accounts of the number of dialects range from as few as seven
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
        <a href="#cite_note-231">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
        <a href="#cite_note-232">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
        <a href="#cite_note-233">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
       dialects, often considered dialect groups or dialect bases that are further subdivided into as many as 50 dialects.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
        <a href="#cite_note-234">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other sources characterize the number of dialects as nine
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
        <a href="#cite_note-235">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or as eight.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
        <a href="#cite_note-236">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Slovenian_Passport3.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="901" data-file-width="635" height="241" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Slovenian_Passport3.jpg/170px-Slovenian_Passport3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Slovenian_Passport3.jpg/255px-Slovenian_Passport3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Slovenian_Passport3.jpg/340px-Slovenian_Passport3.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Slovenian_Passport3.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Front cover of a bilingual Slovene passport
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       , spoken by the respective minorities, enjoy the status of official languages in the ethnically mixed regions along the Hungarian and Italian borders, to the extent that even the passports issued in those areas are bilingual. In 2002 around 0.2% of the Slovenian population spoke Italian and around 0.4% spoke Hungarian as their native language. Hungarian is co-official with Slovene in 30 settlements in 5 municipalities (whereof 3 are officially bilingual). Italian is co-official with Slovene in 25 settlements in 4 municipalities (all of them officially bilingual).
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">
        Romani
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
        <a href="#cite_note-237">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
       spoken in 2002 as the native language by 0.2% of people, is a legally protected language in Slovenia. Romani-speakers mainly belong to the geographically dispersed and marginalized Roma community.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
        <a href="#cite_note-238">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       German, which used to be the largest minority language in Slovenia prior to World War II (around 4% of the population in 1921), is now the native language of only around 0.08% of the population, the majority of whom are more than 60 years old.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat.si_228-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-stat.si-228">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Gottscheerish" title="Gottscheerish">
        Gottscheerish
       </a>
       or
       <i>
        Granish
       </i>
       , the traditional German dialect of
       <a href="/wiki/Gottschee" title="Gottschee">
        Gottschee County
       </a>
       , faces extinction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-norwaysi_239-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-norwaysi-239">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A significant number of people in Slovenia speak a variant of
       <a href="/wiki/Serbo-Croatian" title="Serbo-Croatian">
        Serbo-Croatian
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Serbian_language" title="Serbian language">
        Serbian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_language" title="Bosnian language">
        Bosnian
       </a>
       , or
       <a href="/wiki/Montenegrin_language" title="Montenegrin language">
        Montenegrin
       </a>
       ) as their native language. These are mostly immigrants who moved to Slovenia from other
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Former_Yugoslav" title="Former Yugoslav">
        former Yugoslav
       </a>
       republics from the 1960s to the late 1980s, and their descendants. In 2002, 0.4% of the Slovenian population declared themselves to be native speakers of
       <a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">
        Albanian
       </a>
       and 0.2% native speakers of
       <a href="/wiki/Macedonian_language" title="Macedonian language">
        Macedonian
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat.si_228-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-stat.si-228">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Czech_language" title="Czech language">
        Czech
       </a>
       , the fourth-largest minority language in Slovenia prior to World War II (after German, Hungarian, and Serbo-Croatian), is now the native language of a few hundred residents of Slovenia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat.si_228-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-stat.si-228">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Regarding the knowledge of foreign languages, Slovenia ranks among the top European countries. The most taught foreign languages are English, German, Italian, French and Spanish. As of 2007
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , 92% of the population between the age of 25 and 64 spoke at least one foreign language and around 71.8% of them spoke at least two foreign languages, which was the highest percentage in the European Union.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
        <a href="#cite_note-240">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">
        Eurobarometer
       </a>
       survey, as of 2005
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the majority of Slovenes could speak
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian
       </a>
       (61%) and English (56%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EurobarLang_241-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EurobarLang-241">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        :
        <span>
         21
        </span>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A reported 42% of Slovenes could speak German, which was one of the highest percentages outside German-speaking countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EurobarLang_241-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-EurobarLang-241">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Italian is widely spoken on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenian_Istria" title="Slovenian Istria">
        Slovenian Coast
       </a>
       and in some other areas of the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
        Slovene Littoral
       </a>
       . Around 15% of Slovenians can speak Italian, which is (according to the Eurobarometer pool) the third-highest percentage in the European Union, after Italy and
       <a href="/wiki/Malta" title="Malta">
        Malta
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
        <a href="#cite_note-242">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">
        Immigration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Immigration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       In 2015 about 12% (237,616 people) of the population in Slovenia was born abroad.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SURS_243-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SURS-243">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
       About 86% of the foreign-born population originated from countries of the former Yugoslavia state as (in descending order)
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosnia-Herzegovina" title="Bosnia-Herzegovina">
        Bosnia-Herzegovina
       </a>
       , followed by immigrants from
       <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">
        Croatia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">
        Serbia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Macedonia" title="Republic of Macedonia">
        Macedonia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">
        Kosovo
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SURS_243-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-SURS-243">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       By the beginning of 2017 there were about 114,438 people with a foreign citizenship residing in the country making up 5.5% of the total population. Of these foreigners 76% had citizenships of countries from the former Yugoslavia state (excluding Croatia). Additionally 16.4% had EU-citizenships and 7.6% had citizenships of other countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SURS_243-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-SURS-243">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:300px; background: white;">
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
         <tr style="background:#ddd">
          <th colspan="5" style="text-align:center;">
           Ethnic composition of Slovenia
           <br/>
           (according to the 2002 census)
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2002census_7-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-2002census-7">
             [4]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </th>
         </tr>
         <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Slovene
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:teal; width:83.06%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           83.06%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Serb
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:teal; width:1.98%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           1.98%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Croat
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:teal; width:1.81%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           1.81%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Bosniak
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:teal; width:1.10%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           1.10%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           other minorities
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:teal; width:4.85%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           4.85%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           undeclared or unknown
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:gray; width:8.9%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           8.9%
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to the 2002 census, Slovenia's main ethnic group are
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenes" title="Slovenes">
        Slovenes
       </a>
       (83%), however their share in the total population is continuously decreasing due to their relatively low
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fertility_rate" title="Fertility rate">
        fertility rate
       </a>
       . At least 13% (2002) of the population were immigrants from other parts of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Former_Yugoslavia" title="Former Yugoslavia">
        Former Yugoslavia
       </a>
       and their descendants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Medvesek_244-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Medvesek-244">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       They have settled mainly in cities and suburbanised areas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Repolusk_245-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Repolusk-245">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Relatively small but protected by the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Slovenia" title="Constitution of Slovenia">
        Constitution of Slovenia
       </a>
       are the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarians_in_Slovenia" title="Hungarians in Slovenia">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italians_in_Slovenia" title="Italians in Slovenia">
        Italian ethnic minority
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MDL2010_246-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MDL2010-246">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution_247-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Constitution-247">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
        <a href="#cite_note-248">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A special position is held by the autochthonous and geographically dispersed
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Roma_in_Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Roma in Slovenia (page does not exist)">
        Roma ethnic community
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
        <a href="#cite_note-249">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
        <a href="#cite_note-250">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The number of people immigrating into Slovenia rose steadily from 1995
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_251-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-251">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and has been increasing even more rapidly in recent years. After Slovenia joined the EU in 2004, the annual number of immigrants doubled by 2006 and increased by half yet again by 2009.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
        <a href="#cite_note-252">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2007, Slovenia had one of the fastest growing
       <a href="/wiki/Net_migration_rate" title="Net migration rate">
        net migration rates
       </a>
       in the European Union.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_251-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-251">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Emigration">
        Emigration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Emigration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       As to emigration, between 1880 and 1918 (World War I) many men left Slovenia to work in mining areas in other nations. The United States in particular has been a common choice for emigration, with the 1910 US Census showing that there were already "183,431 persons in the USA of Slovenian mother tongue".
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute">
          <span title="The material near this tag is possibly inaccurate or nonfactual. (April 2016)">
           dubious
          </span>
         </a>
         <span class="metadata">
          –
          <a href="/wiki/Talk:Slovenia#Dubious" title="Talk:Slovenia">
           discuss
          </a>
         </span>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       But there may have been many more, because a good number avoided anti-Slavic prejudice and "identified themselves as Austrians." Favorite localities before 1900 were Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan, as well as
       <a href="/wiki/Omaha,_Nebraska" title="Omaha, Nebraska">
        Omaha, Nebraska
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Joliet,_Illinois" title="Joliet, Illinois">
        Joliet, Illinois
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cleveland,_Ohio" title="Cleveland, Ohio">
        Cleveland, Ohio
       </a>
       , and rural areas of Iowa. After 1910, they settled in Utah (Bingham Copper Mine), Colorado (especially Pueblo), and Butte, Montana. These areas attracted first many single men (who often boarded with Slovenian families). Then after locating work and having sufficient money, the men sent back for their wives and families to join them.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
        <a href="#cite_note-253">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Religion">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Slovenia" title="Religion in Slovenia">
        Religion in Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft" style="">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:200px">
        <div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black">
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:GreenYellow">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 7957.328271171px; border-left-color:Turquoise">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Turquoise">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Turquoise">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 1589.4544843868px; border-left-color:Orchid">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Orchid">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Orchid">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 475.35631175227px; border-left-color:Green">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Green">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Green">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 267.17780051814px; border-left-color:Lime">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Lime">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Lime">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 153.28270598844px; border-left-color:Silver">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Silver">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Silver">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 60.848773868077px; border-left-color:Black">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Black">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Black">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:99.556196460308px 9.4108313318511px 0 0; border-top-color:Honeydew">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Honeydew">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:47.070393216533px 88.229122643495px 0 0; border-top-color:#2243B6">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#2243B6">
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <p>
          Religion in Slovenia (2002 census
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crnic_254-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-Crnic-254">
            [248]
           </a>
          </sup>
          )
         </p>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #2243B6; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" title="Roman Catholicism">
           Roman Catholicism
          </a>
          (57.8%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Honeydew; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Undeclared (15.7%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Black; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">
           Non-religious
          </a>
          (10.2%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Silver; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Unknown (7.1%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Lime; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Believer, no religion (3.5%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Green; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
           Islam
          </a>
          (2.4%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Orchid; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orthodox_Church" title="Orthodox Church">
           Eastern Orthodoxy
          </a>
          (2.3%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Turquoise; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">
           Lutheranism
          </a>
          (0.8%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:GreenYellow; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Other religion (0.2%)
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Radovljica_Brezje_Bazilika_Sv_Vida_28082012_011.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1979" data-file-width="2832" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Radovljica_Brezje_Bazilika_Sv_Vida_28082012_011.jpg/200px-Radovljica_Brezje_Bazilika_Sv_Vida_28082012_011.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Radovljica_Brezje_Bazilika_Sv_Vida_28082012_011.jpg/300px-Radovljica_Brezje_Bazilika_Sv_Vida_28082012_011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Radovljica_Brezje_Bazilika_Sv_Vida_28082012_011.jpg/400px-Radovljica_Brezje_Bazilika_Sv_Vida_28082012_011.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Radovljica_Brezje_Bazilika_Sv_Vida_28082012_011.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Basilica of the Virgin Mary in
         <a href="/wiki/Brezje,_Radovljica" title="Brezje, Radovljica">
          Brezje
         </a>
         , also known as the Slovenian National Shrine, is the most visited
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic" title="Catholic">
          Catholic
         </a>
         pilgrimage site in Slovenia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Evangeli%C4%8Danska_cerkev,_Bodonci.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1067" data-file-width="1600" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Evangeli%C4%8Danska_cerkev%2C_Bodonci.jpg/200px-Evangeli%C4%8Danska_cerkev%2C_Bodonci.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Evangeli%C4%8Danska_cerkev%2C_Bodonci.jpg/300px-Evangeli%C4%8Danska_cerkev%2C_Bodonci.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Evangeli%C4%8Danska_cerkev%2C_Bodonci.jpg/400px-Evangeli%C4%8Danska_cerkev%2C_Bodonci.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Evangeli%C4%8Danska_cerkev,_Bodonci.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lutheran" title="Lutheran">
          Lutheran
         </a>
         church in
         <a href="/wiki/Bodonci" title="Bodonci">
          Bodonci
         </a>
         in the Prekmurje region
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Before World War II, 97% of the population declared itself
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Slovenia" title="Roman Catholicism in Slovenia">
        Catholic
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Rite" title="Roman Rite">
        Roman Rite
       </a>
       ), around 2.5% as Lutheran, and around 0.5% of residents identified themselves as members of other denominations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat.si_228-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-stat.si-228">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Catholicism was an important feature of both social and political life in pre-Communist Slovenia. After 1945, the country underwent a process of gradual but steady
       <a href="/wiki/Secularization" title="Secularization">
        secularization
       </a>
       . After a decade of persecution of religions, the Communist regime adopted a policy of relative tolerance towards churches. After 1990, the Catholic Church regained some of its former influence, but Slovenia remains a largely secularized society. According to the 2002 census, 57.8% of the population is Catholic. In 1991, 71.6% were self-declared Catholics which means a drop of more than 1% annually.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
        <a href="#cite_note-255">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The vast majority of Slovenian Catholics belong to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_Rite" title="Latin Rite">
        Latin Rite
       </a>
       . A small number of
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">
        Greek Catholics
       </a>
       live in the
       <a href="/wiki/White_Carniola" title="White Carniola">
        White Carniola
       </a>
       region.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
        <a href="#cite_note-256">
         [250]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Despite a relatively small number of
       <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">
        Protestants
       </a>
       (less than 1% in 2002), the Protestant legacy is historically significant given that the Slovene standard language and Slovene literature were established by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">
        Protestant Reformation
       </a>
       in the 16th century.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primoz_Trubar" title="Primoz Trubar">
        Primoz Trubar
       </a>
       , a theologian in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lutheran" title="Lutheran">
        Lutheran
       </a>
       tradition, was one of the most influential
       <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformers" title="Protestant Reformers">
        Protestant Reformers
       </a>
       in Slovenia. Protestantism was extinguished in the
       <a href="/wiki/Counter-Reformation" title="Counter-Reformation">
        Counter-Reformation
       </a>
       implemented by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habsburg_dynasty" title="Habsburg dynasty">
        Habsburg dynasty
       </a>
       , which controlled the region. It only survived in the easternmost regions due to protection of Hungarian nobles, who often happened to be
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Calvinist" title="Calvinist">
        Calvinist
       </a>
       themselves. Today, a significant
       <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">
        Lutheran
       </a>
       minority lives in the easternmost region of
       <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
        Prekmurje
       </a>
       , where they represent around a fifth of the population and are headed by a bishop with the seat in
       <a href="/wiki/Murska_Sobota" title="Murska Sobota">
        Murska Sobota
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257">
        <a href="#cite_note-257">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Besides these two Christian denominations, a small
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Slovenia" title="History of the Jews in Slovenia">
        Jewish community
       </a>
       has also been historically present. Despite the losses suffered during the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust">
        Holocaust
       </a>
       , Judaism still numbers a few hundred adherents, mostly living in Ljubljana, site of the sole remaining active
       <a href="/wiki/Synagogue" title="Synagogue">
        synagogue
       </a>
       in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
        <a href="#cite_note-258">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the 2002 census,
       <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
        Islam
       </a>
       is the second largest religious denomination with around 2.4% of the population. Most Slovenian Muslims came from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosnia" title="Bosnia">
        Bosnia
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259">
        <a href="#cite_note-259">
         [253]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The third largest denomination, with around 2.2% of the population, is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orthodox_Church" title="Orthodox Church">
        Orthodox Christianity
       </a>
       , with most adherents belonging to the
       <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Orthodox_Church" title="Serbian Orthodox Church">
        Serbian Orthodox Church
       </a>
       while a minority belongs to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Macedonian_Orthodox_Church" title="Macedonian Orthodox Church">
        Macedonian
       </a>
       and other Orthodox churches.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 2002, around 10% of Slovenes declared themselves as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheists" title="Atheists">
        atheists
       </a>
       , another 10% professed no specific denomination, and around 16% decided not to answer the question about their religious affiliation. According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">
        Eurobarometer Poll
       </a>
       2010,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
        <a href="#cite_note-260">
         [254]
        </a>
       </sup>
       32% of Slovenian citizens responded that "they believe there is a god", whereas 36% answered that "they believe there is some sort of spirit or life force" and 26% that "they do not believe there is any sort of spirit, god, or life force".
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Education">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Slovenia" title="Education in Slovenia">
        Education in Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:University_of_Ljubljana_Palace.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3400" data-file-width="4584" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/University_of_Ljubljana_Palace.jpg/220px-University_of_Ljubljana_Palace.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/University_of_Ljubljana_Palace.jpg/330px-University_of_Ljubljana_Palace.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/University_of_Ljubljana_Palace.jpg/440px-University_of_Ljubljana_Palace.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UniverzaMaribor.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/UniverzaMaribor.jpg/220px-UniverzaMaribor.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/UniverzaMaribor.jpg/330px-UniverzaMaribor.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/UniverzaMaribor.jpg/440px-UniverzaMaribor.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Universities in Ljubljana and Maribor
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenia's education ranks as the 12th best in the world and 4th best in the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       , being significantly higher than the
       <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
        OECD
       </a>
       average, according to the
       <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">
        Programme for International Student Assessment
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
        <a href="#cite_note-261">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Among people age 25 to 64, 12% have attended higher education, while on average Slovenes have 9.6 years of formal education. According to an OECD report, 83% of adults ages 25–64 have earned the equivalent of a high school degree, well above the OECD average of 74%; among 25- to 34-year-olds, the rate is 93%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
        <a href="#cite_note-262">
         [256]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the 1991 census there is 99.6%
       <a href="/wiki/Literacy" title="Literacy">
        literacy
       </a>
       in Slovenia.
       <a href="/wiki/Lifelong_learning" title="Lifelong learning">
        Lifelong learning
       </a>
       is also increasing.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_263-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-263">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Primary
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Responsibility for education oversight at primary and secondary level in Slovenia lies with the Ministry of Education and Sports. After non-compulsory pre-school education, children enter the nine-year
       <a href="/wiki/Primary_school" title="Primary school">
        primary school
       </a>
       at the age of six.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
        <a href="#cite_note-264">
         [258]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Primary school is divided into three periods, each of three years. In the academic year 2006–2007 there were 166,000 pupils enrolled in elementary education and more than 13,225 teachers, giving a ratio of one teacher per 12 pupils and 20 pupils per class.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_263-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-263">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Secondary
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       After completing elementary school, nearly all children (more than 98%) go on to secondary education, either vocational, technical or general secondary programmes (
       <a href="/wiki/Gymnasium_(school)" title="Gymnasium (school)">
        gimnazija
       </a>
       ). The latter concludes with
       <a href="/wiki/Matura#Matura_in_Slovenia" title="Matura">
        matura
       </a>
       , the final exam that allows the graduates to enter a university. 84% of secondary school graduates go on to tertiary education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_263-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-263">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Tertiary
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Among several universities in Slovenia, the best ranked is the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Ljubljana" title="University of Ljubljana">
        University of Ljubljana
       </a>
       , ranking among the first 500 or the first 3% of the world's best universities according to the
       <a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">
        ARWU
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
        <a href="#cite_note-265">
         [259]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
        <a href="#cite_note-266">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Two other public universities include the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Maribor" title="University of Maribor">
        University of Maribor
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
        <a href="#cite_note-267">
         [261]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Styria_(Slovenia)" title="Styria (Slovenia)">
        Styria
       </a>
       region and the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Primorska" title="University of Primorska">
        University of Primorska
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
        Slovene Littoral
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
        <a href="#cite_note-268">
         [262]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition, there is a private
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Nova_Gorica" title="University of Nova Gorica">
        University of Nova Gorica
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
        <a href="#cite_note-269">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and an international
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EMUNI_University" title="EMUNI University">
        EMUNI University
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
        <a href="#cite_note-270">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Culture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Slovenia" title="Culture of Slovenia">
        Culture of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ivan_Grohar_-_Sejalec.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1427" data-file-width="1600" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ivan_Grohar_-_Sejalec.jpg/220px-Ivan_Grohar_-_Sejalec.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ivan_Grohar_-_Sejalec.jpg/330px-Ivan_Grohar_-_Sejalec.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ivan_Grohar_-_Sejalec.jpg/440px-Ivan_Grohar_-_Sejalec.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ivan_Grohar_-_Sejalec.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/The_Sower" title="The Sower">
           The Sower
          </a>
         </i>
         (1907), produced by the impressionist painter
         <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Grohar" title="Ivan Grohar">
          Ivan Grohar
         </a>
         , became a
         <a href="/wiki/Metaphor" title="Metaphor">
          metaphor
         </a>
         for Slovenes
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
          <a href="#cite_note-271">
           [265]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
          <a href="#cite_note-272">
           [266]
          </a>
         </sup>
         and was a reflection of the transition from a rural to an urban culture.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
          <a href="#cite_note-273">
           [267]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Heritage">
        Heritage
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Heritage">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Slovenia has a widespread and diverse architectural heritage, including 2,500 churches, 1,000 castles, ruins, and manor houses, farmhouses, and special structures for drying hay, called
       <a href="/wiki/Hayrack" title="Hayrack">
        hayracks
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        <span lang="sl" title="Slovene language text">
         kozolci
        </span>
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       Three
       <a href="/wiki/Historic_site" title="Historic site">
        historic sites
       </a>
       in Slovenia are on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">
        UNESCO World Heritage Site
       </a>
       list.
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0kocjan_Caves" title="Škocjan Caves">
        Škocjan Caves
       </a>
       and its
       <a href="/wiki/Karst" title="Karst">
        karst
       </a>
       landscape are a protected site. The
       <a href="/wiki/Heritage_of_Mercury._Almad%C3%A9n_and_Idrija" title="Heritage of Mercury. Almadén and Idrija">
        Idrija Mercury mining site
       </a>
       is of world importance, as are the
       <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_pile_dwellings_around_the_Alps" title="Prehistoric pile dwellings around the Alps">
        prehistoric pile dwellings
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Ljubljana_Marshes" title="Ljubljana Marshes">
        Ljubljana Marshes
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The most picturesque church is the medieval and Baroque building on
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Bled#Bled_Island" title="Lake Bled">
        Bled Island
       </a>
       . The castle above the lake is a museum and restaurant with a view. Near
       <a href="/wiki/Postojna" title="Postojna">
        Postojna
       </a>
       there is a fortress called the
       <a href="/wiki/Predjama_Castle" title="Predjama Castle">
        Predjama Castle
       </a>
       , half hidden in a cave. Museums in Ljubljana and elsewhere feature unique items such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Divje_Babe_Flute" title="Divje Babe Flute">
        Divje Babe Flute
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Ljubljana_Marshes_Wheel" title="Ljubljana Marshes Wheel">
        oldest wheel in the world
       </a>
       . Ljubljana has medieval, Baroque, Art Nouveau, and modern architecture. The architect
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ple%C4%8Dnik" title="Plečnik">
        Plečnik
       </a>
       's architecture and his innovative paths and bridges along the Ljubljanica are notable.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Comedy">
        Comedy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Comedy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Comedians historically included the pioneer of Slovene comedy plays Anton Tomaž Linhart and much later
       <a href="/wiki/Singer-songwriter" title="Singer-songwriter">
        singer-songwriter
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Frane_Mil%C4%8Dinski" title="Frane Milčinski">
        Frane Milčinski
       </a>
       (1914–1988), the socialist period comedian and journalist
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Tone_Fornezzi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tone Fornezzi (page does not exist)">
        Tone Fornezzi
       </a>
       , the Italian-style comedians
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Nata%C5%A1a_Ti%C4%8D_Raljan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Nataša Tič Raljan (page does not exist)">
        Nataša Tič Raljan
       </a>
       with her
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Mona_Liza&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Mona Liza (page does not exist)">
        Mona Liza
       </a>
       character,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gojmir_Le%C5%A1njak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gojmir Lešnjak (page does not exist)">
        Gojmir Lešnjak
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Boris_Kobal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Boris Kobal (page does not exist)">
        Boris Kobal
       </a>
       with the characters from the legendary
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=TV_Poper_Show&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="TV Poper Show (page does not exist)">
        TV Poper Show
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TV_Poper_Show_274-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TV_Poper_Show-274">
         [268]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the leading Slovene impersonator
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Sa%C5%A1o_Hribar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Sašo Hribar (page does not exist)">
        Sašo Hribar
       </a>
       with his
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Radio_Ga-Ga_Show&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Radio Ga-Ga Show (page does not exist)">
        Radio Ga-Ga Show
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The new generation of comedians include
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stand_up_comedy" title="Stand up comedy">
        stand up comedians
       </a>
       , such as
       <a href="/wiki/Tin_Vodopivec" title="Tin Vodopivec">
        Tin Vodopivec
       </a>
       , who co-founded the
       <a href="/wiki/Punch_Festival" title="Punch Festival">
        Punch Festival
       </a>
       , the radio host and impersonator
       <a href="/wiki/Denis_Avdi%C4%87" title="Denis Avdić">
        Denis Avdić
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Elephant_and_a_Fruit" title="The Elephant and a Fruit">
        The Elephant and a Fruit
       </a>
       group.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slon_in_Sadez_History_275-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Slon_in_Sadez_History-275">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Cuisine">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenian_cuisine" title="Slovenian cuisine">
        Slovenian cuisine
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenian_wine" title="Slovenian wine">
        Slovenian wine
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PrekmurskaGibanica1.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/PrekmurskaGibanica1.JPG/220px-PrekmurskaGibanica1.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/PrekmurskaGibanica1.JPG/330px-PrekmurskaGibanica1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/PrekmurskaGibanica1.JPG/440px-PrekmurskaGibanica1.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PrekmurskaGibanica1.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Prekmurska_gibanica" title="Prekmurska gibanica">
          Prekmurska gibanica
         </a>
         is a typical pastry of the
         <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
          Prekmurje
         </a>
         region.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Velika_no%C4%8D_-_jedila_hren_%C5%A1unka_pirhi_potica.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2000" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Velika_no%C4%8D_-_jedila_hren_%C5%A1unka_pirhi_potica.jpg/150px-Velika_no%C4%8D_-_jedila_hren_%C5%A1unka_pirhi_potica.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Velika_no%C4%8D_-_jedila_hren_%C5%A1unka_pirhi_potica.jpg/225px-Velika_no%C4%8D_-_jedila_hren_%C5%A1unka_pirhi_potica.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Velika_no%C4%8D_-_jedila_hren_%C5%A1unka_pirhi_potica.jpg/300px-Velika_no%C4%8D_-_jedila_hren_%C5%A1unka_pirhi_potica.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Velika_no%C4%8D_-_jedila_hren_%C5%A1unka_pirhi_potica.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Potica as part of traditional Slovenian Easter breakfast
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenian cuisine is a mixture of the Central European cuisine (especially
       <a href="/wiki/Austrian_cuisine" title="Austrian cuisine">
        Austrian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_cuisine" title="Hungarian cuisine">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       ), the
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_cuisine" title="Mediterranean cuisine">
        Mediterranean cuisine
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Balkan_cuisine" title="Balkan cuisine">
        Balkan cuisine
       </a>
       . Historically, Slovenian cuisine was divided into town, farmhouse, cottage, castle, parsonage and monastic cuisines. Due to the variety of Slovenian cultural and natural landscapes, there are more than 40 distinct regional cuisines.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnology" title="Ethnology">
        Ethnologically
       </a>
       , the most characteristic Slovene dishes were one-pot dishes, such as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Ri%C4%8Det" title="Ričet">
         ričet
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Istrian_stew" title="Istrian stew">
        Istrian stew
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        <span lang="sl" title="Slovene language text">
         jota
        </span>
       </i>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Minestrone" title="Minestrone">
        minestrone
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        <span lang="sl" title="Slovene language text">
         mineštra
        </span>
       </i>
       ), and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/%C5%BDganci" title="Žganci">
         žganci
        </a>
       </i>
       buckwheat spoonbread; in the
       <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
        Prekmurje
       </a>
       region there is also
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Bujta_repa" title="Bujta repa">
         bujta repa
        </a>
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Prekmurska_gibanica" title="Prekmurska gibanica">
         prekmurska gibanica
        </a>
       </i>
       pastry. Pršut
       <a href="/wiki/Prosciutto" title="Prosciutto">
        prosciutto
       </a>
       is known as (
       <i>
        <span lang="sl" title="Slovene language text">
         pršut
        </span>
       </i>
       ) in the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_Littoral" title="Slovene Littoral">
        Slovene Littoral
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Nut_roll" title="Nut roll">
        nut roll
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        <span lang="sl" title="Slovene language text">
         potica
        </span>
       </i>
       ) has become a symbol of Slovenia, especially among the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_Slovenes" title="American Slovenes">
        Slovene diaspora in the United States
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Soup" title="Soup">
        Soups
       </a>
       were added to the traditional one-pot meals and various kinds of porridge and stew only in relatively recent history.
      </p>
      <p>
       Each year since 2000, the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Festival_of_Roasted_Potatoes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Festival of Roasted Potatoes (page does not exist)">
        Festival of Roasted Potatoes
       </a>
       has been organized by the
       <i>
        Society for the Recognition of Roasted Potatoes as a Distinct Dish
       </i>
       , attracting thousands of visitors. Roasted potatoes, which have been traditionally served in most Slovenian families only on Sundays—preceded by a meat-based soup, such as beef or chicken soup—have been depicted on a special edition of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Post_mark" title="Post mark">
        post marks
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Post_of_Slovenia" title="Post of Slovenia">
        Post of Slovenia
       </a>
       on 23 November 2012.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
        <a href="#cite_note-276">
         [270]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The best known sausage is
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kranjska_klobasa" title="Kranjska klobasa">
         kranjska klobasa
        </a>
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Dance">
        Dance
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Dance">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Ballet
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Pino_Mlakar" title="Pino Mlakar">
        Pino Mlakar
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Pia_Mlakar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pia Mlakar (page does not exist)">
        Pia Mlakar
       </a>
       were the most notable ballet dancers and members of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ljubljana_Opera_and_Ballet_Company" title="Ljubljana Opera and Ballet Company">
        Ljubljana Opera and Ballet Company
       </a>
       from 1946–1960. Pino Mlakar was also a full professor at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academy_for_Theatre,_Radio,_Film_and_Television" title="Academy for Theatre, Radio, Film and Television">
        Academy for Theatre, Radio, Film and Television
       </a>
       (AGRFT) of the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Ljubljana" title="University of Ljubljana">
        University of Ljubljana
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Modern dance
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       In the 1930s in Ljubljana was founded a
       <a href="/wiki/Mary_Wigman" title="Mary Wigman">
        Mary Wigman
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Modern_dance" title="Modern dance">
        modern dance
       </a>
       school by her student
       <a href="/wiki/Meta_Vidmar" title="Meta Vidmar">
        Meta Vidmar
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Folk Dance
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Numerous folk dances along with colorful costumes distinguishing between single and married women are found throughout Slovenia. Pueblo, Colorado, home to numerous Slovenian families who emigrated around 1900, has an annual Slovenian Folklore festival.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Festivals.2C_book_fairs.2C_and_other_events">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Festivals,_book_fairs,_and_other_events">
        Festivals, book fairs, and other events
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Festivals, book fairs, and other events">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       A number of music, theater, film, book, and children's festivals take place in Slovenia each year, including the music festivals
       <a href="/wiki/Ljubljana_Summer_Festival" title="Ljubljana Summer Festival">
        Ljubljana Summer Festival
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Lent_Festival" title="Lent Festival">
        Lent Festival
       </a>
       , the stand up comedy
       <a href="/wiki/Punch_Festival" title="Punch Festival">
        Punch Festival
       </a>
       , the children's
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Pippi_Longstocking_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pippi Longstocking Festival (page does not exist)">
        Pippi Longstocking Festival
       </a>
       , and the book festivals
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_book_fair" title="Slovene book fair">
        Slovene book fair
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frankfurt_after_the_Frankfurt" title="Frankfurt after the Frankfurt">
        Frankfurt after the Frankfurt
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2012, Maribor was the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture" title="European Capital of Culture">
        European Capital of Culture
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The most notable music festival of Slovene music was historically the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenska_popevka" title="Slovenska popevka">
        Slovenska popevka
       </a>
       festival. Between 1981 and 2000 the
       <a href="/wiki/Novi_Rock" title="Novi Rock">
        Novi Rock
       </a>
       festival was notable for bringing rock music across
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iron_curtain" title="Iron curtain">
        Iron curtain
       </a>
       from the West to the Slovenian and then Yugoslav audience. In
       <a href="/wiki/Titoism" title="Titoism">
        Titoist
       </a>
       Yugoslavia,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jazz_festival_Ljubljana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jazz festival Ljubljana (page does not exist)">
        Jazz festival Ljubljana
       </a>
       right after the World War II begun the long tradition of Jazz festivals in Slovenia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
        <a href="#cite_note-277">
         [271]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Film">
        Film
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Film">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Film actors
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Slovene film actors and actresses historically include
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ida_Kravanja" title="Ida Kravanja">
        Ida Kravanja
       </a>
       , who played her roles as
       <i>
        Ita Rina
       </i>
       in the early European films, and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Metka_Bu%C4%8Dar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Metka Bučar (page does not exist)">
        Metka Bučar
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278">
        <a href="#cite_note-278">
         [272]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After the WW II, one of the most notable film actors was
       <a href="/wiki/Polde_Bibi%C4%8D" title="Polde Bibič">
        Polde Bibič
       </a>
       , who played a number of roles in many films that were well received in Slovenia, including
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Don%27t_Cry,_Peter" title="Don't Cry, Peter">
         Don't Cry, Peter
        </a>
       </i>
       (1964),
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=On_Wings_of_Paper&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="On Wings of Paper (page does not exist)">
         On Wings of Paper
        </a>
       </i>
       (1968),
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Kekec%27s_Tricks" title="Kekec's Tricks">
         Kekec's Tricks
        </a>
       </i>
       (1968),
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Flowers_in_Autumn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Flowers in Autumn (page does not exist)">
         Flowers in Autumn
        </a>
       </i>
       (1973),
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Widowhood_of_Karolina_%C5%BDa%C5%A1ler" title="The Widowhood of Karolina Žašler">
         The Widowhood of Karolina Žašler
        </a>
       </i>
       (1976),
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dedi%C5%A1%C4%8Dina" title="Dediščina">
         Heritage
        </a>
       </i>
       (1986),
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Primo%C5%BE_Trubar_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Primož Trubar (film) (page does not exist)">
         Primož Trubar
        </a>
       </i>
       (1985), and
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=My_Dad,_The_Socialist_Kulak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="My Dad, The Socialist Kulak (page does not exist)">
         My Dad, The Socialist Kulak
        </a>
       </i>
       (1987). Many of these were directed by
       <a href="/wiki/Matja%C5%BE_Klop%C4%8Di%C4%8D" title="Matjaž Klopčič">
        Matjaž Klopčič
       </a>
       . He also performed in television and radio drama.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bibic_in_memoriam_279-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Bibic_in_memoriam-279">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Altogether, Bibič played over 150 theatre and over 30 film roles.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bibic_in_memoriam_279-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Bibic_in_memoriam-279">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Film directors
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Feature_film" title="Feature film">
        Feature film
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Short_film" title="Short film">
        short film
       </a>
       production in Slovenia historically includes
       <a href="/wiki/Karol_Grossmann" title="Karol Grossmann">
        Karol Grossmann
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Franti%C5%A1ek_%C4%8Cap" title="František Čap">
        František Čap
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/France_%C5%A0tiglic" title="France Štiglic">
        France Štiglic
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Igor_Pretnar" title="Igor Pretnar">
        Igor Pretnar
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jo%C5%BEe_Poga%C4%8Dnik" title="Jože Pogačnik">
        Jože Pogačnik
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Zobec&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Peter Zobec (page does not exist)">
        Peter Zobec
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Matja%C5%BE_Klop%C4%8Di%C4%8D" title="Matjaž Klopčič">
        Matjaž Klopčič
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bo%C5%A1tjan_Hladnik" title="Boštjan Hladnik">
        Boštjan Hladnik
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Du%C5%A1an_Jovanovi%C4%87_(theatre_director)" title="Dušan Jovanović (theatre director)">
        Dušan Jovanović
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vitan_Mal" title="Vitan Mal">
        Vitan Mal
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Franci_Slak" title="Franci Slak">
        Franci Slak
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Karpo_Godina" title="Karpo Godina">
        Karpo Godina
       </a>
       as its most established filmmakers. Contemporary film directors
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filip_Robar_-_Dorin" title="Filip Robar - Dorin">
        Filip Robar - Dorin
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jan_Cvitkovi%C4%8D" title="Jan Cvitkovič">
        Jan Cvitkovič
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Damjan_Kozole" title="Damjan Kozole">
        Damjan Kozole
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Janez_Lapajne" title="Janez Lapajne">
        Janez Lapajne
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Marko_Okorn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Marko Okorn (page does not exist)">
        Marko Okorn
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Marko_Naber%C5%A1nik" title="Marko Naberšnik">
        Marko Naberšnik
       </a>
       are among the representatives of the so-called "Renaissance of Slovenian cinema". Slovene screenwriters, who are not film directors, include
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Sa%C5%A1a_Vuga&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Saša Vuga (page does not exist)">
        Saša Vuga
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Miha_Mazzini" title="Miha Mazzini">
        Miha Mazzini
       </a>
       . Women film directors include
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Polona_Sepe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Polona Sepe (page does not exist)">
        Polona Sepe
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hanna_A._W._Slak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hanna A. W. Slak (page does not exist)">
        Hanna A. W. Slak
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maja_Weiss&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maja Weiss (page does not exist)">
        Maja Weiss
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
        <a href="#cite_note-280">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Documentarians
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Most notable documentaries made by Slovenian directors include the humanitarian films by
       <a href="/wiki/Tomo_Kri%C5%BEnar" title="Tomo Križnar">
        Tomo Križnar
       </a>
       on the Nuba people.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Film critics
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Slovene film critics include
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Silvan_Furlan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Silvan Furlan (page does not exist)">
        Silvan Furlan
       </a>
       , the founder of the
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenian_Cinematheque&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Slovenian Cinematheque (page does not exist)">
         Slovenian Cinematheque
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281">
        <a href="#cite_note-281">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Zdenko_Vrdlovec&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Zdenko Vrdlovec (page does not exist)">
        Zdenko Vrdlovec
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Rapa_%C5%A0uklje&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Rapa Šuklje (page does not exist)">
        Rapa Šuklje
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Marcel_%C5%A0tefan%C4%8Di%C4%8D_Jr.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Marcel Štefančič Jr. (page does not exist)">
        Marcel Štefančič Jr.
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Popek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Simon Popek (page does not exist)">
        Simon Popek
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">
        Literature
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Literature">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Slovene_writers_and_poets_in_Hungary" title="List of Slovene writers and poets in Hungary">
        List of Slovene writers and poets in Hungary
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Slovenian_women_writers" title="List of Slovenian women writers">
        List of Slovenian women writers
       </a>
      </div>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Authors
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Today, notable authors include
       <a href="/wiki/Boris_Pahor" title="Boris Pahor">
        Boris Pahor
       </a>
       , a German Nazi concentration camp survivor, who opposed
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_Fascism" title="Italian Fascism">
        Italian Fascism
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Titoism" title="Titoism">
        Titoist
       </a>
       Communism.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
        <a href="#cite_note-282">
         [276]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
        <a href="#cite_note-283">
         [277]
