        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Literary history
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:134px;max-width:134px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:132px;max-width:132px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pre%C5%A1ern-Goldenstein.jpg">
           <img alt="France Prešeren, best-known Slovenian poet" data-file-height="1025" data-file-width="680" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Pre%C5%A1ern-Goldenstein.jpg/130px-Pre%C5%A1ern-Goldenstein.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Pre%C5%A1ern-Goldenstein.jpg/195px-Pre%C5%A1ern-Goldenstein.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Pre%C5%A1ern-Goldenstein.jpg/260px-Pre%C5%A1ern-Goldenstein.jpg 2x" width="130"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/France_Pre%C5%A1eren" title="France Prešeren">
           France Prešeren
          </a>
          , best-known Slovenian poet
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:132px;max-width:132px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pre%C4%8Drtana_kitica_Zdravljice.jpg">
           <img alt="Zdravljica" data-file-height="4737" data-file-width="3696" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Pre%C4%8Drtana_kitica_Zdravljice.jpg/130px-Pre%C4%8Drtana_kitica_Zdravljice.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Pre%C4%8Drtana_kitica_Zdravljice.jpg/195px-Pre%C4%8Drtana_kitica_Zdravljice.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Pre%C4%8Drtana_kitica_Zdravljice.jpg/260px-Pre%C4%8Drtana_kitica_Zdravljice.jpg 2x" width="130"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          "
          <a href="/wiki/Zdravljica" title="Zdravljica">
           Zdravljica
          </a>
          " (
          <i>
           A Toast
          </i>
          ; part) with rejection mark from
          <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Empire" title="Austrian Empire">
           Austrian
          </a>
          censorship (due to potential revolutionary content; the music of Zdravljica is now the Slovenian national
          <a href="/wiki/Anthem" title="Anthem">
           anthem
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       History of
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_literature" title="Slovene literature">
        Slovene literature
       </a>
       began in the 16th century with
       <a href="/wiki/Primo%C5%BE_Trubar" title="Primož Trubar">
        Primož Trubar
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Protestant_Reformation_in_the_Slovene_Lands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Protestant Reformation in the Slovene Lands (page does not exist)">
        other Protestant Reformers
       </a>
       . Poetry in the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">
        Slovene language
       </a>
       achieved its highest level with the
       <a href="/wiki/Romantic_poetry" title="Romantic poetry">
        Romantic
       </a>
       poet
       <a href="/wiki/France_Pre%C5%A1eren" title="France Prešeren">
        France Prešeren
       </a>
       (1800–1849). In the 20th century, the Slovene literary fiction went through several periods: the beginning of the century was marked by the authors of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Slovene_Modernism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Slovene Modernism (page does not exist)">
        Slovene Modernism
       </a>
       , with the most influential Slovene writer and playwright,
       <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Cankar" title="Ivan Cankar">
        Ivan Cankar
       </a>
       ; it was then followed by
       <a href="/wiki/Expressionism" title="Expressionism">
        expressionism
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Sre%C4%8Dko_Kosovel" title="Srečko Kosovel">
        Srečko Kosovel
       </a>
       ), avantgardism (
       <a href="/wiki/Anton_Podbev%C5%A1ek" title="Anton Podbevšek">
        Anton Podbevšek
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ferdo_Delak" title="Ferdo Delak">
        Ferdo Delak
       </a>
       ) and
       <a href="/wiki/Social_realism" title="Social realism">
        social realism
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Ciril_Kosma%C4%8D" title="Ciril Kosmač">
        Ciril Kosmač
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pre%C5%BEihov_Voranc" title="Prežihov Voranc">
        Prežihov Voranc
       </a>
       ) before World War II, the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Poetry_of_resistance_and_revolution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Poetry of resistance and revolution (page does not exist)">
        poetry of resistance and revolution
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karel_Destovnik_Kajuh" title="Karel Destovnik Kajuh">
        Karel Destovnik Kajuh
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Matej_Bor" title="Matej Bor">
        Matej Bor
       </a>
       ) during the war, and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intimism_(Slovene_poetry)" title="Intimism (Slovene poetry)">
        intimism
       </a>
       (
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Poems_of_the_Four&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Poems of the Four (page does not exist)">
        Poems of the Four
       </a>
       , 1953),
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenian_post-war_modernism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Slovenian post-war modernism (page does not exist)">
        post-war modernism
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Edvard_Kocbek" title="Edvard Kocbek">
        Edvard Kocbek
       </a>
       ), and
       <a href="/wiki/Existentialism" title="Existentialism">
        existentialism
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Dane_Zajc" title="Dane Zajc">
        Dane Zajc
       </a>
       ) after the war.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Postmodernism" title="Postmodernism">
        Postmodernist
       </a>
       authors include
       <a href="/wiki/Boris_A._Novak" title="Boris A. Novak">
        Boris A. Novak
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Marko_Kravos" title="Marko Kravos">
        Marko Kravos
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Drago_Jan%C4%8Dar" title="Drago Jančar">
        Drago Jančar
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Evald_Flisar" title="Evald Flisar">
        Evald Flisar
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Toma%C5%BE_%C5%A0alamun" title="Tomaž Šalamun">
        Tomaž Šalamun
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Brina_Svit" title="Brina Svit">
        Brina Svit
       </a>
       . Among the post-1990 authors best known are
       <a href="/wiki/Ale%C5%A1_Debeljak" title="Aleš Debeljak">
        Aleš Debeljak
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Miha_Mazzini" title="Miha Mazzini">
        Miha Mazzini
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Alojz_Ihan" title="Alojz Ihan">
        Alojz Ihan
       </a>
       . There are several
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literary_magazines" title="Literary magazines">
        literary magazines
       </a>
       that publish Slovene prose, poetry, essays, and local literary criticism.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Book reviews
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       In the
       <a href="/wiki/Bukla_Magazine" title="Bukla Magazine">
        Bukla Magazine
       </a>
       , issued free of charge, both fiction and non-fiction Slovene books published in the previous month are reviewed since 2005.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">
        Music
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Music">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Slovenia" title="Music of Slovenia">
        Music of Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenian_Philharmonics" title="Slovenian Philharmonics">
        Slovenian Philharmonics
       </a>
       , established in 1701 as part of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academia_operosorum_Labacensis" title="Academia operosorum Labacensis">
        Academia operosorum Labacensis
       </a>
       , is among the oldest such institutions in Europe.
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Slovenia" title="Music of Slovenia">
        Music of Slovenia
       </a>
       historically includes numerous musicians and composers, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">
        Renaissance
       </a>
       composer
       <a href="/wiki/Jacobus_Gallus" title="Jacobus Gallus">
        Jacobus Gallus
       </a>
       (1550–1591), who greatly influenced Central European classical music, the Baroque composer
       <a href="/wiki/Janez_Krstnik_Dolar" title="Janez Krstnik Dolar">
        Janez Krstnik Dolar
       </a>
       (ca. 1620–1673), and the violin virtuoso
       <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Tartini" title="Giuseppe Tartini">
        Giuseppe Tartini
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       During the medieval era, secular music was as popular as church music, including wandering
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Minnesinger" title="Minnesinger">
        minnesingers
       </a>
       . By the time of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">
        Protestant Reformation
       </a>
       in the 16th century, music was used to proselytize. The first Slovenian hymnal,
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Eni_Psalmi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Eni Psalmi (page does not exist)">
         Eni Psalmi
        </a>
       </i>
       , was published in 1567. This period saw the rise of musicians like
       <a href="/wiki/Jacobus_Gallus" title="Jacobus Gallus">
        Jacobus Gallus
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Jurij_Slatkonja" title="Jurij Slatkonja">
        Jurij Slatkonja
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
        <a href="#cite_note-284">
         [278]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1701,
       <a href="/wiki/Johann_Berthold_von_H%C3%B6ffer" title="Johann Berthold von Höffer">
        Johann Berthold von Höffer
       </a>
       (1667–1718), a nobleman and amateur composer from Ljubljana, founded the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenian_Philharmonics" title="Slovenian Philharmonics">
        Academia Philharmonicorum Labacensis
       </a>
       , as one of the oldest such institutions in Europe, based on Italian models.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285">
        <a href="#cite_note-285">
         [279]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Composers of Slovenian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lieder" title="Lieder">
        Lieder
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Art_song" title="Art song">
        art songs
       </a>
       include
       <a href="/wiki/Emil_Adami%C4%8D" title="Emil Adamič">
        Emil Adamič
       </a>
       (1877–1936),
       <a href="/wiki/Fran_Gerbi%C4%8D" title="Fran Gerbič">
        Fran Gerbič
       </a>
       (1840–1917),
       <a href="/wiki/Alojz_Ger%C5%BEini%C4%8D" title="Alojz Geržinič">
        Alojz Geržinič
       </a>
       (1915–2008),
       <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Ipavec" title="Benjamin Ipavec">
        Benjamin Ipavec
       </a>
       (1829–1908),
       <a href="/wiki/Davorin_Jenko" title="Davorin Jenko">
        Davorin Jenko
       </a>
       (1835–1914),
       <a href="/wiki/Anton_Lajovic" title="Anton Lajovic">
        Anton Lajovic
       </a>
       (1878–1960),
       <a href="/wiki/Kamilo_Ma%C5%A1ek" title="Kamilo Mašek">
        Kamilo Mašek
       </a>
       (1831–1859),
       <a href="/wiki/Josip_Pav%C4%8Di%C4%8D" title="Josip Pavčič">
        Josip Pavčič
       </a>
       (1870–1949),
       <a href="/wiki/Zorko_Prelovec" title="Zorko Prelovec">
        Zorko Prelovec
       </a>
       (1887–1939), and
       <a href="/wiki/Lucijan_Marija_%C5%A0kerjanc" title="Lucijan Marija Škerjanc">
        Lucijan Marija Škerjanc
       </a>
       (1900–1973).
      </p>
      <p>
       In the early 20th century,
       <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">
        impressionism
       </a>
       was spreading across Slovenia, which soon produced composers
       <a href="/wiki/Marij_Kogoj" title="Marij Kogoj">
        Marij Kogoj
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Slavko_Osterc" title="Slavko Osterc">
        Slavko Osterc
       </a>
       . Avant-garde
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_classical_music" title="European classical music">
        classical music
       </a>
       arose in Slovenia in the 1960s, largely due to the work of
       <a href="/wiki/Uro%C5%A1_Krek" title="Uroš Krek">
        Uroš Krek
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Dane_Skerl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Dane Skerl (page does not exist)">
        Dane Škerl
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primoz_Ramovs" title="Primoz Ramovs">
        Primož Ramovš
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ivo_Petric" title="Ivo Petric">
        Ivo Petrić
       </a>
       , who also conducted the
       <a href="/wiki/Slavko_Osterc_Ensemble" title="Slavko Osterc Ensemble">
        Slavko Osterc Ensemble
       </a>
       .
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jakob_Jez&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jakob Jez (page does not exist)">
        Jakob Jež
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Darijan_Bo%C5%BEi%C4%8D" title="Darijan Božič">
        Darijan Božič
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Lojze_Lebic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Lojze Lebic (page does not exist)">
        Lojze Lebič
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Vinko_Globokar" title="Vinko Globokar">
        Vinko Globokar
       </a>
       have since composed enduring works, especially Globokar's
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=L%27Armonia_(opera)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="L'Armonia (opera) (page does not exist)">
         L'Armonia
        </a>
       </i>
       , an opera.
      </p>
      <p>
       Modern composers include
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Uros_Rojko&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Uros Rojko (page does not exist)">
        Uroš Rojko
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Tomaz_Svete&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tomaz Svete (page does not exist)">
        Tomaž Svete
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Brina_Jez-Brezavscek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Brina Jez-Brezavscek (page does not exist)">
        Brina Jež-Brezavšček
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bo%C5%BEidar_Kantu%C5%A1er" title="Božidar Kantušer">
        Božidar Kantušer
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Aldo_Kumar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Aldo Kumar (page does not exist)">
        Aldo Kumar
       </a>
       . Kumar's
       <i>
        Sonata z igro 12
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        A sonata with a play 12
       </i>
       ), a set of variations on a rising
       <a href="/wiki/Chromatic_scale" title="Chromatic scale">
        chromatic scale
       </a>
       , is particularly notable.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovene_National_Opera_and_Ballet_Theatre" title="Slovene National Opera and Ballet Theatre">
        Slovene National Opera and Ballet Theatre
       </a>
       serves as the national opera and ballet house.
      </p>
      <p>
       The composer of
       <a href="/wiki/Film_score" title="Film score">
        film scores
       </a>
       for 170 films was
       <a href="/wiki/Bojan_Adami%C4%8D" title="Bojan Adamič">
        Bojan Adamič
       </a>
       (1912–1995).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DSS2005_286-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DSS2005-286">
         [280]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Traditional folk music
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Harmony" title="Harmony">
        Harmony singing
       </a>
       is a deep rooted tradition in Slovenia, and is at least three-part singing (four voices), while in some regions even up to eight-part singing (nine voices). Slovenian folk songs, thus, usually resounds soft and harmonious, and are very seldom in minor. Traditional Slovenian folk music is performed on Styrian harmonica (the oldest type of accordion), fiddle, clarinet,
       <a href="/wiki/Zither" title="Zither">
        zithers
       </a>
       , flute, and by brass bands of alpine type. In
       <a href="/wiki/Prekmurje" title="Prekmurje">
        eastern Slovenia
       </a>
       , fiddle and cimbalon bands are called
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Velike_goslarije&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Velike goslarije (page does not exist)">
        velike goslarije
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Modern folk (Slovenian country) music
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Slak_lojze.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="567" data-file-width="850" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Slak_lojze.jpg/220px-Slak_lojze.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Slak_lojze.jpg/330px-Slak_lojze.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Slak_lojze.jpg/440px-Slak_lojze.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Slak_lojze.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Folk musician
         <a href="/wiki/Lojze_Slak" title="Lojze Slak">
          Lojze Slak
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       From 1952 on, the
       <a href="/wiki/Slavko_Avsenik" title="Slavko Avsenik">
        Slavko Avsenik
       </a>
       's band began to appear in broadcasts, movies, and concerts all over the
       <a href="/wiki/West_Germany" title="West Germany">
        West Germany
       </a>
       , inventing the original "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gorenjska" title="Gorenjska">
        Oberkrainer
       </a>
       " country sound that has become the primary vehicle of ethnic musical expression not only in Slovenia, but also in Germany,
       <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">
        Austria
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">
        Switzerland
       </a>
       , and in the
       <a href="/wiki/Benelux" title="Benelux">
        Benelux
       </a>
       , spawning hundreds of
       <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">
        Alpine
       </a>
       orchestras in the process. The band produced nearly 1000 original compositions, an integral part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenian-style_polka" title="Slovenian-style polka">
        Slovenian-style polka
       </a>
       legacy. Many musicians followed Avsenik's steps, including
       <a href="/wiki/Lojze_Slak" title="Lojze Slak">
        Lojze Slak
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Slovenska popevka
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       A similarly high standing in Slovene culture, like the
       <a href="/wiki/Sanremo_Music_Festival" title="Sanremo Music Festival">
        Sanremo Music Festival
       </a>
       has had in Italian culture, was attributed to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenska_popevka" title="Slovenska popevka">
        Slovenska popevka
       </a>
       , a specific genre of popular Slovene music.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287">
        <a href="#cite_note-287">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Popular music
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Among pop, rock, industrial, and indie musicians the most popular in Slovenia include
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Laibach_(band)" title="Laibach (band)">
        Laibach
       </a>
       , an early 1980s
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_music" title="Industrial music">
        industrial music
       </a>
       group.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LAIBACH_Press_Photo_2011.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="322" data-file-width="550" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/LAIBACH_Press_Photo_2011.jpg/220px-LAIBACH_Press_Photo_2011.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/LAIBACH_Press_Photo_2011.jpg/330px-LAIBACH_Press_Photo_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/LAIBACH_Press_Photo_2011.jpg/440px-LAIBACH_Press_Photo_2011.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LAIBACH_Press_Photo_2011.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Industrial_music" title="Industrial music">
          industrial
         </a>
         group
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Laibach_(band)" title="Laibach (band)">
          Laibach
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       With more than 15 million views for the official
       <a href="/wiki/A_cappella" title="A cappella">
        a cappella
       </a>
       "
       <a href="/wiki/Africa_(Toto_song)" title="Africa (Toto song)">
        Africa
       </a>
       " performance video since its publishing on
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">
        YouTube
       </a>
       in May 2009 until September 2013
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-youtube_africa_288-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-youtube_africa-288">
         [282]
        </a>
       </sup>
       that earned them kudos from the song's co-writer,
       <a href="/wiki/David_Paich" title="David Paich">
        David Paich
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
        <a href="#cite_note-289">
         [283]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Perpetuum_Jazzile" title="Perpetuum Jazzile">
        Perpetuum Jazzile
       </a>
       is the group from Slovenia that is internationally most listened online. Other Slovenian bands include a historically
       <a href="/wiki/Progressive_rock" title="Progressive rock">
        progressive rock
       </a>
       ones that were also popular in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Titoist" title="Titoist">
        Titoism
       </a>
       Yugoslavia, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Buldo%C5%BEer" title="Buldožer">
        Buldožer
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/La%C4%8Dni_Franz" title="Lačni Franz">
        Lačni Franz
       </a>
       , which inspired later
       <a href="/wiki/Comedy_rock" title="Comedy rock">
        comedy rock
       </a>
       bands including
       <a href="/wiki/Zmelkoow" title="Zmelkoow">
        Zmelkoow
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Slon_in_Sade%C5%BE" title="Slon in Sadež">
        Slon in Sadež
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mi2_(rock_band)" title="Mi2 (rock band)">
        Mi2
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
        <a href="#cite_note-290">
         [284]
        </a>
       </sup>
       With exception of
       <a href="/wiki/Terrafolk" title="Terrafolk">
        Terrafolk
       </a>
       that made appearances worldwide, other bands, such as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zakloni%C5%A1%C4%8De_Prepeva" title="Zaklonišče Prepeva">
        Zaklonišče Prepeva
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ank_Rock" title="Šank Rock">
        Šank Rock
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Big_Foot_Mama" title="Big Foot Mama">
        Big Foot Mama
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dan_D" title="Dan D">
        Dan D
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Zablujena_generacija" title="Zablujena generacija">
        Zablujena generacija
       </a>
       , are mostly unknown outside the country. Slovenian metal bands include
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Noctiferia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Noctiferia (page does not exist)">
        Noctiferia
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Death_metal" title="Death metal">
        death metal
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Negligence_(band)" title="Negligence (band)">
        Negligence
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Thrash_metal" title="Thrash metal">
        thrash metal
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Naio_Ssaion" title="Naio Ssaion">
        Naio Ssaion
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Gothic_metal" title="Gothic metal">
        gothic metal
       </a>
       ), and Within Destruction (
       <a href="/wiki/Deathcore" title="Deathcore">
        deathcore
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
        <a href="#cite_note-291">
         [285]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2009_Lent_Festival_-_Vlado_Kreslin_(4).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="667" data-file-width="1000" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/2009_Lent_Festival_-_Vlado_Kreslin_%284%29.jpg/220px-2009_Lent_Festival_-_Vlado_Kreslin_%284%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/2009_Lent_Festival_-_Vlado_Kreslin_%284%29.jpg/330px-2009_Lent_Festival_-_Vlado_Kreslin_%284%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/2009_Lent_Festival_-_Vlado_Kreslin_%284%29.jpg/440px-2009_Lent_Festival_-_Vlado_Kreslin_%284%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2009_Lent_Festival_-_Vlado_Kreslin_(4).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Folk_rock" title="Folk rock">
          folk rock
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Singer-songwriter" title="Singer-songwriter">
          singer-songwriter
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Vlado_Kreslin" title="Vlado Kreslin">
          Vlado Kreslin
         </a>
         during a concert at the
         <a href="/wiki/Lent_Festival" title="Lent Festival">
          Lent Festival
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Maribor" title="Maribor">
          Maribor
         </a>
         , 2009
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Singer-songwriters
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Slovenian post-WWII
       <a href="/wiki/Singer-songwriter" title="Singer-songwriter">
        singer-songwriters
       </a>
       include
       <a href="/wiki/Frane_Mil%C4%8Dinski" title="Frane Milčinski">
        Frane Milčinski
       </a>
       (1914–1988),
       <a href="/wiki/Toma%C5%BE_Pengov" title="Tomaž Pengov">
        Tomaž Pengov
       </a>
       whose 1973 album
       <i>
        Odpotovanja
       </i>
       is considered to be the first
       <a href="/wiki/Singer-songwriter" title="Singer-songwriter">
        singer-songwriter
       </a>
       album in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Former_Yugoslavia" title="Former Yugoslavia">
        former Yugoslavia
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
        <a href="#cite_note-292">
         [286]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Toma%C5%BE_Domicelj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tomaž Domicelj (page does not exist)">
        Tomaž Domicelj
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Marko_Brecelj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Marko Brecelj (page does not exist)">
        Marko Brecelj
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Andrej_%C5%A0ifrer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Andrej Šifrer (page does not exist)">
        Andrej Šifrer
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Eva_Sr%C5%A1en" title="Eva Sršen">
        Eva Sršen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Neca_Falk" title="Neca Falk">
        Neca Falk
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Jani_Kova%C4%8Di%C4%8D" title="Jani Kovačič">
        Jani Kovačič
       </a>
       . After 1990,
       <a href="/wiki/Adi_Smolar" title="Adi Smolar">
        Adi Smolar
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Iztok_Mlakar" title="Iztok Mlakar">
        Iztok Mlakar
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vita_Mavri%C4%8D" title="Vita Mavrič">
        Vita Mavrič
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vlado_Kreslin" title="Vlado Kreslin">
        Vlado Kreslin
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Zoran_Predin" title="Zoran Predin">
        Zoran Predin
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_Lov%C5%A1in" title="Peter Lovšin">
        Peter Lovšin
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Magnifico_(musician)" title="Magnifico (musician)">
        Magnifico
       </a>
       have been popular in Slovenia, as well.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        World music
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       The 1970s
       <a href="/wiki/Bratko_Bibi%C4%8D" title="Bratko Bibič">
        Bratko Bibič
       </a>
       's band
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Begnagrad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Begnagrad (page does not exist)">
        Begnagrad
       </a>
       is considered one of the direct influences on modern
       <a href="/wiki/World_music" title="World music">
        world music
       </a>
       . Bibič's unique
       <a href="/wiki/Accordion" title="Accordion">
        accordion
       </a>
       style, often solo, with no accompaniment, has also made him a solo star.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Punk rock
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Slovenia was the center for
       <a href="/wiki/Punk_rock" title="Punk rock">
        punk rock
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Titoism" title="Titoism">
        Titoist
       </a>
       Yugoslavia. Representatives of this genre include
       <a href="/wiki/Pankrti" title="Pankrti">
        Pankrti
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Niet" title="Niet">
        Niet
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Lublanski_Psi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Lublanski Psi (page does not exist)">
        Lublanski Psi
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C4%8Cao_Pi%C4%8Dke&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Čao Pičke (page does not exist)">
        Čao Pičke
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Via_Ofenziva&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Via Ofenziva (page does not exist)">
        Via Ofenziva
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=To%C5%BEibabe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tožibabe (page does not exist)">
        Tožibabe
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Otroci_Socializma&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Otroci Socializma (page does not exist)">
        Otroci Socializma
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Techno and tech-house
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Slovenia has also produced several DJs, including
       <a href="/wiki/DJ_Umek" title="DJ Umek">
        DJ Umek
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Valentino_Kanzyani" title="Valentino Kanzyani">
        Valentino Kanzyani
       </a>
       . Specialising in party techno and tech-house, the pair co-founded the label
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Recycled_Loops&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Recycled Loops (page does not exist)">
        Recycled Loops
       </a>
       as well as having releases on labels such as Novamute, Primate, Intec and Bassethound Records.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Theatre">
        Theatre
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Theatre">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lublana_143.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2611" data-file-width="5644" height="102" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Lublana_143.jpg/220px-Lublana_143.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Lublana_143.jpg/330px-Lublana_143.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Lublana_143.jpg/440px-Lublana_143.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lublana_143.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovene_National_Theatre,_Ljubljana" title="Slovene National Theatre, Ljubljana">
          National Theatre
         </a>
         in Ljubljana
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In addition to the main houses, which include
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovene_National_Theatre,_Ljubljana" title="Slovene National Theatre, Ljubljana">
        Slovene National Theatre, Ljubljana
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maribor_National_Drama_Theatre" title="Maribor National Drama Theatre">
        Maribor National Drama Theatre
       </a>
       , a number of small producers are active in Slovenia, including
       <a href="/wiki/Physical_theatre" title="Physical theatre">
        physical theatre
       </a>
       (e.g.
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Betontanc&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Betontanc (page does not exist)">
        Betontanc
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Street_theatre" title="Street theatre">
        street theatre
       </a>
       (e.g.
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ana_Monr%C3%B3_Theatre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Ana Monró Theatre (page does not exist)">
        Ana Monró Theatre
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Theatresports" title="Theatresports">
        theatresports
       </a>
       championship
       <a href="/wiki/Impro_League" title="Impro League">
        Impro League
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Improvisational_theatre" title="Improvisational theatre">
        improvisational theatre
       </a>
       (e.g.
       <a href="/wiki/IGLU_Theatre" title="IGLU Theatre">
        IGLU Theatre
       </a>
       ). A popular form is
       <a href="/wiki/Puppetry" title="Puppetry">
        puppetry
       </a>
       , mainly performed in the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Puppet_Theatre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Ljubljana Puppet Theatre (page does not exist)">
        Ljubljana Puppet Theatre
       </a>
       . Theater has a rich tradition in Slovenia, starting with the 1867 first ever Slovene-language drama performance.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Visual_arts.2C_architecture_and_design">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts,_architecture_and_design">
        Visual arts, architecture and design
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Visual arts, architecture and design">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Slovenia's
       <a href="/wiki/Visual_arts" title="Visual arts">
        visual arts
       </a>
       , architecture, and design are shaped by a number of architects, designers, painters, sculptors, photographers, graphics artists, as well as comics, illustration and conceptual artists. The most prestigious institutions exhibiting works of Slovene visual artists are the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Slovenia" title="National Gallery of Slovenia">
        National Gallery of Slovenia
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art,_Ljubljana" title="Museum of Modern Art, Ljubljana">
        Museum of Modern Art
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Architecture
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Modern_architecture" title="Modern architecture">
        Modern architecture
       </a>
       in Slovenia was introduced by
       <a href="/wiki/Max_Fabiani" title="Max Fabiani">
        Max Fabiani
       </a>
       , and in the mid-war period,
       <a href="/wiki/Jo%C5%BEe_Ple%C4%8Dnik" title="Jože Plečnik">
        Jože Plečnik
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Vurnik" title="Ivan Vurnik">
        Ivan Vurnik
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Štravs2011_293-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Štravs2011-293">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the second half of the 20th century, the national and universal style were merged by the architects
       <a href="/wiki/Edvard_Ravnikar" title="Edvard Ravnikar">
        Edvard Ravnikar
       </a>
       and first generation of his students: Milan Mihelič, Stanko Kristl, Savin Sever. Next generation is mainly still active
       <a href="/wiki/Marko_Mu%C5%A1i%C4%8D" title="Marko Mušič">
        Marko Mušič
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vojteh_Ravnikar" title="Vojteh Ravnikar">
        Vojteh Ravnikar
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jurij_Kobe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jurij Kobe (page does not exist)">
        Jurij Kobe
       </a>
       and groups of younger architects.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Comics and animation
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Milko_Bambi%C4%8D" title="Milko Bambič">
        Milko Bambič
       </a>
       is known for the first
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenes" title="Slovenes">
        Slovene
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Comic_strip" title="Comic strip">
        comic strip
       </a>
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Little_Negro_Bu-ci-bu" title="Little Negro Bu-ci-bu">
         Little Negro Bu-ci-bu
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WIA2001-10-08_294-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WIA2001-10-08-294">
         [288]
        </a>
       </sup>
       an allegory of
       <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">
        Mussolini
       </a>
       's career,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WIA2001-10-08_294-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-WIA2001-10-08-294">
         [288]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and as the creator of the
       <i>
        Three Hearts
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        <span lang="sl" title="Slovene language text">
         Tri srca
        </span>
       </i>
       ) brand, still used today by
       <a href="/wiki/Radenska" title="Radenska">
        Radenska
       </a>
       . After the WW II, both the comics and animated advertisements drawn by
       <a href="/wiki/Miki_Muster" title="Miki Muster">
        Miki Muster
       </a>
       gained popularity in Slovenia.
      </p>
      <p>
       The first Slovenian
       <a href="/wiki/Animation" title="Animation">
        animated
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Feature_film" title="Feature film">
        feature film
       </a>
       was the 1998
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Socialization_of_a_Bull&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Socialization of a Bull (page does not exist)">
         Socialization of a Bull
        </a>
       </i>
       , made by
       <a href="/wiki/Zvonko_%C4%8Coh" title="Zvonko Čoh">
        Zvonko Čoh
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Milan_Eri%C4%8D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Milan Erič (page does not exist)">
        Milan Erič
       </a>
       who together drew fifty thousand frames during the ten years of its making. The first entirely
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Computer_made_animation" title="Computer made animation">
        computer made animations
       </a>
       are the 2003
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Perkmandeljc&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Perkmandeljc (page does not exist)">
         Perkmandeljc
        </a>
       </i>
       and the 2008
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C4%8Cikorja_an%27_kafe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Čikorja an' kafe (page does not exist)">
         Čikorja an' kafe
        </a>
       </i>
       , both made by
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Du%C5%A1an_Kastelic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Dušan Kastelic (page does not exist)">
        Dušan Kastelic
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Conceptual art
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       A number of
       <a href="/wiki/Conceptual_art" title="Conceptual art">
        conceptual visual art
       </a>
       groups formed, including
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=OHO_(art_group)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="OHO (art group) (page does not exist)">
        OHO
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Group_69&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Group 69 (page does not exist)">
        Group 69
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/IRWIN" title="IRWIN">
        IRWIN
       </a>
       . Nowadays, the Slovene visual arts are diverse, based on tradition, reflect the influence of neighboring nations and are intertwinned with modern European movements.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
        <a href="#cite_note-295">
         [289]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Design
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Internationally most notable Slovenian design items include the 1952
       <a href="/wiki/Rex_(chair)" title="Rex (chair)">
        Rex
       </a>
       chair, a
       <a href="/wiki/Scandinavian_design" title="Scandinavian design">
        Scandinavian design
       </a>
       -inspired wooden chair, by
       <a href="/wiki/Interior_design" title="Interior design">
        interior designer
       </a>
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Niko_Kralj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Niko Kralj (page does not exist)">
        Niko Kralj
       </a>
       that was given in 2012 a permanent place in
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Designmuseum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Designmuseum (page does not exist)">
        Designmuseum
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">
        Denmark
       </a>
       , the largest museum of design in Scandinavia, and is included in the collection of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art,_New_York" title="Museum of Modern Art, New York">
        Museum of Modern Art
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MOMA" title="MOMA">
        MOMA
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">
        New York
       </a>
       , as well.
      </p>
      <p>
       An
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_design" title="Industrial design">
        industrial design
       </a>
       item that has changed the international ski industry is
       <a href="/wiki/Elan_SCX" title="Elan SCX">
        Elan SCX
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Elan_(company)" title="Elan (company)">
        Elan
       </a>
       company. Even before the Elan SCX, Elan skis were depicted in two films, the 1985
       <a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">
        James Bond
       </a>
       film series part
       <a href="/wiki/A_View_to_a_Kill" title="A View to a Kill">
        A View to a Kill
       </a>
       with Roger Moore, and
       <a href="/wiki/Working_Girl" title="Working Girl">
        Working Girl
       </a>
       where
       <i>
        Katharine Parker
       </i>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Sigourney_Weaver" title="Sigourney Weaver">
        Sigourney Weaver
       </a>
       ) was depicted as skiing on the
       <i>
        RC ELAN
       </i>
       model skis and poles.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Sculpture
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:V._Vodnik_monument_Ljubljana_front_side_2008-03.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="683" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/V._Vodnik_monument_Ljubljana_front_side_2008-03.jpg/150px-V._Vodnik_monument_Ljubljana_front_side_2008-03.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/V._Vodnik_monument_Ljubljana_front_side_2008-03.jpg/225px-V._Vodnik_monument_Ljubljana_front_side_2008-03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/V._Vodnik_monument_Ljubljana_front_side_2008-03.jpg/300px-V._Vodnik_monument_Ljubljana_front_side_2008-03.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:V._Vodnik_monument_Ljubljana_front_side_2008-03.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The sculpture of the poet
         <a href="/wiki/Valentin_Vodnik" title="Valentin Vodnik">
          Valentin Vodnik
         </a>
         (1758–1819) was created by Alojz Gangl in 1889 as part of
         <a href="/wiki/Vodnik_Monument" title="Vodnik Monument">
          Vodnik Monument
         </a>
         , the first Slovene national monument.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The renewal of Slovene sculpture begun with
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Alojz_Gangl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Alojz Gangl (page does not exist)">
        Alojz Gangl
       </a>
       (1859–1935) who created sculptures for the public monuments of the
       <a href="/wiki/Carniola" title="Carniola">
        Carniolan
       </a>
       polymath
       <a href="/wiki/Johann_Weikhard_von_Valvasor" title="Johann Weikhard von Valvasor">
        Johann Weikhard von Valvasor
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Valentin_Vodnik" title="Valentin Vodnik">
        Valentin Vodnik
       </a>
       , the first Slovene poet and journalist, as well as
       <i>
        The Genius of the Theatre
       </i>
       and other statues for the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenian_National_Opera_and_Ballet_Theatre" title="Slovenian National Opera and Ballet Theatre">
        Slovenian National Opera and Ballet Theatre
       </a>
       building.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
        <a href="#cite_note-296">
         [290]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The development of sculpture after World War II was led by a number of artists, including brothers
       <a href="/wiki/Boris_Kalin" title="Boris Kalin">
        Boris
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Zdenko_Kalin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Zdenko Kalin (page does not exist)">
        Zdenko Kalin
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jakob_Savin%C5%A1ek" title="Jakob Savinšek">
        Jakob Savinšek
       </a>
       stayed with figural art. Younger sculptors, for example
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Janez_Boljka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Janez Boljka (page does not exist)">
        Janez Boljka
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Drago_Tr%C5%A1ar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Drago Tršar (page does not exist)">
        Drago Tršar
       </a>
       and particularly
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Slavko_Tihec&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Slavko Tihec (page does not exist)">
        Slavko Tihec
       </a>
       , moved towards
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abstract_sculpture" title="Abstract sculpture">
        abstract
       </a>
       forms.
       <a href="/wiki/Jakov_Brdar" title="Jakov Brdar">
        Jakov Brdar
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Mirsad_Begi%C4%87&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Mirsad Begić (page does not exist)">
        Mirsad Begić
       </a>
       returned to human figures.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Graphics
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       During World War II, numerous graphics were created by
       <a href="/wiki/Bo%C5%BEidar_Jakac" title="Božidar Jakac">
        Božidar Jakac
       </a>
       , who helped establish the post-war
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academy_of_Visual_Arts_and_Design,_Ljubljana" title="Academy of Visual Arts and Design, Ljubljana">
        Academy of Visual Arts
       </a>
       in Ljubljana.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hinko_Smrekar_-_Ilustracija_za_knjigo_Martin_Krpan.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="650" data-file-width="975" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Hinko_Smrekar_-_Ilustracija_za_knjigo_Martin_Krpan.jpg/220px-Hinko_Smrekar_-_Ilustracija_za_knjigo_Martin_Krpan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Hinko_Smrekar_-_Ilustracija_za_knjigo_Martin_Krpan.jpg/330px-Hinko_Smrekar_-_Ilustracija_za_knjigo_Martin_Krpan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Hinko_Smrekar_-_Ilustracija_za_knjigo_Martin_Krpan.jpg/440px-Hinko_Smrekar_-_Ilustracija_za_knjigo_Martin_Krpan.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hinko_Smrekar_-_Ilustracija_za_knjigo_Martin_Krpan.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hinko_Smrekar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hinko Smrekar (page does not exist)">
          Smrekar
         </a>
         's illustration of
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Martin_Krpan" title="Martin Krpan">
           Martin Krpan
          </a>
         </i>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1917
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hinko_Smrekar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hinko Smrekar (page does not exist)">
        Hinko Smrekar
       </a>
       illustrated
       <a href="/wiki/Fran_Levstik" title="Fran Levstik">
        Fran Levstik
       </a>
       's book about the well-known Slovene folk hero
       <a href="/wiki/Martin_Krpan" title="Martin Krpan">
        Martin Krpan
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Children%27s_literature" title="Children's literature">
        children's books
       </a>
       illustrators include a number of women illustrators, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Marlenka_Stupica" title="Marlenka Stupica">
        Marlenka Stupica
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Marija_Lucija_Stupica" title="Marija Lucija Stupica">
        Marija Lucija Stupica
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/An%C4%8Dka_Go%C5%A1nik_Godec" title="Ančka Gošnik Godec">
        Ančka Gošnik Godec
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Marjanca_Jemec_Bo%C5%BEi%C4%8D" title="Marjanca Jemec Božič">
        Marjanca Jemec Božič
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Jelka_Reichman" title="Jelka Reichman">
        Jelka Reichman
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Many generations of children have been educated by the technical and science illustrations created by
       <a href="/wiki/Bo%C5%BEo_Kos" title="Božo Kos">
        Božo Kos
       </a>
       and published in Slovenian children's magazines, such as
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ciciban&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Ciciban (page does not exist)">
        Ciciban
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Recently,
       <a href="/wiki/Lila_Prap" title="Lila Prap">
        Lila Prap
       </a>
       's illustrations gained popularity in Japan, where children's' cartoons based on her illustrations have been televised.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Painting
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Historically,
       <a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">
        painting
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sculpture" title="Sculpture">
        sculpture
       </a>
       in Slovenia was in the late 18th and the 19th century marked by
       <a href="/wiki/Neoclassicism" title="Neoclassicism">
        Neoclassicism
       </a>
       (
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Matev%C5%BE_Langus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Matevž Langus (page does not exist)">
        Matevž Langus
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Biedermeier#Visual_arts" title="Biedermeier">
        Biedermeier
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Tominz" title="Giuseppe Tominz">
        Giuseppe Tominz
       </a>
       ) and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romantic_visual_arts" title="Romantic visual arts">
        Romanticism
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Mihael_Stroj" title="Mihael Stroj">
        Mihael Stroj
       </a>
       ). The first art exhibition in Slovenia was organized in the late 19th century by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ivana_Kobilica" title="Ivana Kobilica">
        Ivana Kobilica
       </a>
       , a woman-painter who worked in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Naturalism_(visual_art)" title="Naturalism (visual art)">
        realistic
       </a>
       tradition.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Impressionism_(arts)" title="Impressionism (arts)">
        Impressionist
       </a>
       artists include
       <a href="/wiki/Matej_Sternen" title="Matej Sternen">
        Matej Sternen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Matija_Jama" title="Matija Jama">
        Matija Jama
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rihard_Jakopi%C4%8D" title="Rihard Jakopič">
        Rihard Jakopič
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Grohar" title="Ivan Grohar">
        Ivan Grohar
       </a>
       whose
       <i>
        The Sower
       </i>
       (Slovene: Sejalec) was depicted on the €0.05
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenian_euro_coins" title="Slovenian euro coins">
        Slovenian euro coins
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Franc_Berneker&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Franc Berneker (page does not exist)">
        Franc Berneker
       </a>
       , who introduced the impressionism to Slovenia.
       <a href="/wiki/Expressionism" title="Expressionism">
        Espressionist
       </a>
       painters include
       <a href="/wiki/Veno_Pilon" title="Veno Pilon">
        Veno Pilon
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Tone_Kralj" title="Tone Kralj">
        Tone Kralj
       </a>
       whose picture book, reprinted thirteen times, is now the most recognisable image of the folk hero
       <a href="/wiki/Martin_Krpan" title="Martin Krpan">
        Martin Krpan
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
        <a href="#cite_note-297">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some of the best known painters in the second half of the 20th century were
       <a href="/wiki/Zoran_Mu%C5%A1i%C4%8D" title="Zoran Mušič">
        Zoran Mušič
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gabrijel_Stupica&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gabrijel Stupica (page does not exist)">
        Gabrijel Stupica
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Marij_Pregelj" title="Marij Pregelj">
        Marij Pregelj
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Photography
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       In 1841,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Janez_Puhar" title="Janez Puhar">
        Janez Puhar
       </a>
       (1814–1864) invented a process for photography on glass, recognized on 17 June 1852 in Paris by the Académie Nationale Agricole, Manufacturière et Commerciale.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
        <a href="#cite_note-298">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Gojmir_Anton_Kos" title="Gojmir Anton Kos">
        Gojmir Anton Kos
       </a>
       was a notable
       <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">
        realist
       </a>
       painter and photographer between First World War and WW II.
      </p>
      <p>
       The first photographer from Slovenia whose work was published by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Geographic_(magazine)" title="National Geographic (magazine)">
        National Geographic
       </a>
       magazine is
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Arne_Hodali%C4%8D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Arne Hodalič (page does not exist)">
        Arne Hodalič
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
        <a href="#cite_note-299">
         [293]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Sports">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Slovenia" title="Sport in Slovenia">
        Sport in Slovenia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tina_Maze_with_Olympic_silver_medal_2010.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3600" data-file-width="1904" height="321" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Tina_Maze_with_Olympic_silver_medal_2010.jpg/170px-Tina_Maze_with_Olympic_silver_medal_2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Tina_Maze_with_Olympic_silver_medal_2010.jpg/255px-Tina_Maze_with_Olympic_silver_medal_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Tina_Maze_with_Olympic_silver_medal_2010.jpg/340px-Tina_Maze_with_Olympic_silver_medal_2010.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tina_Maze_with_Olympic_silver_medal_2010.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Alpine skier
         <a href="/wiki/Tina_Maze" title="Tina Maze">
          Tina Maze
         </a>
         , a double Olympic gold medalist and the overall winner of the 2012–13 World Cup season
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Slovenia is a natural sports venue, with many Slovenians actively practicing sports.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SportSLO.SI_300-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SportSLO.SI-300">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A variety of sports are played in Slovenia on a professional level,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-medjugorac4_301-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-medjugorac4-301">
         [295]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with top international successes in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Team_handball" title="Team handball">
        handball
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">
        basketball
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">
        volleyball
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
        association football
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">
        ice hockey
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">
        rowing
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Swimming_(sport)" title="Swimming (sport)">
        swimming
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">
        tennis
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">
        boxing
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Athletics_(sport)" title="Athletics (sport)">
        athletics
       </a>
       . Prior to World War II,
       <a href="/wiki/Gymnastics" title="Gymnastics">
        gymnastics
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Fencing" title="Fencing">
        fencing
       </a>
       used to be the most popular sports in Slovenia, with champions like
       <a href="/wiki/Leon_%C5%A0tukelj" title="Leon Štukelj">
        Leon Štukelj
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Miroslav_Cerar" title="Miroslav Cerar">
        Miroslav Cerar
       </a>
       gaining Olympic medals for Slovenia. Association football gained popularity in the interwar period. After 1945, basketball, handball and volleyball have become popular among Slovenians, and from the mid-1970s onward,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Winter_sports" title="Winter sports">
        winter sports
       </a>
       have, as well. Since 1992, Slovenian sportspeople have won
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenia_at_the_Olympics" title="Slovenia at the Olympics">
        22 Olympic medals
       </a>
       , including three gold medals, and
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenia_at_the_Paralympics" title="Slovenia at the Paralympics">
        19 Paralympic medals
       </a>
       , also with three golds.
      </p>
      <p>
       Individual sports are also very popular in Slovenia, including tennis and
       <a href="/wiki/Mountaineering" title="Mountaineering">
        mountaineering
       </a>
       , which are two of the most widespread sporting activities in Slovenia. Several Slovenian
       <a href="/wiki/Extreme_sport" title="Extreme sport">
        extreme
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endurance_sports" title="Endurance sports">
        endurance sportsmen
       </a>
       have gained an international reputation, including the mountaineer
       <a href="/wiki/Toma%C5%BE_Humar" title="Tomaž Humar">
        Tomaž Humar
       </a>
       , the mountain skier
       <a href="/wiki/Davo_Karni%C4%8Dar" title="Davo Karničar">
        Davo Karničar
       </a>
       , the ultramaraton swimmer
       <a href="/wiki/Martin_Strel" title="Martin Strel">
        Martin Strel
       </a>
       and the ultracyclist
       <a href="/wiki/Jure_Robi%C4%8D" title="Jure Robič">
        Jure Robič
       </a>
       . Past and current winter sports Slovenian champions include
       <a href="/wiki/Alpine_skiing" title="Alpine skiing">
        Alpine skiers
       </a>
       , such as
       <a href="/wiki/Mateja_Svet" title="Mateja Svet">
        Mateja Svet
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bojan_Kri%C5%BEaj" title="Bojan Križaj">
        Bojan Križaj
       </a>
       , and double olympic gold medalist
       <a href="/wiki/Tina_Maze" title="Tina Maze">
        Tina Maze
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Cross-country_skiing" title="Cross-country skiing">
        cross-country skier
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Petra_Majdi%C4%8D" title="Petra Majdič">
        Petra Majdič
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Ski_jumping" title="Ski jumping">
        ski jumpers
       </a>
       , such as
       <a href="/wiki/Primo%C5%BE_Peterka" title="Primož Peterka">
        Primož Peterka
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_Prevc" title="Peter Prevc">
        Peter Prevc
       </a>
       . Boxing has gained popularity since
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dejan_Zavec" title="Dejan Zavec">
        Dejan Zavec
       </a>
       won the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Boxing_Federation" title="International Boxing Federation">
        IBF
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_welterweight_boxing_champions" title="List of welterweight boxing champions">
        Welterweight World Champion
       </a>
       title in 2009.
      </p>
      <p>
       Prominent team sports in Slovenia include football, basketball, handball, volleyball, and ice hockey. The
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenia_national_football_team" title="Slovenia national football team">
        men's national football team
       </a>
       qualified for one
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UEFA_European_Football_Championship" title="UEFA European Football Championship">
        European
       </a>
       (2000) and two
       <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">
        World Cups
       </a>
       (2002 and 2010). Of Slovenian clubs,
       <a href="/wiki/NK_Maribor" title="NK Maribor">
        NK Maribor
       </a>
       played three times in the
       <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League" title="UEFA Europa League">
        UEFA Europa League
       </a>
       and also three times in the
       <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League" title="UEFA Champions League">
        UEFA Champions League
       </a>
       . The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenian_national_basketball_team" title="Slovenian national basketball team">
        men's national basketball team
       </a>
       has participated at 13
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurobasket" title="Eurobasket">
        Eurobaskets
       </a>
       , winning the gold medal with
       <a href="/wiki/Goran_Dragi%C4%87" title="Goran Dragić">
        Goran Dragić
       </a>
       being named the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MVP" title="MVP">
        MVP
       </a>
       at the
       <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2017" title="EuroBasket 2017">
        2017 edition
       </a>
       , and three
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_World_Championship" title="FIBA World Championship">
        FIBA World Championships
       </a>
       . Slovenia also hosted the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_EuroBasket_2013" title="FIBA EuroBasket 2013">
        2013 Eurobasket
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenia_national_handball_team" title="Slovenia national handball team">
        men's national handball team
       </a>
       has qualified for three Olympics, eight IHF
       <a href="/wiki/IHF_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="IHF World Men's Handball Championship">
        World Championships
       </a>
       , including their third-place finish at the 2017 edition, and for eleven
       <a href="/wiki/European_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="European Men's Handball Championship">
        European Championships
       </a>
       . Slovenia was the hosts of the
       <a href="/wiki/2004_European_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2004 European Men's Handball Championship">
        2004 European Championship
       </a>
       , where the national team won silver. Slovenia's most prominent handball team,
       <a href="/wiki/RK_Celje" title="RK Celje">
        RK Celje
       </a>
       , won the
       <a href="/wiki/EHF_Champions_League" title="EHF Champions League">
        EHF Champions League
       </a>
       in the 2003–04 season. In women's handball,
       <a href="/wiki/RK_Krim" title="RK Krim">
        RK Krim
       </a>
       won the
       <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_EHF_Champions_League" title="Women's EHF Champions League">
        Champions League
       </a>
       in 2001 and 2003. The
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenia_men%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Slovenia men's national volleyball team">
        national volleyball team
       </a>
       won a silver medal at the
       <a href="/wiki/2015_Men%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship" title="2015 Men's European Volleyball Championship">
        2015 European Championship
       </a>
       . Slovenia will co-host the
       <a href="/wiki/2019_Men%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship" title="2019 Men's European Volleyball Championship">
        2019 European Championship
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenia_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team" title="Slovenia men's national ice hockey team">
        national ice hockey team
       </a>
       has played at nine
       <a href="/wiki/Ice_Hockey_World_Championships" title="Ice Hockey World Championships">
        Ice Hockey World Championships
       </a>
       and at the
       <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">
        2014 Winter Olympics
       </a>
       , they also qualified for the
       <a href="/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics" title="2018 Winter Olympics">
        2018 Olympics
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
        See also
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: See also">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Slovenia" title="Outline of Slovenia">
         Outline of Slovenia
        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
        Notes
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovenia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: Notes">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references">
         <li id="cite_note-4">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-4">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           As defined by the Act Regulating the Coat-of-Arms, Flag and Anthem of the Republic of Slovenia and the Flag of the Slovene Nation ("Zakon o grbu, zastavi in himni Republike Slovenije ter o slovenski narodni zastavi") from 1994 and published on the web page of the
           <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Slovenia)" title="National Assembly (Slovenia)">
            National Assembly of Slovenia
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-1">
             [1]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bozic_2-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Bozic-2">
             [2]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The question whether the entire
           <i>
            Zdravljica
           </i>
           or only its seventh stanza constitutes the Slovenian national anthem remains unresolved. Whereas the
           <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Slovenia" title="Constitution of Slovenia">
            Constitution of Slovenia
           </a>
           determines the title of the poem, the act about the anthem specifically determines its seventh stanza. It has been argued that the act contradicts the constitution and that the question should be resolved by the
           <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Slovenia" title="Constitutional Court of Slovenia">
            Slovenian Constitutional Court
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3">
            <a href="#cite_note-3">
             [3]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-28">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-28">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Slovenia's placement within the regional classification schemes for Europe is controversial.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Armstrong2007_23-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-Armstrong2007-23">
             [18]
            </a>
           </sup>
           It is often placed in Central Europe and the Balkans, but also sometimes in Southeast Europe.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Armstrong2007_23-2">
            <a href="#cite_note-Armstrong2007-23">
             [18]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Examples include the
           <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Statistics_Division" title="United Nations Statistics Division">
            United Nations Statistics Division
           </a>
           (Southern Europe),
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNStat_24-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-UNStat-24">
             [19]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">
             The World Factbook
            </a>
           </i>
           (Central Europe),
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fact_25-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Fact-25">
             [20]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Encarta" title="Encarta">
             Encarta
            </a>
           </i>
           ("south central Europe")
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_26-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Encarta-26">
             [21]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Peter_J._Katzenstein" title="Peter J. Katzenstein">
            Peter J. Katzenstein
           </a>
           ("no way to decide").
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
            <a href="#cite_note-27">
             [22]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </li>
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

            <a class="external text" href="http://www.delo.si/clanek/127578" rel="nofollow">
             "Katero kitico č'mo kot himno zapet
             <span style="padding-right:0.2em;">
              '
             </span>

            </a>

             </span>

            </span>

           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Katero+kitico+%C4%8D%27mo+kot+himno+zapet%27&amp;rft.date=2010-11-03&amp;rft.issn=1854-6544&amp;rft.aulast=Bo%C5%BEi%C4%8D&amp;rft.aufirst=Dragan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.delo.si%2Fclanek%2F127578&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASlovenia">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-3">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-3">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation news">
            Škrinjar, Klara (3 September 2012).
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.delo.si/novice/politika/zdravljica-v-politicnem-in-pravnem-primezu.html" rel="nofollow">
             "Zdravljica v političnem in pravnem primežu"
            </a>
            [Zdravljica in the Political and Legal Vice].
            <i>
             Delo.si
            </i>
            (in Slovenian).
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Delo.si&amp;rft.atitle=Zdravljica+v+politi%C4%8Dnem+in+pravnem+prime%C5%BEu&amp;rft.date=2012-09-03&amp;rft.aulast=%C5%A0krinjar&amp;rft.aufirst=Klara&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.delo.si%2Fnovice%2Fpolitika%2Fzdravljica-v-politicnem-in-pravnem-primezu.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASlovenia">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-2002census-7">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-2002census_7-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>

           <cite class="citation book">
            Armstrong, Werwick. Anderson, James (2007). "Borders in Central Europe: From Conflict to Cooperation".
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=FWA3ppuOgK4C&amp;pg=PA165" rel="nofollow">

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Borders+in+Central+Europe%3A+From+Conflict+to+Cooperation&amp;rft.btitle=Geopolitics+of+European+Union+Enlargement%3A+The+Fortress+Empire&amp;rft.pages=165&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-134-30132-4&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DFWA3ppuOgK4C%26pg%3DPA165&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASlovenia">

            </span>

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Journal+of+Applied+Business+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Corporate+Strategies+In+The+Post-Transition+Economy%3A+The+Case+Of+Slovenian+Companies&amp;rft.volume=27&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=61-68&amp;rft.date=2011-01%2F2011-02&amp;rft.issn=0892-7626&amp;rft.aulast=Lahovnik&amp;rft.aufirst=Matej&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fjournals.cluteonline.com%2Findex.php%2FJABR%2Farticle%2Fdownload%2F910%2F894&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASlovenia">

            </a>
